Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Nose is candy sugar that is roasted and yeast.  Feel is fizzy.  Flavor is fruit, yeast, and soy.  Fruit comes too late and is too little.  There just isnt enough happening here.  A disappointment..

Fra flaske, dufter dejligt af frugt, let røg... super flot meget mørkebrun nærmest sort med højt lysebrunt skum, smage super dejligt af frugter ... let røget eftersmag samt rosiner... i alt en super dejlig Abbey dubbel ! en klaaaaasikker!
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a fluffy off white head. The aroma is yeast, dark fruit, coriander and ligth chocolate. The flavour is spices, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, raisins and sweet malt.

12 oz bottle. Pours brown with a white head. Slightly malty and yeasty in the aroma with a distinct raisin note. The raisin follows through in the body with some plum as well. A bit of chocolate layered in, but a somewhat odd aftertaste. Overall a good beer, but the finish lacked the smoothness that I expected.

From notes: Poured ruby red-brown with a large light tan head.  Aroma is initially lightly yeasty, then becomes fruity-sweet.  Palate is deep and slightly oily, but medium-bodied.  Fruity flavor reminiscent of raisins that intensifies as it warms.  Nutty and chocolatey notes also appear as it warms a bit.  Very good.
A bit blend aroma, and same goes for the taste; nothing special. Some sweetness and fruity hints, but to me it lacks depth/complexity.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown colour with a small, foamy, slightly off-white head. Aroma of sweet fruits, mild honey and some malts. Flavour of sweet fruits, malts, mild honey, mild chocolate, grassy hops and some hay. Medium bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a dry, fruity finish. Good.

Poured into its glass, showing a dark red, brownish colour with a huge, frothy head, made out of big and small bubbles. Nice carbonation going on in the glass and the head lasts the entire drinking expierence. Aroma has malty hints, with an undertone of armomatising herbs. Flavour has the matls present, alongside with some plums, blackberries and kandi sugar. With a little bit of improvising and imagination, youll be able to find some chocolate. Incredibly soft and well balanced brew to drink. Really nice beer to enjoy a bit chilled, next to a fireplace while there is a storm going on outside.
Pours brown with a large beige head. Aroma is caramel, fruit, raisin and light alcohol. Flavour is roasted caraeml, fruit, raisin and alcohol.
Bottle at Kanslos, the Hague.  Really nice example of the style.  Nothing outstanding, but a good beer

Not the best Belgian Ive run across.  Dry for a Dubbel, with a winelike finish that seems out of place with the rest of the beer.  All the wanted features are there, just muted.   Im surprised at this beers meekness, especially since its at least three years old.  Obvious joke:  Corsendont.  (2008)
Is there a better brown ale out there?  A true Belgium that everyone copies themselves around.  Sometimes, its worth spending the extra money.

BPA Leiden 20110406 (33 cl bottle; blind tasting): A clear redish brown beer with a light brown head. The aroma is sweet/caramel; malty/roasted and some dark fruit (berries). The taste is sweet (caramel), malty (roasted) with some coffe and drak fruit notes. Some alcohol. In the aftertaste the beer had still some sweetness (sticky) and malt bitterness (somewhat dry). Personal this beer is to sweet.
Pour is a deep cola brown with a decent sized tan head. Nose is of bread and dark fruits. Taste is of dark fruits and sugar. A bit thick on the tongue, but rather refreshing overall.
Bottle. Dark reddish brown with a huge creamy tan head. Aroma: yeast, raisins, fruit. Taste: sweet and malty, raisins, yeast, fruit and candy. Medium-bodied with quite a lot of carbonation.
One of my personal favorites, I describe it as a liquid Chunky candy bar. Great sweet, chocolate, raisin and nutty notes abound.

Bottle at Fyrhuset Kuba. Black color with a small light brown head. Malty aroma with licorice and spices. Yesty taste with sugar and dry fruit. An ok beer but I find it misses something compared to other belgians.
This is an alright abbey dubbel ale. I have had the pleasure of having tried better ones, though.

Bottle poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Tan head that quickly diminished, good lacing around the edge of the glass. Pours thick, dark brown in color. Aroma is one of nutty, yeasty. Definitely a brown ale in flavor. Good beer.

Appearance: Dark redish brown, clear. Good amount of tan head.
Aroma: Malty, sweetness. Dark fruit, molasses.
Taste: Dark malt and dark fruit. Sweet. Enjoyable.
Info: 330ml bottle, 6/2-2011

Small bottle. Dark brown, nice head. Aroma is malty and a bit soily. Taste has a light roasty character with a modest yeast presence. Palate hasnt got much dried fruit that Im used to in dubbels. Carbonation is lively. Plain and malty finish. Good but could have been more interesting.

0.33l bottle. Pours a dark brown body with a red hue and a fading off-white head. Aroma starts with some alcohol, continues with red currants, caramel and yeast. Medium bodied and medium carbonated. Tastes nice and hopy with some yeast before it continues with a almost like green apple-sour note and dark fruits. Pokes your tongue a long time after you have swallowed. Ends lightly dry and quite quickly.

Bottle 330ml @ home
[Trade by Dedollewaitor] Pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of dried fruits, yeast and malt. Taste is light sweet.
Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft to fizzy.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2011 11.2 oz. Pours dark brown with nice half inch head that quickly diminishes. It smells very good like dark fruit and belgain sweetness. The dark fruit doesnt come through much in the taste. It is sweet and slightly smoky maybe a little sour. Thin on the palate and alcohol is not over powering. Overall a good beer but not great.

Light sweet malt aroma.  Fairly clear deep brown ale.  Thin tan head.  Lightly sweet with very dry finish.  Notes of chocolate and brown bread.  Very heavily carbonated, almost excessively so.  Bubbles scrub away the flavor before you can fully appreciate.  Nice but not very complex.
Dark brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, hervy malty, dried fruit, yeasty and light spicy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and fruity finish. 170310

Beautiful dark brown in color with a soapy off white head. Musty cardboard aroma mixed with some sweet raisins and dried fruit.  I can also pickup some nutty scents.  High carbonation on the tongue.  Some sweet dried fruit flavors; raisin and prune followed by some dry oak  and herbal notes.  Overall, its good.  Id pay again to drink some more... but not too fond of the high carbonation.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts caramel and fruits taste malts caramel fruits spices and hops
Mellow and light on the tounge with some sweetness.  Slightly ashy/nutty aftertaste.  Easy to drink.
This is a Belgian dubbel with a strong presence on the palate, it is a deep brown with notes of dark fruits, malt, and some spice.
Bottle pours a deep red/brown with a large tan head. Scent is sweet malts with fruits and yeast. Sweet taste of caramel, roasted malt and fruit.
Dark brown colour with a big off-white head and nice lacing. Malty, fruity and some caramel in the aroma. Creamy full body, a dry and spicy bittersweet flavour.

Brown pour with creamy tan head and lace. Aroma of molasses, roasted malt and a hint of chocolate. Peat, sweet dark fruit, sweet roasted malt with a nice malty finish. Medium body with slightly aggressive carbonation. Nice beer
Dark color, off white head. Fruity aroma, some yeast and caramel. Lots of yeast in the taste and hop bitterness. Bitter aftertaste.

Dark brown with som ered to it, and a massive off white head. Belgian yeast, caramel and some orange and spices. The yeast dominates the flavor and its dry and with a substantial bitterness in the end. I like that its dry but its almost too dry for a Belgian Dubble and the taste could be a little more powerful.
27th October 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Dark beer. Soft palate. Nice clear chocolate tones. Smooth and frothy. Very drinkable.
Colore marrone con bella schiuma cremosa. Aroma caldo tra caramello e punte di frutta e cacao. In bocca si dolciastra ma ben equilibrata, semplice ma efficace.

Sampled from a bottle at Mondial de la bière.  Light chestneu brown with a small white head.  Smells like a dubbel - earthy caramel.  The flavour brings in some yeast, bread and fruit to go with the caramel.  Sweetish.  Not bad.
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy very dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is yeasty, apple and burnt caramel malt.  Nutty start.  Yeast and caramel in the finish.
750 ml.  Poured a dark brown with a medium head.  Not as smooth as I anticipated due to its reputation.  Spicy with a little bite.  Drinkable though.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2012 Aroma is yeasty with some brown sugar, dark fruits and hints of alcohol.  Pour is opaque brown with a thick foamy off-white head that settles thin but continues to cover the pour and maintains a solid ring of lacing.  Taste is dark malt, and fruit hops and a ton of
Licorice.  Palate is sticky and the finish lingers with a slight caramel aftertaste.

Tap.  Pour is deep clear brown with a medium beige head.  Aroma is lightly spicy, light roasted malt, and lightly fruity.  Flavor is a bit more mild than expected.  It is light roasted malt, light fruit, distant chocolate, and light spice.  This is fine, but not nearly as full-bodied or bold as I was hoping for.

Small format bottle. Pours a rich brown body accompanied by a rocky tan head. Lace clings to glass. Aroma is malty with some smoke (as beer warms) and yeast. Flavour is a bit lactic with other evidence of malt, raisin and black cherry. Soft and creamy mouth-feel. Finish also has a slight amount of tin. Having said all that its a damn fine beer.

Bottle. Poured a rich opaque brown. Nose is yeasty with candied sugars and some roasted malts. Brown ale with Belgian yeast and hints of chocolate and caramel. Well carbonated with a dark fruit finish. Solid.
Smoky, chocolatey. Alcohol very present, but not overpowering. Darker than expected, almost stoutlike. Amazing.

Pours a dark brown, with some hints of red.  A tan head rests atop, with decent retention and lacing. Admittedly, Im a little stuffed up right now, so this might be a little off.  Malty, distinct caramel scent.  Dark fruits and malts primarily. Less caramel in the taste than the smell. Mostly dark fruits, of which I cant be sure. Very balanced taste. Very creamy, with a nice dry finish. Decent carbonation, hardly any alcohol.  I would say this is a beer to enjoy slowly.  Very drinkable.

Poured a very dark brown with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is very fruity and sweet with some doughy notes.  Lots of yeast as well.  Taste is also fruity and slightly dry.  Too much carbonation in this bottle.  Taste is slightly sweet, but not too much, and the finish is slightly dry and bitter.  Finish has yeasty and earthy characteristics.  Overall pretty good, but not amazing.

pours opaque dark brown. good carbonation gives it a nice bubbly mouthfeel. leathery dark fruit flavors, like raisin and prune, but not very sweet.  black licorice flavors are strong. some bitter, smoky, roast flavors in the finish.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Aroma of Belgian spice, brown sugar, dark fruits.  Hints mainly of the toasty malts, dark fruits, and very faint dark chocolate.  Creamy texture and flavors combine well in the palate.  Good beer.

Pours clear ruby brown with fluffy off white head leaving some lacing. Aroma is malty, sweet, hay, fidges and caramel. Thin body, slightly sourish mouthfeel. Flavor of caramel, lavendel, malts and sourish hops. Thin fruity palate. Finishes shortlived with a light tart aftertaste.

Bottle thx to tkrjukoff, cons 2010-11-27 Sätila
AR: fruity fudge
AP: light coca cola, wee ofwhite head
F: loads of carbonation, dry/sweet, wee chocolate, sugar, heavy in alcohol makes the flavors go thin, grainy

21/11/2010 - 33cl bottle @ home
Little cloudy dark brown beer. Beige irregular head, dissipates quickly, non adhesive. Aroma: caramel, liquorice, ripe sweet fruits. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: caramel, mocha, brown sugar, general fruitiness. Aftertaste: mocha, spices and caramel. 
Note: the bottle has been in the fridge for quite some time. This probably hasnt been to good for the beer. I have more of these, so it will be re-rated.
Medium brown with off-white head.  Smooth, but full mouthtaste, balancing the sweet and bitter nicely.  Drinks "easy."
Rusty brown with white head. Dark fruits. Smooth feel in the mouth.´Medium carbonated. The sweetness and bitterness in the finish goes along well. A good abbey ale!

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2013 Draft, Sharp Edge.  Poured a brown color.  Sweeter aroma. Frothy head.  Med sweetness, medium bodied.  A delicious belgium beer.  Smooth, balanced, not to sweet not to spicy like some belgiums.  I need to get a case of this stuff.  Re-rate 2013:  sharp edge:  light dark fruits, light raisins, light toffee.  Drier finish.  Slight hops at end.  Yummy.

Pours with a very large and frothy head. Sweet aroma. Very strong inital taste with a rush of toasted hops. One of my all time favorites. First time having it on draft, I might enjoy the aged bottle taste a little better.

Some (stale) malt, caramel and honey in the aroma. Light to medium body, bit too watery for my taste. Medium carbonation. Tastes like honey, syrup, sugar candy and some light hops. Makes it a very drinkable beer, but lacks body to make it a superb dubbel.

A really dark colored brown beer, with the famous light sweetness I know of old brown beer or dark beer (dutch: oud bruin of donker bier). But this is also a strong abbey beer that has a very easy drink. This really is my style and I like this beer, but I have had better in its class.
On tap at sharp edge. Appearance is a translucent brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma is somewhat fruity. Taste is like a lightly flavored, fruity candy. Smooth on the palate. All around nice.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2011 Bottle @ home.  Pours a huge tan head with a dark red/brown body.  Some nuttiness with a lot of candy sugar and darker malts in the nose.  Fairly well carbonated with a candied sugar body and darker malts.  Quite sweet flavor and aftertaste.  Flavor is pretty good but not all that exciting.  Mostly just a brown sugar flavor.

Appearance:  dark cola brown with a nice velvety light brown bubbly head, lots of legs.  Aroma:  sweet dark malts, light hint of chocolate, tons of sweet fruits (cherrries and raisins especially) in heavy syrup. Taste:  blast of those sweet fruits, yeast, spices (clove, anise, tobacco), which transitions quickly to smooth sweet malts, dark chocolate and fresh brown bread.  Finish:  medium in length, slightly sweet and malty.  Notes:  Delicious dubbel.  Palate was very nice; started out with a ton of rather sharp, refreshing carbonation, then as it warmed the bubbles became very soft and gentle.  Flavors were great; the transition from the fruit/spices to the dark sweet malt was sudden but pleasant.

Színe sötétbarna egy jó ujjnyi vastag, krémes, bézs színű habbal a tetején, mely végül vékonyan megmarad.
Az illata pörkölt, karamellás ill. élesztős.
Teste sima és szirupos.
Összetett, malátás karakterű aromájában aszalt gyümölcsös (szilva, mazsola), karamellás, pörkölt és citrusos hatások tűnnek fel, igen kellemes íze étcsokoládé jellegű.
Enyhén fanyar befejezése citrusos, pörkölt kesernyés, kiegészítve egy (melengető) alkoholos édességgel, mely végül kiszárítja a torkot és egy gyümölcsös-étcsokoládés utóízben marad meg.
Ez finom!

Bottle:
Off white foamy head on a brown beer.
Taste is bit watery and very dull in its taste.
Just some hints of (toasted) malts, yeast and dark fruits.
Also noted some hints of sugars, spices and iron.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Hazelnut pour into a sniffer glass. I was excited about this one, and ended up a bit disappointed. Faint roasted aromas with some raisins. Taste follows the nose, very noticeable raisin flavor, with chocolate notes. Tasty enough, worth trying at least once.
Bomber.  Pours a rich brown with a thick creamy head.  Notes of rasin and chocolate.  What a great beer!  If I could afford it, I would drink this daily.

Pours brown with thick creamy tan head and foamy lacing.  Notes of rich caramel malt and raisins.  Well balanced, excellent taste - an exemplary example of brown ale.  Smooth and creamy on the palate.

Hungary 2010, bottle. Black with a dense off white head. Rich malt with hints of dark fruit and yeast on the nose. Dark fruit with complex dark malts, toffee caramel, more yeastiness. Quite delicious.

Bottle. Large, rapidly diminishing, light brown head over a clear dark garnet body. Aroma-taste of raisins/sultanas, spices, treacle and peaches with a balanced body and a soda waterlike dry finish. Light to medium bodied with some carbonic acidity. Nice.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2015 Had this back at the Blind Pigs original local in Champaign. One of my very first abbey styles. Loved it. Serving: Bottle
Molasses, dark roasted malt, Cola brown, thick tan head. Dark roasted malt flavor, slightly tart with raisin notes. Molasses at midpalate. Roasted pecan finish.
33 cl bottle, pours dark with a nice creamy head, aroma of chocolate, yeast and dark fruits, taste is fruity, slightly malty, spicy with a hint of dough, ok finish, very enjoyable overall.

330ml bottle, Trappist glass.  Mahogany-brown hue, nice large foamy beige head diminishes slowly to a film.  Some pleasant yeasty, vinous, cherry, and sugary aromas but  I detect some off notes that are a little distracting. After it had warmed liquorice, golden syrup, and a brief appearance from some wonderful hoppy citrus aromas .  Fruity sugary chocolaty sweetness dominates, some bitterness, a touch of sourness.  Dry finish.  Mixed feelings about this one but overall the good way overcomes any bad.

Bottle at Maggies Attic.  A dark brown pour into a Corsendonk Christmas glass and topped with a frothy off-white head.  Aroma is yeasty with dark fruits, brown and candi sugars.  Not really all that strong of a scent but nice.  The flavor adds some spice.  Smooth dark fruits, belgian yeast, and plenty of sugary notes.  Not much in the way of alcohol showing.  Theres an ever so slight metallic finish thats the only detractor but its almost a non factor.  Pretty good beer here.  Im surprised it took me so long to try this beer and Ill have to be sure to try some of the other Corsendonk brews available sometime in the near future.

Dark brown, opaque, large bubbles on the head, light aroma, like cherry but without the fruit.  Smooth flavor, no overpowering taste (I just think "brown ale"), and even though I cant really associate the taste with anything specific, it does linger.  More high notes than low, but a good balance. Enjoyable.
Bottiglia da 33 comprata dal Besagnino; una dubbel che non mi ha detto nulla, anzi mi ha detto di non berla mai più

Amazing aroma coming from this beer. A little bit funky, with fruitiness and caramel. Taste is very satisfying, bready and dry. There is a hidden sweetness in this beer as well. Palate is cola-like, not happy about that one. Its a very good flavour, but needs to be thicker and smoother in the palate.

Rating #411, bottle from Fish n Beer, brought by Amer  

Dark brown with an ok head. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, cola, flowers and hops. Flavor is sourish yeast, hops, chocolate, cinnamon and a bit smoke in the finish - nice touch. A bit thin palate, but very soft. A nice beer, but a ratebeer-average of 3.71, is called overrating.

Dark brown beer with quite big and beige head. Aroma is complex and surprising, I was waiting dark fruits and sweetness, but first hint of aromas are very aromatic and also parfume and spicies, more fruiteness when beer is warmer. More surprises in the flavour and it is slightly different than aroma and also more that I expected, dark fruits, yeast, carnation, and still lot of spicies and aromaticity. Nicely, almost full bodied and pleasant to drink. Very interesting and unexpected beer with exceedingly lot of nuancees.
Smells like wine and woody.  Tastes like cherries and chocolate.  I like! Not worth the 9 bucks at the hotel lobby though.

Bottle 33cl. A brown ale with huge head. Smell is spicy and yeasty. Aroma is on spices like cinnamon, licorice, clove, metallic notes, its like a Christmas beer. Bit disappointed on malty side, not very complex, a watery finish.
UPDATED: OCT 13, 2010 Taste like brown leffe but with a watery aftertaste. Light hoppy aftertaste. Dark chocolate comes through as well

750 ml bottle purchased at Total Wine in Tustin about a year ago ($7.49).  Pours a dark plum color with two fingers of very beige foam.  Aroma of caramel, bready malts, yeast, some dark fruit.  Flavor also of smooth caramel, dark bread, and dark fruit.  Not overly sweet which is good, but also not a whole lot of complexity here.  I prefer the Corsendonk Pale.  (1057, 359)

Looks good and smells nice and lively on the palate, but this beer is a little lighter on the taste than I prefer. This is a tasty beer, but I would tend to reach for something with a little more body. 

I let this beer sit for a little bit and it got closer to room temperature, and it actually tasted a bit better. I had to add a taste point for this.

Pours out dark brown. Beige good sized head. Holds ok, could be just a little longer. Smells earthy spiced with some note of milk/yeast. Something pleasant inside. Lightly sour earth taste. Spiced, some metallic taste inside.Not a favourite for me, a bit to watery, but even when it should be some stronger, not complete my taste.

pours a dark brown, light enought to see light through it.  the head is fluffy, and off white.  the aroma is malty, with yeast, and earthy.  very light on hops.  the flavor is watery at first, with a middle of slight bitterness, malt, and almost earthy flavors.  the ending for me was metallic. overall pretty good, could be just eh bottle that i had of this that was metallic, because i dont remember that taste other times i have tried it.

750 ml. at a BJCP study session. Poured a dark brown with a rocky tan head. Aroma is of molasses and raisins. Some of the sweetness from the aroma blends into the taste but quicky dries out. Prickly carbonation with a light mouth feel. Overall a complex yet very enjoyable beer.

Location: Draft at the Brass Rail, 6/22/10


Aroma: The nose is dark malts, some wine-like fruitiness, chocolate, Belgian yeast, other fruity esters

Appearance: A dark brown pour with a large foamy light brown head that leaves a disappearing sheet of lace on the glass

Flavor: Taste is medium to heavy sweetness from the malts, fruits, and brown sugar, with a mildly bitter finish for some balance

Palate: It has a medium body, with a smooth and slick mouthfeel that turns slightly sticky in the end palate

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty nice beer for sure, it leans to the sweet side, but does have some balance to it.  Overall, it is enjoyable and well-made.  Im actually a bit surprised I hadnt rated it before, but it was worth a re-visit regardless.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured with a very deep ruby color and a tan, firm foam. Plum, raisin jumps out in the fruity aroma with yeast, burnt wood, molasses and roasted malts. Sweet taste in a light body and high carbonation. Aftertaste is also sweet. Alcohol is well hidden, well balanced brew. Nice one.

Draft at Sunswick, during Belgian Beer Fest 2010. Pours a dark brown with a big, creamy beige head. Strong dark fruit aroma with some light chocolate and modest yeast. Very sweet, with lots of maltiness, brown sugar, toffee and more fruits. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Lightly sticky. I loved it.
Honestly, the taste is kind of nasty. Like drinking some expired "Blood of Christ" from an abandoned 13th Century Holy Roman catacombs.
Dark, clear amber. Yeasty aroma. Some dark fruit (dates?) and chocolate notes.  Smooth and creamy on the palate with a smoky finish.
Bottled. A hazy brown beer. A strong malty aroma, notes of caramel and yeast. Taste is dark malt and caramel, spicy notes. A well balanced and pleasant beer.

Pours fairly dark brown with a little cloudiness and a big brown head. Nose is a delightful blend of dry-hopped spice and brown sugar based malt. Flavor is similar, but with added influences of yeast and a little alcohol. Like most good abbeys, Corsendonk Pater is a clinic in balancing fairly strong hops and bitter spices with a big sugary malt. Finish is long and sweet. Very good beer. The cost is high but worth it (the 750s are slightly superior to the 330s in quality, IMO).
I will confess that with each sip, the beer gets progressively better. Its not my favorite.

Draught at HopDevil, Zagreb. Rubyish brown with a thin beige head that disappeared in short time. Notes of plums, honey, licorice and dark fruit. Flavour is bready malt, dark fruits, licorice and honey. Smooth mouthfeel. Mild bitterness. Dry finish. Interesting drop that drinks well.

Bottle. Pour was deep golden copper with an aroma of caramel, toast, and fruity malt. Flavors were well blended between the darker fruits, toffee, and bread-like characters. There was a slight yeasty flavor in the brew that added to the ester profile. Overall, nice brew, and well balanced.

Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany with a deep ruby hue on the edges. Slightly above average sized, bubbly and foamy off-white, nearing beige head. Decent retention that settles in a thin bubbly layer of lace with thicker patches on the sides.

S - A lot of dark candi sugar and Belgian yeast. Some dark fruit, with it being more on the side of juicy and plum like with a good amount of raisin and some citrus as well. Fairly well spiced (spicy with a peppery and ginger aroma dominating) and a touch of licorice.

T - Starts with a mild background base of dark malt along with a strong dark fruit taste. Similar to the nose, the dark fruit included plum, raisin, and a touch of date/prune. Mid sip, some more dark candi sugar and yeast comes out along with a touch of citrus, licorice, and earthiness. Finishes with those flavors in the background and the dark fruits coming out a bit more. Also a bit of mineral taste comes out. All the flavors are a touch muted and thin however.

M - Medium (maybe a touch on the thin side) body and a bit above average carbonation. Quite smooth and just a little creamy and bubbly.

D - Well balanced flavors with a very smooth body make it very easy to drink. The slight thinness makes it pretty easy to drink too.

Notes: A touch thin and muted flavors (especially for what I was expecting). However, there is a good diversity of traditional Dubbel flavors that are balanced pretty well. Overall, a decent beer that is worth a try if you find it for a good price, but its not worth seeking out and I dont know if I will get it again as there are some other Dubbels I like better for the same price.

Sampled at LAutre Oeil in Aylmer, Quebec. Poured a beautiful hazy caramel-red colour with a big tanned creamy head. This one had excellent retention and decent wavy lace. Great aromas of red apples and other fruits, like plum and raisins, mixed in with caramel, molasse and some coffee. Smooth full-bodied creamy mouthfeel. The taste is simply incredible, with some roasted malts, raisins and the red apples show up in the aftertaste, with some mild bitterness. Great butterscotch-coffee finish. An excellent well-brewed beer I would enjoy anytime. One of my favorite dubbel so far.

Bottle. Nice dubbel. Pours a ruby red/ light brown beer with a good white head. Dark fruits in the aroma with hints of brown sugar. Taste is the same with a very nice aftertaste. One of the best dubbels out there.
On tap at a random Belgium bar i wondered into.  Pours a nice brown with perfect sized head.  Its fruity, nutty, yeasty and malty.  great carbonation really enjoyable

A really awesome beer. Pour is deep burgundy brown with a finger or two of tannish head. Aroma is fruity, malty, toffee. Taste is Sun Maid Raisins with a sweet malt character behind. Exciting and very tasty beer.

Pours a really deep red bod with a dense white head. Smell is sweet malts with notes of oak and leather, some vague raspberry hints in the back. Very interesting. Taste is full-bodied, with candy sugar, molasses and cherry notes. A good and slightly drier dubbel.
Bottle. The beer poured like a rootbeer. The smell is of raisins and oasted malt. The taste is just like what the back of the bottle said it would. Good carbonation.

Dark red with nice head. Aroma from malt, caramel, toasted bread, chocolate, dark fruits. Every eventually other taste drowns in a heavy lasting metallic taste. How can it be? Love Belgic but this was a disappointment.

75 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Deep amber colour with a ruby hue. Frothy head, less body than anticipated. Sweet raisin with some velvety carbonation, alcohol is subdued. Not as interesting as Id hoped.

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. BB 20.2.2011. Two-inch offwhite head with course bubbles, reducing fairly rapidly. Lovely clear dark reddish brown colour. Tangy, sweet malty aroma with caramel, figs, honey. Lively carbonation, medium body. Nicely balanced. Fairly dry and slightly metallic aftertaste.
Weird smoky, dusty aromas. Strong carbonation. Very modest in its palate but has a slightly bitter finish. Not very interesting on its own, but could be nice to accompany some food.

Bubblegum aromas. Yeast, bananas, apricots, peaches, mild chocolate. Very nice aroma. 
Flavours are fruity, malty. Some yeast. Weak body, slightly thin. 
Nice bubblegum candy sugar finish.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2010 Bottled from Presporska pivoteka. Well balanced. Aroma, dry fruits, honey. Taste, starts sweet with raisins, continues with red fruit ends with nice bittersweet finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Excellent beer.
Bottle. Poured a darker brown color with a minimal white head. Aroma was nutty, caramel, and malts. Flavor was yeast, herbs, and a nutty flavor. Medium body. Decent beer.
From Tap at Back Abbey,nuts, chocolate, minimal head, white foam, brown, average carbonation, This is a great Belgian beer.
Very nice dubbel. Well ballanced. Aroma and taste of malts,yeast,chocolate and dry fruits. Long lasting aftertaste with some bitterness.

(bottle) pours a hazy dark ruby-brown colour with a rocky beige head. aroma of nuts, fruity herbal hops, grainy pale malts and grass. flavour is coffee, roasted malts and caramel, with light notes of cardboard and pineapple. medium body with lively carbonation.

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of lightly toasted, nutty and milk chocolate, herbs for the hops and light dough for the yeast, with hints of raisin and cola. Head is large, fizzy, very light brown with fair lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear dark brown with an average amount of small tan particles. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and bittersweet. Palate is medium, oily with a fizzy carbonation and has slight metallic finish. A well crafted Abbey Dubbel, and a good Belgian style for someone new to Belgians to break into. Knock down the carbonation a bit, and its even more enjoyable.

Pours medium brown with large bubbled head that recedes to a thin layer quickly.  Nose is bready and musty, maybe a dark brown bread or something of that nature.  Sweet and sour flavors on the palate are noted, as well as some nice dessert spices.  Highly carbonated.  Sour finish.
Bottle 330 ml.Very dark brown body with thin lasting head.Tastes of fruits.Nice medium body and overall a well balanced brew.

Slightly sweet, with a lively mouthfeel.  Tastes of raisins and a bit of maple syrup, but this is decidedly not a heavy beer.  It is, however, a really nice, classic representation of the style.  The Brits could learn a lot from their Belgian counterparts when it comes to constructing a good brown ale.

Very dark brown pour with a lively white froth that dissipates slowly. The aroma is super vinous- grapes, raisins, caramel-port, spicy dough, backstrap molasses, brown sugar, and super subtle cocoa nib. The flavor also pervades with sweetness, though unexpected touches of roast and spice make for a chalkily crisp sensation. Plum, raisin, and all manifestations of dark fruit are powerful, as are more dark candi-sugars and some bakers chocolate. The palate is medium to full with lively, pillowy effervescence that maintains it body throughout, and finishes quite crisply. Super interesting and wholly quaffable.

Very dark brown pour with a light beige, fizzy head. Aroma has extreme notes of port, caramel, raisin, a bit of plum, dark spices, yeast, Burgundy wine, and a touch of molasses and brown sugar. Flavor is really nice, and has some unique notes that make it more intriguing than your basic abbey dubbel. A nice dry smoke is noticeable, along with touches of chocolate, more vinous notes, and dark fruit. Palate is very lively, with a defined effervescence and a light, semi-dry finish. Really a nice brew; combines solid flavor and depth with an impressive drinkability.

Wonderfully sweet, floral dubbel aroma.  A thin beer with earthy roastiness and a touch of alcohol.  None of the sweetness of a typical dubbel; dry and hints of fruit.  Pours brown with a fading white head.

Pours dark brown with a very large off white head. Aroma of malts, raisins, and cant really grasp much else. The taste is much different than the aroma, more complex and full of dark fruits, chocolate, and roasted malts. Very good.
33 cl bottle. Dark brown body with big tan head. Flavour is malt, sweet, hops and fruit.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was cola with an amazing cascade of long lasting beige head.  Nose was the weak point with this brew, as I only picked up yeast and an odd damp cellar smell.  Taste was malt, light (very surprising but pleasant) fruit cocktail, Belgian yeast, and a lovely dark chocolate that is very creamy, yet not overbearing, that lasts throughout the finish.  This is a very delicious brew, with great lacing, that I can only knock for the aroma.  If not for this one factor, I would have rated higher ... simply fantastic!
A very nice abbey ale.  Pours a medium brown with a nice cream head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is of dark fruit with a hint of spicey malts.  Medium body that finishes dry.
coca cola brown with a strong lasting head. smells deeply malty with subtle spice. dried fruit taste with subtle maltiness with lots of carbonation.

12oz bottle 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a nice off white head that dissipates quickly leaving no lacing 
Aroma: Belgian yeast, dark fruits, nuts 
Taste: Sweet malts, nutty, dark fruits. Some bitterness lingering at the finish  
An decent beer, but not worth almost $5/bottle.
bottle, pours dark brown with a tall tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar and a nice suprising pine hop.  Flavor is doughy with sweet candied sugar and again a nice hop bite.  Unique.

Pours a nice amber/dark brown colour with a large tan head. The aroma is of fruits, doughy yeast and a little caramel. The taste is sweet; kind of like raisins with some alcohol but becomes a little bitter towards the finish. Full bodied and lively carbonation. Overall a very nice beer.

750 ml bottle from Julios Liquors in MA. Cork pops very lively and it pours with a pleasant frothy head. Aroma was....undetectable (I have a cold right now :( 

Taste was very abbey dubbel - imagine a Rochefort 8 but with about half the finish. The palate was quite disappointing but that might have been due to my congestion. This was a good beer, but not great.

Bottle, 33cl - Brown dark beer with a small head. Aroma is sweet fruity with notes of coconut, sourish dried fruit, cloves and bitter orange. Flavor is fruity and dominated by dried apricots and oranges with hints of spices. Balanced beer with no hints of alcohol at all.

07.01.2010, 0,33l Bottle. Dark brown, almost black colour. Tan head. There is a stinging sharp co2 taste. Aroma is dominated by fruit, like raspberry or redberrys. The beer is lively carbonated, maybe a little to much. Smooth bitterness.

Bottled.  Pours dark brown in color with a medium sized creamy beige head.  The aroma  has rich malts, chocolate, yeast, and hints of spices and grapes.  The flavor is moderately sweet caramel malt, chocolate, slight smoke, vinous, with some light bitterness.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Enjoyable; unfortunately this falls under the category of beers that are good beers I probably wont have again anytime soon.
Pours a dark amber. Smells of raisins, yeast and barn. Taste is earthy with dark fruits, some banana and chocolate. Medium bodied but a little thin.

2007 750mL -> trappist glass.  Pours clear amber brown with a 2 finger tan head which thins rapidly.  Looks delicious and crisp!  I smell maple syrup, dried fruit, nuts and buttered toast.  Theres a hint of orange peel here too.
Taste is slightly sweet with a bitter middle and a dry malty finish.  Nice complex transitions like a Widespread Panic jam session.  The body is medium and slightly thin with great prickly carbonation.  
Despite what Ive read, this ale cellars quite well.  Ive been trying to clone this one for a few years but cant quite match the complexity.  Ill gladly come back and humbly study the bottled wisdom of these monks.

330mL Bottle. Rated blind. Eleventh out a a set of 12 Abbey Dubbels. Gusher, apparently. Pours a 

hazy dark red-amber, with a good tall head in rocky flesh. Aroma is 

sharp and kind of hoppy. Alcohols ring loudly, with a refined yeast 

character beneath. Flavor puts forth a similar, kind of sharp hoppy and 

phenolic yeasty (almost plastic like). Beneath the sharpness, theres a 

very mature, sophisticated raisiny malt character, some toasted 

fruitcake, and strong brandy. The body is nice, playing between chewy 

sugars and rising alcohols. Underneath the rather sharp yeast and 

alcohol surface is a pleasant malt body. Decent, but a bit uneven.
GUESS: Allagash or Ommegang
bottle, dark brown colour with nice and foamy , stable white head. Fruity smell. Taste: yeasty, fruity, roasted malts, mild sugary. Nice beer!
Bottle. Brown body with Medium head.  Flavor of raisins malts, maybe a hint of chocolate... maltiness stands out

(br-btl wh-paint, 7.5%)

roasted-malty, dark-fruit(currants), yeast-complexity, §alchl

Pours very dark amber with a thick, foamy, off-white head. Aroma is a bit earthy and with nuts and dark malts. Quite intense flavor that is mildly sweet, bitter and dry. Well balanced. Creamy texture and good carbonation. Quite short dry finish.

A: Wonderful dark brown almost black color. Pours with a nice thick head that recedes to a rim around the glass.

S: Dark fruits, chocolate, molasses and spicy brown sugar.

T: Tastes just like it smells. raisins, brown sugar, and hints of chocolate, and a slight underlying sourness. Not much just enough to raise the complexity.

M: Medium bodied and bubbly.

D: Nice and smooth drinking beer.

Clear brown with sustained head that leaves nice lacing, wasnt expecting such clarity... aroma of dark fruits, belgian yeast, some chocolate... Flavor is fruity, chocolatey, yeasty... Very dry... medium bodied, decent beer, but i wouldnt seek it out again over a beer ive yet to try....
Bottle (in NZ). Aromas got everything, cloves, spice, fruit, chocolate, raisins. And the flavour doesnt disappoint either, though perhaps there is a little bit of harshness on the palate.

Brown pour ruby hue creamy off white head lacing ... fruit and malty aroma ... taste of dark fruits raisins caramel chocolate little roasted malt and some light spice ..... finishes with a slight bitterness .... alcohol hidden well ... very clean and very tasty ... sessionable and a keeper

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Pours a dark amber color with a medium head that goes away fairly fast. Aroma and taste is fruity with some malts. The taste is not very complex but it does have a nice body with a mild bitter aftertaste. I think this is a solid ale... for me it is not one of the great beers but have always enjoyed the ones Ive had.

I felt like this one was pretty bland in the taste department. Pours a beautiful brown with a somewhat dark head and smells wonderful of tangy brett. But the brett bites hard into the tongue on the initial taste but fades and doesnt leave much of an impression after swallowing. It doesnt stay around. Decent and smells fantastically tangy. Nice one, but not for the price.

Bottle. Poured a clear cooper amber with a thick off-white head. Aroma was full of yeast and light fruit notes, particularly apples. Flavor has bit of smokiness as well as some light fruit again and yeast notes.

pours out clear burnt brown with a tall fizzy lumpy beige head.  the body is a deep dark amber in the light bit it is mainly a light brown all around.  the aromas are sweet and pleseant.  i can sense dull licorise, fennel, chives, some alcohol, apples, and raisins.  it is medium to almost full body with a substantial amount of carbonation and a grainy bubbly mouthfeel.  it is a sour bitter at first then it opens up to smokey wood, onion, bitter fruit, some yeast, pale roasted malts, and apricot.  it finishes very dry, and aftertaste is pretty mellow but lingers on for a little while.  not bad for a dubbel but definatley not my favorite.

Pours a rich purple with a medium-sized cream-coloured head. It has a fruity aroma of hops and berries. It tastes of burnt malt, hops and fresh berries. It has a slightly thin mouthfeel, although not extremely thin. Overall, a pretty good beer, although the aroma and appearance are a notch above the taste of the beer itself.

Bottle at Union Jacks poured into a Corsendonk Trappist glass (which I bought for $3.00) produced a dark brown body and medium light brown head that was creamy and long lasting.  Taste was dominated with spices and dark fruits.  The complexity of flavors and aroma increased as the ale warmed.  Another very enjoyable Belgium ale.

On tap at "Le Belge" in Offenbach, from a Corsendonk chalice. Its actually "Paternoster", you know. ;=)

Reddish dark brown colour; medium, creamy beige head with some lacing.

Intense aroma of licorice and orange peel. Medium to low carbonation, medium body, slightly grainy mouthfeel despite the alcohol.

Taste is not too sweet, fortunately (something I detest in some Belgian ales), herbal spices and aniseed dominate. Rather bitter at first, then getting slightly sweeter towards the finish, but then dry again. Interesting! Mildly alcoholic after taste - otherwise, the alc seems well integrated, the beer on the whole well-balanced and compelling, if not terribly complex.

Very good, highly sessionable(!) Belgian dubbel.

Bottle from Mr Lawrence Wine Merchants, Brockley. Pours a dark brown with an impressive biege head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruits. interesting flavours. Licorice, raspberries, dark chocolate, brown sugar. Finishes sweet  with malt and hop notes.

750mL Bottle -- At first I was unimpressed with this brew, but as time went on and the temperature in my glass rose so did my satisfaction.  I still think it is a little thin on the palate but the flavors and complexity are there.
A litle over aged bottle but still marvelous. Nice sweet chrystal malt aroma that is also present in the taste with a lively fizz. Wery nice color and a fine but short foam.

Pours a nice brown color with a huge foam head.  After the foam subsides the beer presents itself as a nice brown ale.  Has a nice feel/body to it and a malty and nutty flavor.  It just isnt worth the price though.

pours a deep brown with an off white head, smells terribly like stale bread to me every time i drink this but its what it tastes like that really matters. this stuff is up there with the best of the best in taste in belgium. a wonderful mixture of plums and pears that hit you at the same time as chocolate and belgian baked bread, while you get a strong malty presence. ends dry but full of flavor, leaves you always wanting more.

The bottle looks very simple, a bit too simple, I think. The beer in the glass very dark, almost black, nice head. Starts malty and strong, quite fruity with notes of plum and raisins. Very soft finish, well balanced, warming aftertaste. Not bad!

Very nicely done.Pours a cola brown with a big head. Aroma is wonderful full of fruit bread and malt. Flavor has a touch of root beer. Finish is exceptionally smooth. Very easy to put a few of these away.

Bomber into pint.  Dark brown with some clear brown around the edges, medium carbonation and huge dark tan head.  Taste is a bit like beef stew in a delicious way, nice body.  Plus at $9 a bomber pretty happy with it.

750ml shared with Pipper. Clear brown body with nice lacing light khaki brown head.  Aroma is wheaty, yeasty, and fruity with cereal notes.  Flavor is the same pretty much with a nice hop profile... nice fall beer.  Medium body with fine light carbonation.  Overall: good, but not supremely unique.
330ml bottle. Pours dark brown. Off-white head. Aroma has cola malt and brown sugar. Flavor is from roasted malt, is sweet, has brown sugar and some chocolate. Bubbly palate and mild bitternes.

Pours a dark brown color with a loosing cream head.  Aroma of smokey roasted malts.  Flavors of dry fruits like raisins and plums.  Roasted malts and some coffee.  Sweet and spicy, good carbonations, with a dry ending. Full of tastes, very pleasant.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2009 750 ml. bottle. pours a thick rapidly deflating beige head, over a clear, dark reddish brown (SRM 33) body.....nose is sweet malts, bit of coffee, cocoa, barnyard.....taste early is sweet malts, balanced by dried fruits (raisin, cherry) followed by roasted malt and hop bitterness....mouth feel is rather light, carbonation medium. This is a pleasant Dubbel, but does not have the layers of nose and taste that the best have.

Aroma: Malty, fruit presence (aroma was overall too light). Appearance: Dark brown with big head that has medium retention. Flavor: Malts, caramel, some dried fruit presence, and a bit of bitterness. Palate:  medium body, lively, finish was faded faster than i would have liked.  Overall: good beer but not quite enough flavor or special characteristics that make it stand out to me.

Bottle. Pour dark brown, settles into a gorgeous amber. Thick frothy tan head which reduces slowly. Aroma of fruits, malts, and hints of chocolate. Body is outstandingly moderate and the finish is extremely smooth. Highly recommended ale.

On tap in an abbey glass. Dark brown with a white head.  Aroma is all sweet malts and caramel.  Flavor is big sweet malt, nuts, and caramel up front which transitions into dark fruits and finishes roasty.

Bottle shared by my neighbor.  Im surprised Ive never tried this one before.  Nice sweet malty, fruity aroma. Brown in color with a fluffy white head.  Flavor is sweet with dark fruits, malts, and some yeast. Heavy carbonation.  A pretty decent dubbel.
33cl bottle.  reddy brown colour.  A nice beer but doesnt stand out.  Still very nice

Bottle shared with Bigmmartin, thanks holmes.  Pours a deep brown with a frothy tan head.  Aroma is stong with sweet malts and dark fruits.  Notes of chocolate, raisens, port wine, fruity yeast, and caramel.  On the palate, it is thick and smooth.  The flavor pulls out the dark fruits, giving it a sweet, dry finish.  Very good.
750mL Bottle. Lovely beer! Pours a nice deep brown colour, thick tan head. Beutifully balanced beer, with great chocolate, dried fruits. Finish with some bitterness, but very smooth.

Bottle.  Pours a fantastic deep golden brown, with a nice thick tan head.  Aromas are very muted, but there is some port wine and chocolate.  The flavors are good, there are some dried fruits and good bitterness.  Overall, while the mouthfeel is nice and well carbonated, the flavor seems thin.  The good Belgian yes profile is there along with good flavors, but it isnt as concentrated and full as expected.

Nice deep brown color with a fluffy head and great retention. Full of port wine aromas along with chocolate and some cherry and raisins. Theres nothing like Belgian yeast. For a darker beer, it sits light on the palate and the carbonation makes the flavors dance. Very nice traditional abbey ale.

Bottle 33cl.
Poursa a clear copporbrown colour with a good size head and normal carbonation.
Very fruity smell to it, has also got some nuts there and sweetness.
Taste is good balance between dried fruits and bitterness, has a very nice palate also.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2010 Bottle, best before date shows 06/09/04 (??!!). Bought in a liquor shop at Urk. Chocolate brown colour, lots of carbonization, big, thick creamy coloured head. Aromas of chocolate, pepper and spices, something coffeeish, figs and cassis. Soft taste, cassis-like, with berrries. a bit acidic also. Finish not great, quickly fading. Because of the strange best before date I will taste this once again sometimes.
11 feb 2010: Now recent bottle, same aroma and looks, taste is not fruity now, more malty, hops and bitterness. Finish is good, and slightly bitter.

Bottle at Staminee de Garre in Brugge, Belgium.  Awesome clear dark brown appearance with a thick, creamy off-white head.  Aroma is malt, dark fruits, yeast, and mild smoke.  Flavor is great with caramel malt, roast, dark fruits, vinous notes, raisins, and chocolate.  Medium-full body, slightly creamy on the palate.

Bottled.  Poured clear coppery brown with a creamy cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up rich dark fruits, toasted figs, and a pinch of chocolate with dry, fresh yeast laced throughout.. a touch phenolic on the edges, but otherwise well presented.  The flavor had currants, dark fruit, and berries on a bed of caramel at the core.. peppery yeast was laced throughout, and alcohol was more and more apparent as it warmed up.. spicy finish with more dark fruit.  Medium-plus bodied with heavy, filling carbonation on the palate.. balance was OK.  Solid brew overall.

Pours a clear copper-amber body and a beige head that laces.  Smells of candied nuts, yeast, and fruit.  Flavor is dried fruit, vanilla, yeast, and some citrus.  Finish lingers some.  Little oily and sweet.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 Pours brown, nice beige head, good lace. Nose of malt, nuts, yeast, fruit. Taste is yeast, caramel, malt, roasted nuts, slightly bitter finish. Overall a very good brew that I enjoy every time I have it, the perfect balance of roasted, malty, fruity goodness.

Bottle sampled at the Belgian tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 7/16/09.  Cloudy brown pour with a big tan head.  Malty aroma with lots of caramel and some Belgian yeast.  Yeasty flavor up front giving way to caramel malt and a bitter thin finish.

Solid dark brown color with a beautiful slightly off white head. Nice lacing as well. Unfortunately I think this was the highlight of what was otherwise just a very good beer. Not quite outstanding in my eyes. The aromas were very good. Plenty of roasty malts, caramel, candied nuts, plums, and other fruits on the nose. Yeast also. Especially up front. The flavors just werent quite there for me. Raisin and malt. I think Im being overly hard on this beer. Still very good just not quite great in my eyes.

(Sample Date: 7/11/2009   Source:Other)   Clear deep mahogany brown with a huge rocky off white head that collapses quickly. Caramel and roast aroma with slightly sour hints and light spicy phenolics. High carbonation, medium body and fizzy mouth feel. Flavor is caramel, dark sugars, and dark fruits with hint of roastiness and chocolate and a very slight sour twang. Finish is medium and lightly spicy with just a touch of residual bitterness. Yummy.
Well I thought the commercial description was right on.  Very complex beer with a distinctive taste and very drinkable.  Smooth and tasteful, definitely will drink this brew again.

Smells rich and malty. Looks quite dark, not quite a black pilsner, you can still see the light through it. A strong malty taste that doesnt ovrepower and lots of carbonation make it feel good and taste good.

Okay here is they deal if there was a belgium beer that I thought would change the minds of non beer drinkers this would be it. plumes and sugar on the nose. Pours heavenly brown with a nice white head. This beer as a fantastic mouthfeel medium body that is so crisp and smooth I thought I was drinking silk. Flavor was brown Utopia in a bottle. Chocolate. plum raisin and sugar made this brew an incredible experience.

Bottled.
Brown with beige head. Aroma of malt, yeast and dried fruit. Flavor is caramel, raisins, alcohol and chocolate

Pours nearly solid brown, I can tell this bottle is a few years old from the gigantic yeast blobs that pour into it. The head on this beer is beige and very large. Aroma is obviously Belgian yeast along with honey and ripe fruit. Taste is mellow yeast and roast malt. Very smooth texture but once again I think it has mellowed a bit. After reading "slightly smoky" I can pick up on it, but before it just seemed like toasted bread.

Pours deep reddish brown with a beige head and excellent retention. Aroma of malt, yeast and dark fruits. THe flavour is full. Notes of plum, chocolate, bread, roasted malt and slightly alcoholic. Good mouthfeel and a very dry finish.

dark brown beer with a foamy head. 
sharp yeasty smell, with some citrics and hints of fruit.
The palate starts with a promise of chocolate which dissolves into a rather bitter liquorice taste. Does have a solid yeasty taste although its rather undefined.

Pours a chocolate brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is initially molasses and dark fruits. As it warms the aroma becomes hoppy. Citrus, soft fruit, chocolate, herbal notes and malt on the nose. The taste is very disappointing as compared to the nose. Dark fruit, chocolate, a little biscuit and unrefined malt. palate is nice. The taste just disappointed me.

POSTER DRANK ONCE !
Struggling back from illness this beer had been sitting waiting. Loved the Agnus and expected much from the brown. The appearance was solid and dark, and the smell malty and potent. Head thinned rapidly and the effervescent brown brew was malty and hoppy, with some treacle. A little like the Het Kapittel Pater but slightly more distinguished and effervescent. Wanted perhaps just a little more mystery

Pours a dark, ruby amber.  Long lasting foamy brown head with lacing.  Aroma of caramel, yeasty malt and ester.  Taste is yeasty, a little bready and ends with some sweet caramel/toffee notes.  A good dubbel

Bottle. Pours a deep, rich, clear reddish tawny-brown. Looks similar in the glass to St. Bernardus 12! Great, persistent, off-white head, with okay lacing. Aroma is much hoppier than expected, and in absolutely no way is that a bad thing! Pine resin, citrus, funk, molasses/treacle, pretty light fruit character, and much more interesting and delicate than expected. Compared to nose, palate is numb, dull, like a duck that has been struck on the head. Basic, plummy, malty, coffee, citrus hops. Good, but with big holes in the palate.
Bottle. Lesser of the two prevalent Corsendonk. With saying that it is still a great beer.

This beer is very easy to drink considering its dark color; not nearly as heavy as it appears.  Quite heavy carbonation and a large head which dissipates quickly even in the tulip glass from the brewery.

This beer has a very dark brown body light barely passes threw, might be a bit cloudy but I cant tell because the beer is to dark, it also has a massive pillowy beige head. The aroma was yeasty and of dark fruit, maybe some nuts in there to. Feels soft and highly carbonated in my mouth, its also very dry. The flavour is very red wine like and maybe a little sour, Im also getting some dates or prune flavours at the back of my throat. Im trying really hard to like this beer but its just letting me down, dont get me wrong this is still a good beer but theirs just better abbey style beer out there."

Pours a very deep brown with a soft pillowy head that dissaptes quickly.  Smells of rich malts, caramel, and some nice hints of spice.  There are some pleasant notes of dark fruits as well.  The spice is most noticeable.  But the malts come through giving flavors of chocolate, prunes, and subtle candied sugars.  Very nice.

Dark brown, fluffy beige head. Lots of raisin and plum in the nose, also some banana and pepper. Smooth mouth has some chocolate, sugary raisin, more and a dark fruit finish. With warmth, the roasted malt gets a little ashy and smoky. Very smooth and laid back thanks to only moderate carbonation and a relatively large body. Surprisingly warming. Im not a huge fan of the style, but this is quite pleasant.

Enjoyed via 11.2oz bottle.  Pours a medium brown to medium-dark copper.  Nose of spices, perhaps a little clove, and a touch of banana and darker fruits.  Palate seems to be an interesting balance of sweetness up front and some sourness at the finish, almost what one might expect from an Oud Bruin.  Perhaps a little bit of caramel, some alcohol, and a wee bit of prune.  Well crafted.
Dark fruits, chocolate and malt in both the aroma and the taste. Fairly dry. I like it but it is maybe a bit unexciting.
Tabac et sucres bruns. Ça goûte bon en bouche. Beau malt jouflu. Mais pas très complexe. Cest toute. Jen bois une.

12 oz bottle thanks to machfive55. Pours a deep brown color with a huge fluffy beige head. The aroma is very nice; spices, nutmeg, light oak, roasted chocolates. The flavor is awesome; smooth and rich chocolates, tons of yeast, light fruit, a spicy backbone. A full and creamy palate. The thing I liked most was how unassuming this beer is, it is simple and quaffable but also awesome. A superb brown ale.
33 cl bottle. Brown color with a large off white head. Weak aroma of caramel, flavor is also weak of dark fruits and roasted malt. Thin beer that was boring.
Bottle shared with Steve and Eric.  Pours a beautiful brown with a thick tan head.  Aromas of smokey fruit and a belgian monastery.  Flavors of plum and figs and hints of choc.

Pour is a deep reddish brown like polished wood. Big tan head moderately creamy. Smells a little sour with caramel sweet undertones. Taste is sour and woody with cherry and mushrooms Feels light in the mouth without being watery. An easy beer to drink,

Pours a dark ruby-brown with a lasting layer of off-white foam and some lacing. Aroma is sweet and fruity, reminiscent of sorghum ale, oddly. Tastes disarmingly quaffable - sweet with a hint of smoke, spicy finish, a tad watered-down but still quite pleasant. Milky, though thin body with light carbonation. Well-executed and quaffable Belgian ale. Yum!
12 oz bottle as picture shows.  Pours a dark brown with off white head.  I was really impressed with this dubbel.  The beer description is very accurate.  Excellent palate.
I thought this one was lacking a pronounced flavor, but it was still pretty good. Easy to drink,  but Ill take a Westmalle or Chimay over this any day.
Apperance is almost dark. Aroma and taste, good and fruity. I tought about Westmalle dubbel when I tried it, but less taste.

Bottle split with BillVanE.  Man, theres a lot going on here, but nothing really standing out further than anything else.   A decent amount of malt and hops in the nose, a hint of smoke in the taste, a little bit of darker fruits and a yeasty finish encompass this great brew.  Not sure if its worth the price (not sure of the price) but a great easy drinking treat.  Cheers!

330ml brown bottle. Van Steenberge brewed version, BBD 29/03/07. Brown coloured, showing some haze. Small tan head, tight, creamy with good retention and lacing. Aroma is raisiny malt, slight fruity notes. Malty flavour, chocolate biscuits, yeasty. Finishes yeasty with some chcolate. Medium mouthfeel, soft bodied, tight persistent natural carbonation. Classic dubbel.
Dark bronze/brown with persistent thick tan head.  Sugary, hint of honey or molasses, and lightly chocolate.  One of my favorite Belgian beers recently.

Dark brown body. Light, light brown head, quite lasting actually. The aroma is spicy, fruity and sweet. Maybe a hint of yeast. A buttery finish, and a taste of brown sugar and tar. Mmmm.

(Bottle, Tromsø, 14.11.2008)

0,33 LITER bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. BB 02/10/09. 
App.:  Deep reddish brown with a some loose, bubbly tan head.
  
Aroma:  Bright fruitiness, lots of brown sugar and some molasses, very malty with some dark dried fruits as well, sweet but with definite tang, grapes, vinous, a little citrusy and spicy.
  
Palate:  Medium body and soft but full effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much more fruitiness with definite orange peel and citrus, still a goodly amount of brown and burnt sugars, some minty herbals, some cardboard; off-dry with a bit of brightness and a touch of bitterness. 

Might be a bit tired.  Still not bad.

Bottle Trappistenhuis Gent. Pours dark  maroon brown with a huge head. Maybe overcarbonated or dirty glasswork but probably the first. Molasses, kandi sugar and burnt sweetness upfront. Flavor sour bitterness and bit metallic mouthfeel.
31.12.08: Very impressive bottle in tin box, but the taste was more disappointing. I am not a big fan of Belgian beer, that is probably why.
Draft. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are malt, fruits and spices.

Picked up single 750 ml bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits. Pours a semi-clear dark brown brew with a thick and lumpy off-white head that has some nice retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, some light toffee, hint of chocolate, cinnamon and some raisin. Taste is sweet, medium to full bodied, with flavors of dark caramel malt, raisin, a hint of prunes, candi sugar, and some cherry. Finish is semi-sweet, a mild alcohol warmth with a sweet caramel and raisin aftertaste. Nice!

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Very fruity. Caramellic moderate bitter flavor. Powerfull fruity notes. Long nice moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. nice beer.

Pours a dark brown color that allows just a hint of amber light around the edges. Head is off-white and quickly fades to about 1/4 inch and holds, some lacing observed. The Aroma is rich with raisins, chocolate, toffee, and Belgian spices. The flavor mirrors the mirrors the aroma with emphasis on the spices (Cardamon, cloves, and allspice). The mouthfeel was medium, smooth an satisfying; the carbonation was lively and appropriate. The finish was long with dried fruits. Overall: This is an excellent Belgian. Recommended.

Pours copper-brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Not a lot of lacing.  Malty, caramel aroma.  Heavy phenol/medicinal scents with nutmeg and earthy bread.  Mouthfeel is lighter than expected; the carbonation makes this much easier to drink than other, syrupy dubbels.  Mostly dark dried fruits blended with candy and brown sugar in the taste.  Again, the alcohol, while not very high, is noticeable.  Sweet without cloying.  Not what I expected, but a good beer, nonetheless.

Average size, fizzy head, strong carbonation similar to pop. Weak  aroma, smelled slightly like Belgium yeast.. Not much head retention, dark red body. Taste slightly roasted sweet like raisins or prunes malt. 2 stage beer, creamy sweet to mild coffee bitter. Mild creamy body with soft carbonation and a mild finish. Poured 12oz into glass. Good beer.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2009 Tried it warmish, but personally preferred it quite cold. Very thick head that you can feel all the way through the drinking process. Better than nearly all the Belgian browns Ive tried except for Kasteel and the Corsendonk Christmas Ale. Aroma is weak. Medium dark brown color. Raisin, coriander, cloves, yeast, nuts. I agree with the cinnamon and fig. Finished a bit more sour than it started, but the rich, creamy, foamy palate never wavered. Very nice, although, the Christmas Ale is still their best in my assessment. Ill have to try the Tripel as well.

Poured a nice deep brown with a foamy tan head, that lasted long into the beer.  The aroma was malty with some fruity notes.  The flavor was complex, chocolate, fruity, nutty with roasty notes.  Some hops come through a little as the beer warms then fade away quickly.  A well brewed, clean and tasty brown ale.  Nice.
11.Xoz bottle.  Light brown... weak aroma. A bit yeasty, somewhat malty with standard Belgian taste mixed with a little bit of mild hoppiness.

3qt 5oz bottle Best by 2002.  Poured in late 2007.  Trappist glass.
Not necessarily an aging beer, it was falling apart when we finally celebrated graduation of a roommate with this old dusty bottle.
Slightly fermenty sour aroma with smoke and some red fruit.  Slight sour with raisins and chocolate, mellow compared to a newer bottle.  Foamy smooth palate.  Little to no head on the beer, with large quantities of protein aggregates...which one would expect.

Overall, gains some character after a few years.....use a coffee filter if aggregates aren’t your style, I did not mind them in the least.

Dusty caramelized figs with a sight cinnamon notes.  Dark brown color with hints f orange, medium frothy head with nice lacing. Malty spicy sweet with bitter orange peel, some tart notes, a little clove in there. Highly carbonated, medium body, smooth molasses finish with some alcohol warmth.  Solid beer.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2009 Fantastic Beer that started out no better than Sam Adams American Ale, but then I realized that the flavor improved as it warmed. Drink this only slightly chilled, and not with sushi. It has a little of the Orval alcohol sting to it that I did not find too pleasing.

Bottle from my sister for Christmas.  Poured a dark, red tinted brown with a medium to large tan head.  Aroma of yeast, brown sugar, light hints of caramel and fruit.  The palate was pretty good with a healthy amount of carbonation.  Coated the mouth well.  Nice blend of flavors that got better with time.  Caramel, brown sugar, cocoa, yeast and fruit.  A really well done beer in a style that I really like.
Dark brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Flavor of caramel and chocolate malt, slight bitter finish.  Good one.
Brown with some cloudiness and an off-white foam head. Very carbonated. Lots of winter berries, treacle and sugar and some hints of tea on the end. Nice.

Bomber, generously shared by Arthur.  Pours dark brown with a good sized cream head.  Soft aroma of sweet malt and earth.  This beer starts soft, dancing lightly on the palate with a full-bodied mouthfeel and crisp carbonation.  Soft fruit and malt ease in, blending with a delicious nutty character.  Corsendonk finishes with lingering sweetness, complemented with some toasted chocolate.  Really nice.  This beer reminded me of Rochefort 8, although Im sure the styles are quite the same.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with an extremely large, brownish head.  Aromas of chocolate, raisins, port, and molasses.  Very lively palate with a thin, oily texture.  Long aftertaste that is smooth.  Wonderful beer.

brown beer with a beige head who lets some traces when dissapearing
smells of malt yeast caramel and some fruit (dried plums)
tasts malty and fruity too
aftertaste is bittersweet and malty-fruity

Una dubbel decisamente ’carica’ con una splendida dolcezza e sentori balsamici al naso, un corpo un po’ troppo leggero (e frizzantezza inadeguatamente elevata) ma sapore pieno e avvolgente, con note di uvetta e cannella.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a large off-white head that faded to a film by mid-glass and left partial lace.  Pleasant aroma of yeast, brown sugar, and a bit of spice.  The flavor is caramel, yeast, brown sugar and some spice.  Mild bitterness at the finish and a bit dry towards the finish as well.  I had read the description on the bottle before opening this beer and was expecting rich malt with notes of port, raisins, and black chocolate, none of which I experienced.  Still, a solid beer.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Wow, superior to St. Bernardus Pater 6 even.  Beautiful bouquet, sweet dark fruits galore.  Another awesome, bubbly, tickling the tongue mouthfeel.  Only problem: finishes a little too dry.  Very nice.

Bottled to a trappist glass. Dark brown body with amber hints, highly frothed beige head, you can hear the carbonation like a soda. Aroma is vinous, fruity, apple, brown sugar, smokey, rye, slightly chocolate, prunes, and obviously yeast. Palate is noticeably soft and smooth. Flavor is vinous, pumpernickel bread, indeed slightly chocolate, raisins, yeast, and not very bitter. Nothing it overwhelming, its balanced, and its very smooth.
bottle, dark amber, frothy head, malty nose, flavor is light toffee, caramel and cocoa, finish is light dry ovaltine
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $3.49 Very good!

My first Belgian brown.  Quite tasty.  Big big head lots of retention.  Nose of Cinnamon and spice.  Flavors of dark roast compliment a medium palate.  Finish of warm alcohol and lingering cookie.  Great!

It poured dark brown with ruby highlights and tan fluffy head, settling quickly. Sort of a winey aroma with some burnt sugars and cherries. The flavor is slightly sweet and malty with a hint of roasted bitterness and the nice bready mouthfeel. I think its delicious and well balanced with subdued complexity. VERY drinkable. Cheers!

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 20 Sep 2008) Dark brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty nose with dried fruit, raisins, prunes, dark bread and brown sugar. Malty taste with notes of dark fruit, dark rye bread, raisins and a fairly dry, grainy finish. Not very bitter. Nice and well balanced dubbel.
A typical Belgian beer, good taste and aroma, but nothing special that makes you remember it.

Dark brown pour, large fluff of a white head.  Some malt and sweet aromas, brown sugar.  Taste doesn’t waver too far from the aromas.  Sweet malt, brown sugar, raisin.  A similar spiciness with a pumpkin ale.  A little sticky and clean finishing.  Not a fan of Abbey ales at all, but this one I don’t mind.  Is not overloaded with fruit and carbonation.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark dark brown almost black and a thin fervent tan head disappears instantly.  Yeasty spicy aromas.  Lots of visible carbonation.  Taste is very light bodied despite the color and not as good as I remember, fails to open up as it warms.
Qualities of both an abbey and a brown.  Blends to a surprisingly pleasant combination.  Underwhelming fining however.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2016 750ml bottle (Alko)
Dark brown, viscous. Sweet plummy aroma. Very soft palate. Rich malt base, gentle hops. Good, but lacking the special something that the other Corsendonks have had. Sweet spicy finish.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Porgu, Tallinn) (7:5:7:3:13=3.5)
Less viscous, if anything a little fizzy. Lovely winey fruits on pouring. Pleasant sweeting mellow roast malts, just what you want from a dubbel.
Rerate: 330ml bottle BB2016/02 Drunk 2016/11 (7:4:6:4:13=3.4)
Pleasant malty aroma, some plum and date. Thinnish palate. some grassy hoppy bite.
Rerate: 750ml bottle (7:4:7:4:15=3.7) BB 2011/04 Drunk 2016/11
Super mellow malty aroma. Ditto taste. Crazy mellow taste. Ooooh, nice.
bottle 750ml shared. Thanks to FatPhil&Anna. Color dark brown transparent beige head Scent: sour dried fruits Taste: roasted malts dried fruits, sweet spicy on sour ground. Long bit sticky aftertaste

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 750ml bottle. Dissipating cola appearance, without much of a head on our bottle (nothing like that picture, for instance!). Slightly metallic but lucious and fruity aroma. slightly less carbonation than i would have expected. deep if not very complex mouthfeel with a quick, dry finish. sweet and mildly sticky, doesnt rate to the Nostradamus. (3.6)

Re-rate (5/2010): Had a .5l draft pour of this in Budapest. (I cant believe they get away serving this by the half-liter). Much better than I remembered it, and i see my notes include why cant they all be this good?. Not the most refined dark belgian out there but its incredibly tasty. (4.0)

Pours a sad cola brown with a fizz. Not a head, a fizz. It was gone within 20 seconds, leaving a flat liquid. The carbonation is low enough in this brew that it leaves me wondering if it did in fact come from Belgium. The aroma has notes of a typical Belgian brown ale, but is slightly more metallic. It has a wonderful flavor - much like one of the greats (Nostradamus)... but there’s not enough of it. It’s weak at first, and it just dies - no aftertaste. This was disappointing.

Pours a deep dark mahogany with a large creamy beige head. Taste is rich with roasted malts and toffee flavors and a subtle coffee undertone. Tastey, very pleasent. Aroma is nutty, noticeable oak with a soft hint of smoke.

Bottle. A little bit of an dry red wine, moderate malty, later on light yeasty. A vey large creamy off-white head, which is long lasting; a dark red body. The taste is light bitter with a medium duration. A creamy and sparkling texture with a rather lively carbonation and a medium body. A very nice beer!
Very nice look to it. Normal brown ale aroma with a hint of chocolate. Taste is very comparable to New Castle with a little bit more body.
hazy brown with a fluffy off white head. Roasty aroma with notable hints of yeast.  Toffee, malts, and spice.

Murky brown.  Dry smell with an earthy quality to it.  The flavor has some of the earthy/smoky quality to it I associate with a farmhouse saison.  A little hint of chocolate or toffee in the finish.  Very dry, but still a nice body.

draft, dentatoveredeenke, cph.
aroma: sweet and dusty,
appeareance : cloudy golden, white nice head.
flavor yeasty, sweet. toffee, very nice.
overall good beer, flavor is wonderful, aroma and looks could be better.

35,5cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. It poured a red-brown colour with a big beige head that settled down fast in the glass. It has a fruity flavour that smells of raisins and yeast. The flavour is slightly bitter and tastes of raisins, malts and a hint of coffee. It has a short aftertaste.

Pours a nice amber/brown with a frothy tan head.  Aroma is sweetish with predominant yeast.  Flavors are a bit fruity, but not as sweet as expected.  Weakest point of this beer is that it is a bit thin, and somewhat overcarbonated.   Good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Bottled.  Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a very large foamy head.  Aroma is full of yeast and slightly malty.  Taste is malty and slightly sweet, like black cherries.  I was expecting much more sweetness.  The bottle recommends serving at 45-55 F but I didnt like the palate.  A little too much bite.  I enjoyed it much more as the beer warmed.

Bottle from monopoly outlet, CC Vest. pours Dark brown with nice offwhite head. Fantastic fruity aroma of canned pears and some yeast spicyness. Well balanced fruity taste with semi dry finish with some rhubarb. Fantastic
Bottle, great beer.  malt and fruit on the nose.  some tart fruit and malt on the nose.  Certainly a really good damn beer.
Tastes of sweet, dry malt and a touch of sourness as others have pointed out.  Good beer, very drinkable, but there’s nothing remarkable about it; a typical dubble.

Bottle. Pours a reddish brown colour with an off-white head. The aroma is malty with some notes of berries. The flavour is also malty with some malty notes and has a tartness to it. Thought that I would be more impressed by this beer...

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Poured a completely full glass of brown foam, which slowly condenses into a syrupy brown color. Aroma of light yeastiness and some sour wood notes, but hard to coax out. Flavor is slightly sour brown malts with hints of oak. Uncomplex and lacks the depth one would desire of a Belgian brew. Lackluster for a dubbel. Rerated 11/5/09: Wood-aged sour-tinged malitness seems better developed than I recall. Intriguing melanoiding and dusty malt complexity with deep, haunting, dark fruit notes.
Bottle. Dark brown colour, big head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, some dark fruits, roasted malts. Flavours are the same, very soft and subtle, well balanced. Good dubbel.

750 ml bottle. Poured a very pretty dark brown with a fluffy, slightly off-white head. Slightly fruity aroma, with caramel and just a whiff of banana.
Tastes of candi sugar, plums, raisins with a bit of chocolate. Slight taste of alcohol. Light on the palate. Another very good Belgian.

Splendid beer. Pours a lovely dark brown. Nice head. Very malty aroma, with a hint of raisins. Complicated taste; it kind of goes through a series of raisin-plum, coffee, bready, coffee, spicy. Excellent beer, especially if you like dubbels.
Poured a nice brown with a huge head.  Very pleasant aroma of malt and chocolate.    Nice palate - taste is complicated - lots of flavors at work including raisin, malt, chocolate, coffee.

Bottle.  Light brown pour with a great looking thick tan head.  Aroma of gingerbread, yeast and spices.  Excellent lacing with a taste of yeast, caramel, coffee and raisins.  Great finish.  What a brew!!

Dark brown-ruby body with a nice, delicious, stable foamy beige head. Aromas of raisins, plum, spices and roasted grains, some toffee. Smooth mouthfeel, complex body with a moderated personality what contains the dark fruits too like raisins and dried plum, solid coffee, dark chocolate. Nice , not a strong roasted aftertaste with the fruits. Beloved stuff:)
Got this as a combo pack with the Agnus and two glasses.  This was much better than the Agnus.  Dark brown color with a huge head.  Sweet fruit smell.  Good carbonation.
I found this more preferable than the Agnus, although they don’t really compare!  A nice dubbel.  A tad burnt in taste.  75cl bottle served into Corsendonk glass.  From Brussels South Airport.

Very nice dubbel indeed! Pours a very dark brown hue with a monster head that sticks around. Smells of over-ripened apples, dark fruits, dates. Solid on the palate, a little sweet as you would expect but not cloying. Very easy to drink. Just a very good dubbel that has its own unique subtleties. Gets better as it warms!
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, yet easy to drink, hazy, rocky head, good brew

A hazy brown colored beer, with a foamy beige head. The aroma of fruits, malts and herbs. The taste of dark malts and fruits, like raisins. A little spicey and la little bitterness. A realy good beer.

750 mL bottle bought by my girlfriend for my birthday.Pours a dark reddish brown with fluffy off-white head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is raisins, chocolate, dark fruit, cinnamon, candy sugar. Taste is great: dark, dried fruit, malt, chocolate, vanilla and wood. The candy sugar is apparent in the finish. A lovely dubbel, and a great birthday present.
Bottle, corked and caged. Ive been drinking the Donk for many years now, and all I can say is that. This is THE MVP of Dubbles!

35.5cl bottle from World of Beer (Largo, FL). Pours a dark brownish-red with a one-finger, lingering tan head. Reasonable head retention.
