Smells malty with notes of chocolate, sweet vanilla, prunes, and candy sugar. Light to medium-bodied, notes of roasted malt and wood are prevalent. Some hints of coffee and chocolate on finish. Generally earthy character throughout but a respectable dubbel-style ale.
Bottle.  Pours a amber brown body with a 3 finger white head.  Aroma is sweet malt, dark fruit, chocolate malt, and some booziness.  Flavor is crisp and sweet with dark fruit chewiness.  Solid beer.

Bottle served in Duvel glass.  Very dark but clear brown with bubbly head.  Malty sweet vinous and fruity aromas with some smoky and vintage port notes.  Really distracted by the palate, which just didnt do it for me.  Too much carbonation... big bubbles, on top of a rather thin palate.  Found this quite annoying.  Some cola and licorice flavors on the tongue.  I didnt get too much in the way of dark chocolate... a bit of vanilla, though.  I almost really enjoyed this beer but the palate distracted me quite a bit.

yet another belgain ale that is too fizzy for my palate.  pours ruby/brown with 2 finger off white head.  aroma is yeasty, carmel malt and raisin.  flavor is fruit-yeasty, slightly hoppy.  overall, an easy drinking beer that has enough character to keep me interested.

Brown with a lasting off-white head leaving lace. Bready malt and caramel in the initial aroma. Background notes of licorice, roast malt and dates. Rich malt flavour, but dry as it should be. The licorice and other notes are lingering in the aftertaste.

750ml bottle from BevMo Carmel Mountain.  Deep brown pour, sizable head. Yeasty, Belgian aroma. Oh yeah. I get the impression its going to be a bit dry. Not sure how to describe it. Body is quite carbonated, not overly by any means, though. Flavor is good, unique for sure. I dont really know how Id explain it, perhaps fruity and a hint of dark malt.  I simply love this beer.
750ml bottle dark brown in color with  beige head that dissipates quickly. Very carbonated full of flavor and malty fruit taste. Very nice on the palate a quality brew expected of this Belgium style.
33 cl bottle. Dark brown color, nice beige head. Aroma is dark fruit and malt. Flavor is the same, with sweetness and hints of belgian yeast and roasted malt. Carbonated. Nice, but not very complex.

Tasted at Dicomos wedding. Pours a nice clear dark brown with solid sustainable tan head. Nose of  raisins, and dark malt.  Tasted roasty, some chocolate, and dark fruit.  Very prickly carbonation.  Very good for style, but I just dont personally care for it all that much.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with white head. Aroma is "dark and brown" with clear malt tones. Flavor is roasty, caramel and spicy.
(0.33 l bottle) Deep dark brown. Big tan head. Malts in nose. Dryish palate. Raisin in taste. Slightly burnt taste. Liquorice.
Complex with subtle notes of yeast, fruits. Metalic and spicy soy notes dont help this. Too acidic and much too carbonated for me.

bottle; pours a dark brown with a one to two finger off white head. aroma is a lot of dark fruit, raison and slightly toasted malt. medium to full body a little chewy. plenty of sweet malt, dark fruits, more plum than raison and fades to a slight english hop flavor.

Draught at TDR EX:  Aroma of fruit, sweet malts, alcohol, and some hops.  Poured dark brown/ruby in color with a small, rocky, off-white head that diminished.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Ok lacing.  Sweet flavor.  Tastes of soy sauce, malts, and bubblegum.  Medium body.  Tingly texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Sweet finish.

Black as midnight, majestic crimson purple when held to the light--intimidating and full-bodied with a half-inch white head resting evenly... grape and raisin scents are strong... chocolate and coffee as well--complex and bold... effervescent, lively and smooth... moves quickly through the mouth, yet leaves easily... easy-drinking and dangerous... a confident yet well-mannered taste of light hops, soft smoke and fruitiness that plays on the tongue, with flirty sourness at its finish... I was pleased to pair my second glass with a cigar (quite versatile) and though the weather is on the chilly side, the backbone of this ale stiffens the will... impressive.

This is a beautiful looking beer.  Dark brown with an off white head.  Heavy carbonation with yeasty notes.  Could not taste chocolate. This is a beer you savor instead of session with.  Sweet aftertaste that lingers.
330 ml bottle. nice dark brown colour. creme head. very tastefull. I love these abbey dubbles.
excellent brew.  Superb palate and drinkability.  Smooth and darker flavor than actual hue.  I loved this ber.
Pours rather dark, but not fully dark. A medium rich beer with fruity flavor, some malt and chocolate. A bit short and fresh, but not too bad for a double.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before 02/06/07, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on May 9 2008; eye: ruby, clear, good effervescence, creamy tan head that remains, light lacing; nose: yeast, caramelized malt, light fruity; mouth: creamy, yeast, caramelized malt, light fruity, light alcohol presence, a bit of pepper, finale in yeast with a good support of malt, lightly sweet, slightly bitter, medium body, lightly oily, average carbonation; overall: nice surprise

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 02/06/07, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 9 mai 2008; il : rubis, claire, bonne effervescence, mousse crémeuse fauve qui se maintient, légère dentelle; nez : levure, malt caramélisé, léger fruité; bouche : crémeuse, levure, malt caramélisé, léger fruitée, légère présence dalcool, un ptit peu de poivre, finale en levure avec un très bon support de malt caramélisé, légèrement sucrée, très légèrement amère, corps moyen, légèrement huileuse, carbonatation moyenne; en résumé : belle surprise

Yeast and chocolate on the nose, with some dark fruits, smells like a typical dubbel with maybe a little more chocolate. Big brown color with a densely packed large head with moderate staying power. Chocolate and yeast up front with a really nice finish of hops, dark chocolate, smoke, caramel and cherry. The middle is thin but this is a very good dubbel indeed.

I usually dont like dubbels, But this was pretty good. Not too cloying or giving me the acid reflux. When cooler than room temp (in Panama) it has an amazing taste with the carmel toffee notes and a bunch of other things that only good Belgium beer provides. Available in Panama, and among the best beers ever sold in Panama. Available at Riba Smiths groceries.

Thick tan champagne head.Dark, brown colour. Aroma is a fresh malty fruit. First beer I had overflow the glass in ages. It jumps from the bottle desiring to be inbibed. Has a pleasant woody, roast for a true Belgium. Palate is average. My beer is young (not aged). This store just began selling this beer in this size. Its oilyness goes well with fish and chips..fried foods.
bottle. Clear amber-brown colour, malty nose. Full-bodied, very malty with hints of caramel and toffee, hoppy in a perfumy way and very fruity.
nice dark beer with a full head, flavor is very smokeywood like with a deep fruit taste . i will be getting more of this corsendonk soon

1 pint 9 oz bottle.  Dont know if I got a bad bottle, but very disappointed with this one.  Soapy aroma, and mouthfeel was watery.  Taste was bland, not a typical Belgian.  I expected chocolate and dark fruit flavors/aromas, and it didnt really taste like anything, just astringent and soapy.  If I decide to try again, Ill re-rate.
Lower marks because it is expensive. There are better beers for the money. It is good though. Definitely a hint of chocolate.

Pours clear dark brown with pleasant foam head.  Some malts and fruit aroma which carries into the pallet.  A taste of dark chocolate bitterness that mixes with the alcohol gives it a certain presence. A little bit of a yeasty dry finish.

Pours clear dark brownish with light tan head. Aromas of dark fruits, caramel, dough and  some bananas. Flavor is sweet and malty with a slightly metallic finish. Creamy mouthfeel with lots of carbonation. Medium body. Very nice dubbel.
Rather woody aroma.  Not like barrel aged oaky, but like beechwood chips. This carries through to the rather surprisingly dry flavor.  A hint of tartness on the midpalate.  Not bad.

Pours a clear dark rusty brown with a large light brown fluffy, moussey head that persists for a long time.  Nose of dark fruits, nuts and malts.  Smokey taste of dark fruits.  Noticeable flavor resemblances to a port wine or cognac.  Nice sweet smoky finish.
Nice brown look to it with a fluffy off color head. Nice fruity dark flavor with a hint of chocolate and smoke
Strong aroma of yeast with some sweetness mixed in (dark fruits).  Highly carbonated, lively on the palate.  Yeast flavors w/ dark fruit ending with a nice smoked flavor.

A nice dark brown with an inch of ivory head, the head remains throughout. 

Smells of earth and hops and toasted malts. 

The mouth is immediatley met by the taste of toasted malts and port and finally a hint of chocolate.

Rich and creamy in the mouth, a bit heavy on the carbonation. Great after taste.

Very drinkable. Wish Id bought more than one. Ill definately buy this one again.

Serving type: bottle

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Orangé foncé, avec un mince collet. Odeur tres épicer, épinette, jus dorange, dattes, mures et également des coté poivré et salé. Gout de sel, resemblancede trait médicamenteux., réglise noir, peches. Tres bonne biere!

Dark amber with reddish hues, thin light brown head... lots of sediments.  Aromas of cranberries, raisins, madera, dates, blackberries.... dark fruits!  Nice well balanced mouthfeel, nice alcohol presence with a medium body.  Added flavors of madeira, blackberries, prunes.... Very well rounded brew.  Definite surprise!
light fruity aroma, deep brown with medium beige head.  starts off fizzy and dry with a little sour, then changes to a general dark fruit/yeast combination.

12 ounce bottle-  poured a perfect caramel brown/gold with a huge blond head.  Aroma was very sour and yeasty, but the sourness did not carry through in the taste.  Champagne like carbonation was actually very pleasant.  Taste was all toasted yeast with some slight fruitiness, very mellow and enjoyable.  Good beer, I liked it.
Brown with a dense head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits and a bit of pepper. The flavours are toffee, dark fruits, caramel, dark chocolate and alcohol.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black, and with lacing tan head. Aroma is yeasty, caramel malt and a light fruity note. Flavour is dark malty, caramel and with a light spiced note. A solid fruity flavour takes over before the finish. Fruity and yeasty spiced finish. Light bitterness and a lingering fruity note. Reminds a lot about Wetvleteren 8/12, lovely.
Pours dark brown with a frothy brown head.  Aroma of grass, raisins, and wine.  Has a complexity of flavors with sweet fruit in front turning more vineous at the back.  Nice beer.
Pours a nice brown with a massive white head. Sweet caramel flavor. A little alcohol in the aftertaste but nicely blended in. Easy to drink. I would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Pours murky chestnut with a fine white fizz.     Wonderful sweet nutty aroma with notes of sweet tropical fruits.   Tastes like it smells; Dry, malty, melon, fruit, clove, raisin, caramel.  Sweet finish with a bit of caramel malt and yeast.   Finishes a little similar to nocturnum, but a step above.  Lively, but fuller body, excellent.

33cl bottle in Gent.  Clear dark borwn colour with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of candied fruits and spice, with a touch of alcohol in the back.  Flavour was correct for a dubbel.  Mostly gentle sweet fruit in the front and then settles into a warming spice.  Very well done.
Poured to a dark brown ale with a thick head. Aromas of raisins. Initial taste of malts and ended with a slighty fishy, port taste. Complex beer.

poured dark brown with a slightly tan head, that laced nicly into a trappist glass.  aroma was some dark fruits and spice.  flavor was spicy, with some raisins and chocolate on the back of the tongue.  mild and drinkable, with a palate of tiny bubbles.  good.

330 ml bottle. Almost clear deep mahogany body  with a huge but disappearing beige head. Great aroma of slightly roasted malt, dry fruit and caramel. Flavor is sweet malt, candy sugar, prunes and surprisingly little alcohol. Very easy to drink, great flavor and well balanced brew.
Ez is nagyon finom a világos testvérhez hasonlóan.Ez kicsit gyümölcsösebb,karamellásabb.Mikor milyen kedve van az embernek,azt a fajtáját issza ha tudja.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 (Belgium) Dark Brown color with Med-Tan Head. Has a Sweet Malty Aroma with a soft carmel taste. Finish was kind of dry but very good
UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 bottle.  pours semi dark brown.  didnt really like this beer...was overly yeasty...not my kind of beer but i gave it decent style points

Pours a hazy deep reddish brown color with a creamy tan head that lasts and some beautiful lacing.  Sweet aroma of yeast and fruit.  Complex flavors too.  Nuts, dark cherries, spices, raisins, chocolate, molasses, and caramel.  Seriously good beer.

Appearance: dark brown color with reddish notes. Head with medium size, dense, lasting and with good adherence to glass.
Aroma: toast grains smells and an intensive and pleasant fruitiness. Fruits reminiscences of dark-grapes, plums, figs and blackberries. Slightly citric-smell. Spicy aromas like clove and ginger. Yeast, dessert-wine and wood.
Flavor: slightly sweet start with caramel touches, from dark-malts. Intensive and varied fruits progress with plums, blackberries, cherries, dark-grapes, raisins and figs reminiscences. Spicy notes similar to ginger, clove and vanilla. Light but persistent smoky and woody touches. Truffles reminiscences. Liquory like dessert-wine and cherry-liquor. Complex taste.
Palate: medium body and semi-oily texture. Medium carbonated.
A complex, pleasant, with own-character, fruity, slightly spicy and balanced beer.

Pours a dark brown with a slight reddish hue.  Has a thick and foamy tan head with no real lacing.  A lot of visible carbonation.  A very strong sour-yeasty nose with sweet brown sugar, caramel, and maybe a touch of molasses malt goodness.  A full malt flavor with sourness at the beginning and a nutty caramel middle with a slightly dry finish.  Not a whole lot of body, but carbonation leaves a creamy finish.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet.
Murky brown, lots of floaties.
Nutty, rather sweet malty flavour. Full body, a little bitterness, quite nice.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown body with thin head. aroma is of caramel, yeast, brown sugar. Flavor is the same with a light body that is well carbonated and easy drinking. This one goes down fast.

Bottle, 75cl, corked. Beautiful dark brown pour, against light it becomes more red than brown. Very little head. A sweetish malty aroma with notes of coriander, yeast, fruits, dark chocolate. Full mouthfeel with lots of carbonation. -A sweet taste of roasted malt, apricot, ash, licorice and chocolate. Interestingly the metal packaging my bottle came in says that the beer has 8% alcohol, but the label on the bottle says 7,5% !

Nice med. brown color. A bit more carbonation than I expected but not a drawback at all. Hints of fruit & spice give it a good flavor. Just the right amount of hoppiness makes for a good finish. I like this beer alot more than I thought I would & it is moving up in the ranks.

Bottle. Pours a medium brown with nice tan head. Aroma is yeasty with malt and dark fruits. Flavor is moderately sweet and definitely full of raisin with winelike notes and a full load of maltiness. Finish is clean with a hint of sweetness and spice. Very active and light carbonation offsets a slightly oily body for a good mouthfeel. Very tasty.
Dark brown with a white head.  Sweet like raisins with a hint of spice and an almost chocolate flavor.  Belgian-y aroma.  Medium bodied yet filling to drink.  A tiny bit sticky in the mouth.

Beautiful mahogany color with a thick tan head that sticks around, nice lacing. Slightly sweet smell and yeasty. Medium body with an almost oily mouthfeel. Nice taste is mildly sweet with raisons and chocolate. A good dubbel. 53106
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: A dark brown pour with a large off-white head that endures throughout the drinking.  The aroma is a raisin and sugar sweetness.  Its very sweet in taste, but with a mild kick of spice to it and a little chocolate to go along.  It has a very dry finish.

Pours a deep red with a yeasty frothy off white head. Aroma is yeast, plums, raisin, and malty sugary sweetness. As it warms, the aroma gets a little smoky. Big mouth full of carbonation. Taste is malty, candi sugar sweet, slight hint of smoke. Finishes clean with a little malt sweetness. A very good beer and good to find in Florida again.

Pours a dark brown w/ a nice off-white head. Smells of yeast, and banana. Great spicy-sweet flavor w/ s hint of alcohol. Got a touch of brown sugar/molasses, dark fruit, and spice cake. A very drinkable beer...I would definitely recommend this one!
tan head with light brown appearance.  flavor is subtle with hints of crystal malt.  a solid beer not spectacular
good pour, head doesnt last too long.  dark brown color, taste of dried fruit.  excellent finish.  delicious.
Pours a deep amber to light brown with thick beige head.  Aroma was muted with only some banana noted.  Tastes sweet and spicy with some grape and port flavors.  Also cocoa.  Nice dry finish.
Dark brown pour, with quickly fading off white head. Sweeter than many of the other dubbels ive had, nice aroma of spice. Very good

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 Bottle 0,33l. Dark red brown with a creamy and fluffy tanned head. Strong aroma of spice. Carbonated mouthfeel. Flavor with hints of chocolate and spice. Well rounded. A lasting aftertaste with some sourish bitterness. KI=10
Deep claret colour. Slightly woody aroma that is also prominant in the flavour. Quite a rich flavour overall with elements of malt and dark fruits.
Bottle 33cl. Dark brown colour, nice composition of malt and hops, hides alcohol very well, great finish.
Deep brown, smells of sweet malt and sugar, raisins and a dark fruitiness in the middle then a nasty bite of alcohol (I think thats what it is) about 2/3rd of the way through ruins the finish.

I liked this well enough, but it wasnt as spectacular as I think its competitors. While I was surprised by the immense flavor of the very pale Abbey Pal, the brown left me wanting a little more oomph.
Bottle:  Poured dark brown with a thick light brown head.  Has a bit of an aftertaste but overall not that bad.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 Clear brown coloured beer with average white head. Malty fruity aroma, full creamy palate, ending is a little metallic and bitter.
Nice one.

The beer that got me into Belgians.  Bought it because it was $7 a bottle at a bar I was at and I had to try it.  I loved everything about this beer.  Raising come through as well as chocolate.  Goes great with a chocolate chip cookie.  Head retention great.
Hazy brown with large head. Sweet malty aroma with ripe fruits and yeast. Sweet flavor with caramel, rasted malt and plums.

(bottle): Pours a humongous head, off-white, creamy, good lacing, very lasting. Dark reddish body. Sugary flowery aroma. Sweet hoppy, some malts in the aroma. Sweet sugary taste. Some acidic. Warming up, softer, more floral, less dark fruit.
Rating #300. Brown colour, medium tan head. Aroma is fruity and chocolate. Flavour is of dark fruits, chocolate and malts. Very pleasant, very balanced.

bottle. Pours a lovely shade of semi-translucent brown with a large crackling tan head. Smells sweet and has notes of caramel and fruit. Feels very alive in your mouth. In the beginning it tastes of malt and caramel with a sharp note of alcohol. Mellows out a bit as it warms and the taste of nuts, fruit, and hops emerge. Very well made and worth sampling just to see and hear the head form in the glass.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a big head.  The taste is raisins, malt, brown sugar and just a touch of dried fruit.  Lots of carbonation.  Great stuff.

Pours a dark chestnut brown with big foamy beige head.  Aroma of chocolate malt, alcohol, hazelnut, sugar and raisin.  Carbonated, roasted malt flavor with chocolate, hazelnut and coffee with a dry hoppy finish.

Bottle.  Dark brown almost black in color with a fluffy light tan head.  Little to no fizz medium body.  Sweet malt aroma.  Lively & poppy beginning, medium middle with balanced flavor or malt, hops and yeast.  End quickly with little to no aftertaste.  End dry and crisp with a very light alcohol flavor, not bitter.  Nice and balances with medium carbonination.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 33cl bottle: pours a very dark brown with a nice off white head. aroma is smells like it has something smoked in it with spices added, not bad. flavor of spices but the smoked flavor comes through too strong and i dont know if i like that. not bad but this beer could use some work in my mind.
as a newbie exploring the belgians, this to me was a lot less of the fruit, and more of a taste that didnt overdo it... definitely would drink a few more.

330 ml bottle. Dark ruby red brown colour. Big flake floates. Medium-sized fine-laced creamy off-white head. Definitive Belgian yeast character. Powdery chocolate aromas. Gentle roasted notes. High carbonation level. Crisp malts and sharp carbonation. Yeasty. but still very approachable. Quite nice, and inoffensive even though there are a couple of defects.
Bottle/tap? Almost black body. Nice pale brown head. Sweetish aroma, ok. Moderate sweet flavour. Pleasant. (I de gamle gode tider, Brüssel, 15.12.07)

Pours a clear dimmed ruby with brown edges and has a off-white creamy foamy head, effervescent, creamy lacing adhered to the sides of the glass, 
aromas of dark malt and dark bread, raisin with dark fruit, brown sugar sweetness and some yeast, 
a sip brought flavors of dark malt and dark bread, fruit and some brown sugar molasses sweetness, malt sweetness diminished quickly to leave a loosely sticky
bread-fruit flavor on the palate, leaves some pepper on the tongue, some faint alcohol tingle in the nostrils , there were a few really faint smoke flavors 
detected here and there when the ale was left to warm to room temperature, this has a good dry finish, 
I found this to be a dry Dubbel ale and not as sweet as some other Dubbels, has a light to medium mouth feel, sort of bubbly and creamy in the mouth, a nice drink.
Think I drank this to cold but a very good beer, similar to Corsendonks triple, but even more balanced and a hint of dark malts.

Not a big fan of Belgians so my score may be a bit low but I like to try everything I can get my hands on.  

Much darker than I was actually expecting, almost a reddish tint to it.  

Nice foamy head, smells of fruit and yeast.  I can smell the raisin influence as well. 

Tastes pretty similar to most other Belgians, but has an underlyig darkness to it that is actually quite nice. 

One of the better Belgians Ive had but I still aint a fan.

Pours a dark brown with some dark red coming through when held up to a light. Had a rich, creamy, tan head with a solid lacing. The aroma is of yeast, strawberries, and other fruit. The taste was quite pleasant, I found many various things inside. Started off with some nuts and fig, finished dry with some vanilla and spice. Mouthfeel was medium bodied with a strong carbonation, was also nice and creamy mouthfeel. This beer hides alcohol like it isnt even there, serve cool and notice differences as it warms.

Pours a mahogany brown sugar colour with a creamy head that dies to nothing. You get a mild sweetnes in the nose along with dark fruit and fig and sense of sourness from the Belgian yeast. Very balanced in that you get the sour yeast, you get the sweet malt and you get the fruit but its all subtle and blends nicely. Medium in the mouth and very drinkable

Bottle, poured dark brown with cherry red highlights. Nice creamy tan foamy head that disapated fairly quickly. Everything about this beer was mild. The aroma was nice but not outstanding. Nice carbonation. Had a creamy texture. Light chocolate flavor appeared and a hint of a peppery spice. All in all it was a nice beer, but nothing really jumped out flavorwise to make this something really special.
A dubbel with a deep amber color. Moderately full bodied. Medium hops. Lots of malt. Tastes of raisins, port, flavorful with a big warming character. Pours with a huge head.

Botlle 33 cl. Pours a clear amberish brown with a medium tan head. Aroma isnt your average abbey dubbel, but more like a porter. Smokey, nutty, caramel and some slight sweetness. Taste is different than most other dubbels too, less sweet, caramelly and warm alcoholic and more smoke, roasted malts, coffee and dark chocolate. Nice long bittery finish makes this a very good and original dubbel

This beer pours a very touchy head that will foam up really fast if youre not careful. It has a very light scent that is sweet. You can really smell the alcohol in this beer. This beer is loaded with different flavors. The flavors hit my mouth from all different directions. A range of flavors from Plum to chocolate to a hint of apple. After 30 minutes it made my body temperature rise and I felt very warm. It feels nice and fizzy on my tongue. The fizzyness makes the beers flavors release very fast and you have to be ready. I really enjoyed this beer.

330 ml bottle. Big airy tan head. Clear chestnut colored body. Inviting fruity aroma of oranges and tangerines, tropical and sweet apples. Also some nice whiffs of spices, yeast and wheat. Medium sweet  taste; malty and caramellish with an evident choclolate flavor. Mildly hopped. Yeast, dark fruits, candysugar and alcohol in the background. Smooth, vinous and mouthfilling. Yum.
Pours into a tan, large fluffy head.  Settles into a coffee/stout color.  Hints of fruit and slight carmel.  Medium to heavy body.  Good brew.

shared @ party, big head forms off white im getting some earth tones and yeast in the nose, the taste is that of yeast, and dried fruits, figs perhaps? definitely no chocolate easy drinking. not a bad dubbel.
thin head no lacing...brown amber...nice earthy aroma with figs/raisons....sweet light fruit flavor...very dry finish...bubbly/fizzy mouthfeel...overall fantastic

Aroma: Sweet and sugary. Floral earthyness. molasses.
Appearance: Dark burgundy. Full thick white head. Not much lacing.
Flavor: Sweet and sugary maltiness. Plenty of hoppy goodness. well balanced.
Palate: Well filled body. A little warming, due to the alcohol content. Somewhat chalky

Smells lightly of yeast and some sort of fruitiness? It is foamy on your tongue, with a crisp, lingering aftertaste. Tastes mildly of chocolate raisins (or raisons detre). On the whole, a high quality brew. Possible downsides: a bit (too?) effervescent, possibly not the most desirable taste to some.

0.33 l bottle which poured dark brown-reddish body with big brown head. Aroma of some slightly sourish fruits, but of course also malty, mostly in the sense of caramel. Flavor is even better, bit sweet with caramel and chocolate enriched fruitiness. Finish is quite short, but as nice as the whole beer, more or less reflecting the flavor. Great beer indeed.
Aroma de cravo e malte. Doce (caramelo), um pouco metalizada no paladar. Falta caráter, mas uma boa cerveja.

12 oz. Bottle best before February 15, 2009. The pour is a dark red/brown with a very nice white head.  The amount of generic beer in the aroma is surprising, its not necessarily bad, I just dont expect the typical grainy nose in Belgian brews. As the beer warms, everything gets better. A whiff now reveals more chocolate, raisins, and soft spices. I thought the palate was a bit thin, but again improves once it raises up to cellar temp. Delicate chocolate, bready and spiced notes make up the flavor with a surprising suggestion of lemons. I dont usually get any strong citrus out of a dubbel, but I found it quite prevalent here. The sweetness is appropriate, sadly reminds me of soda, but never becomes sticky or cloying.  This is a predominantly malty brew but isnt notably hearty. Its a fairly delicate beer and enjoyable.

A big bottle gotten as a gift. Very foamy - attractively fruity aroma leads to a cola-sweet flavour that is somewhat two-dimensional but very competent. Nice lingering aroma of yeast and spice. Pretty decent but forgettable.

aggressive carbonation yet muted aroma of mostly cola. head fell quick and was maintained by all them bubbles. strong cola up front before the prune and fig.....oh no im drinking dr pepper! creamy finish and lingering notes of cherries.

Garrafa, em Utrecht (HOL), em novembro de 2007. O rótulo é pintado! Coloração avermelhada, com excelente creme bege, consistente e persistente. Fermento. Algo doce. Cravo e frutas vermelhas. Malte caramelo e lúpulo discretos. Muito bem balanceada. Suave. Presença de metálico. Levemente amarga e seca.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark brown color not unlike a root beer. Fruity aromas that im not expert enough places. Tastes like it smells. Not a bad thing, i just wish i could place it. The closest i can come too is Chamborg liquer but not nearly as sweet. Its creamy on the palate but finishes dry. A very wierd, but good brew.

I agree with the commercial description that this beer has a really interesting mix of fruity and smoky in the aroma.  The color is gorgeous, and the lacey white head lingered in the glass until the last gulp.  Incredibly refreshing and washed away smooth.  My only criticism is that the flavor was a little bit light, which was very surprising considering the high alcohol content.  In truth, as the beer warmed up this flavor improved, but so much as to make me really take notice.  I bet this is great off the tap.  Cheers.

75cl bottle - pours dark brown/copper with a big, fluffy off-white head. Aroma is extremely fruity, lots of apple and yeast and brown sugar. Smelled to me like a dark cider. Flavour was similarly cider-like, which doesnt seem to match up with a lot of the other reviews here, so I wonder about the condition of the bottle I had. There was a strong yeasty/biscuity character underneath this, but the sour sweetness of the cider sort of put me off this one. Very juicy. Weird.

750 ml split with Naka.  Brown with amber tones, nice thick off white head.  Nose os nice and malty, good lacing.  Hint of honey.  Taste is malty with touch of brown sugar, crisp hopness, but very subtle at the beginning and diminishing to a nice complex bread/biscuit aftertaste.  Touch of tart in there.  This is highly drinkable.  Seems to be a good breakfast beer.

It comes out of the bottle a rich transparent reddish-brown with a fairly thick tan head. Aroma is nice and malty, not too strong. Flavor is strong and mouth-filling, malty, smoky, a little peaty with just a touch of sweetness, like molasses. Very smooth but with a little bit of a bite.

thanks to ian for this one!  Caramelly malty aroma with a strong sign of anise in the aroma.  Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Smooth malts, caramel, feint roasty flavors, with some anise, im really enjoying the anise aromas and flavors.   Very good.
Bottle at home ... Deep red/brown ...yeasty and little raisin nose... fruity malty, some yeast and dark fruit quite sweet  little chocolate... bit overy fizzy but good mouth feel

Draught @ DTE, Copenhagen. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Sweet malty spicy aroma with some yeasty hints. Spicy malty flavor with some hints of yeast and dark fruit. Sweet malty finish with hints of dark fruit in the aftertaste.

330ml bottle served chilled in a tulip glass at Le Mirage, Tromsø. Clear, mahogany body topped by a creamy, off-white head with good retention and glass-lacing - very nice to look at! Mild cocoa to the nose with notes of roastiness. Taste of dark fruits and, when it warms, there is also moderate sweetness of caramel-covered malts added some spicy (cinnamon) notes in the aftertaste. Smooth palate (02.11.2007).
darkbrown coloured body with a average off white head a nice fruity aroma a malty fruity taste and a a average malty bitter finich

Had at Logans Oceanside beer tasting with AlohaC, and Hair, and Matt, and Ken, and Bill, and others.  Huge 2 liter bottle.  Labeled as "Monks Brown Ale."  Amber liquid.  Small head.  Very malty.  No date on bottle.  Very nice.  Medium body.

Rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting. Pours brown red with a beige head.  Floral, perfumy nose with fruits, caramels, and toffee.  Flavors constitute toffee, florals, caramels, perfumy, and lightly chemically.  Light body and carbonation.

Rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting.  Dark brown color with small, almost none existent off-white head.  Perfumy and spicey aroma.  Spice flavor with medium malt sweetness.  Thin and no carbonation to speak of.  Solid, not bad, but not exciting, too thin. , easy drinking.

Bottle at McClearys Public House, Marietta, PA...another whim from the lengthly beer menu...pours dark brown with an off-white head...smell of malt, caramel, light candy...flavor was subtle but very good of malt, toffee, very light chocolate-coffee...good beer, I enjoyed this one.

12 oz. bottle.  Overall, very good Belgian Dubbel.  Pours a deep brown with a good size head which quickly disappears.  Very active on the palate.  Notes of raisin, malts and spice.  Very carbonated and full of life.  Would definitely buy again.
Nice brown color with a thick tan head.  A lot of malty bread and nuttiness in aroma.  Flavors match and this is a wonderfull ale.  A little fruitiness too.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2015 33cl bottle at De Raedt, Eeklo (Belgium). A wonderful dubbel with brown, for its lovely pitch brown or black colour and beige foam and with an exceptional aroma. Think of dark fruits, sugar, caramel, and malts. Hints of sourness add to the experience.
Very strong its dark but not too dark.  Got it in a mug but I feel like I would be much cooler if it were in a Goblet!!

750 ml bottle.  Poured a scarlet-brown with a large and thick light brown head.  Aroma is yeasty and red fruits (cranberry, raspberry, and cherry) with a little banana.  Wonderful taste.  Roasted malt and tart fruit.  The yeast is subtle.  The finish is smooth and warming.  This is a wonderful beer for a rainy Sunday afternoon.  Ill be buying more of these.

On tap, from old notes.  Deep brown in color with hints of red and creamy off white foam.  Aroma of ripe fruit and malt, flavor is full of ripened fruits with hints of yeast and dark malts.  One of my first Belgians ever, still a solid choice.

750 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a dark brown color that allows just a hint of amber light around the edges.  Head is off-white and quickly fades to about 1/4 inch and holds, some lacing observed. The Aroma is rich with raisins, chocolate, toffee, and Belgian spices. The flavor mirrors the mirrors the aroma with emphasis on the spices (Cardamon, cloves, and allspice). The mouthfeel was  medium, smooth an satisfying; the carbonation was lively and appropriate. The finish was long with dried fruits. Overall: This is an excellent Belgian. Recommended.

rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting. pours dark ruby w/ off white head. nose is very perfumy, florals. flavor is red apples, perfumy, toffee, cloves, mouth feel smooth, carbonation is medium.

Bottle @ MicroBar, London. Pours brown with solid beige head. Aroma is spices / caramel / dark fruits. Taste is malty / some caramel / chocolat / raisins. Carbonation is perfect. This is a great beer, highly recommended!

This has been a favourite of mine for some years. I was recently able to acquire 2 FULL cases for a very, very reasonable price, which I am not going to mention here. I am going to attempt to age atleast half of a case for the recommended 5 years. I would love to see how it matures. As always, pours a great deep brown with some slight reddish hues. The aroma is beautiful and full of fruit and heavy malts. The flavour is another exceptional trait. A very nice sour fruit finish, with a somewhat nutty roasted start. This is, again, a great brew, but by no means is it anything "special". A classic yes, but not ground breaking. Classic is sometimes better.
Not bad for a "Dubbel", but I wouldnt specify it as one myself.  Yet another Belgian thats good, but nothing special or unique.
Ah. One of my first Belgians way back when. A nice one that I kind of miss. Rich. Fruity. Havent had this in quite some time.
Pours deep brown with nice notes of  dried fruits and heavy malts.  The palate is medium bodies with a very long malt finish that has some tang and notes of spices.

12 oz. bottle. Aroma of dark fruits, dark malt, and something floral. Nearly opaque brown color with a beige head that didnt last long. Medium bodied with creamy carbonation. Starts with lightly roasted malt, some chocolate, tangy fruit, and perhaps a hint of bitter. The finish is pretty dry, with a little smoke, some bitter, and something like chocolate bread or perhaps yeast? It is not extremely complex, but it has a nice variation from start to finish.

Nov 2005 - This was a beautiful beer...dark brown with 2 fingered head that just wouldnt go away. The foamy bubbles on top, combined with the just right amount of carbonation made each sip a treat in the mouth. The flavor wasnt as complex to me as to most, with some dried fruits and malty flavor with even a little hop twang at the end. Not as rich, sweet and spicey as I would have liked, but still a darned good beer.

Nice mild caramel malts, fruity and mildly yeasty. Lively carbonation which settled over time. Got better after being in the glass for half hour or so. Brought home as a "gift" by Andrea - not really my style but after visiting the Hop Leaf in Chicago I think Ill start exploring Belgian beers. Nice treat!
Tasted this very nice beer already from draft as well on bottle. Niow i had a bottle out of 1999. Still very nice and tastefull. Full bodied
bottle. amber, mahogany. aroma of fruit, brown sugar, caramel. Big taste of butterscotch, fig, fruit, malts, spice.  Long finish, wonderful mouthfeel. Excellent brew.

750 bottle.  Pours a coffee brown in color with a huge head.  The aroma is of floral hops and fruits.  To start out, the flavor is of sweet summer fruit with a yeasty breadiness.  As it warms a bit, the malts become more evident with a light caramel note.  It finishes sweet and a bit strong with a chocolatey espresso note.  One of my top favorite beers.

Aroma is light with a caramel malt tone and faint yeast scent.  Color is a deep amber with good carbonation and a thick tight head.  Taste is mellow, smooth and light.  Starting with a light/medium body it goes down with a very smooth feel.  Finish comes in with mild sweet malt flavor, very faint yeast tones and a mild bitterness that leaves a metallic after taste.  Im a bit disappointed its not as good as there Tripel (Abbey Pale Ale) and really isnt close to other Belgian Ales.
Pour: a very deep amber brown. Head: creamy, thick, foamy, light belgian aroma. Flavor: spice, earthy, Belgian yeast. Palate: lively. Finish: warm, yeasty.

0.75 l bottle. Mahagony color with creamy head. Sweetish aroma with notes of raisins, chocolade, licorice and alcohol. Dryer taste with cork, wood, licorice, clove and some vinous notes. Too much cork in the flavor.
Nice cola color and huge head making it difficult to pour.  Rich malt flavors in a light body.  The esters one hopes to find in a Belgian are present, withut overpowering the malt.

Tasted right after Westmalle Dubbel for comparison. The Corsendonk came up a little shy but still established itself as quality. Poured a dark brown with a reddish hue. This is the first place it takes a step down from Westmalle. The latter is much denser and murkier, denser consistency. The head is thick creamy beige. The aroma is sweet, shows some alcohol, a little dry, vinous, dark fruits, Belgian aroma. The flavor is upfront Belgian musty, sweet, dark fruits, dry. Not a ton of complexity and stuff.

Poured dark brown/black. head was rather large and creamy. smell was sweet, fruit and sugar. flavor is what the bottle described, raisins dominant with some chocolate at the end and sone fig. palate is soft and kinda thin for what i expected. not what im used to for the style ( body wise and low in complexity) but still plenty of flavor and easy drinking.

Pours a dark, dark brown with garnet highlights; head is mderately full, rocky but creamy, and beige being mostly lasting and leaving some nice lacing.  Nose is interesting to say the least; a little port-ish and a grape note that is unique, Belgian chocolate, yeast, and hints at fig, molasses, and smoke.  Nose is a bit faint and hard to describe but certainly intriguing.  Flavor is a bit uninteresting as compared to the nose; raisin, darker chocolate, yeast, and some fig with mild spices in there too.  Palate is soft to lively, nearly medium, and silky but a little watery.  Finishes mostly sweet with a bit of dryness, chocolate and raisin notes lingering.  A fairly well done dubbel but really lacked the complexities of greater examples and the flavor was nothing compared to the nose.  Certainly not a typical example of the style but nice in its own regards.
Heel erg smakelijke Pater. Geurt heerlijk als wijn en drinkt perfect. Is ook niet erg bitter op het eind.
Bottle at Cardinal, stavanger. Red / orange colour with a beige head. Aroma is yeast, cellar notes. Flavour is yeast, cellar notes, sweet, apple, candis sugar. Pleasent nice beer.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, with a nice average head.  Aroma is malt, caramels, little roastiness.  The flavor was amazing.  The beverage was smooth, with a nice malt, caramel, and some chocolate taste to it.  It finishes surprisingly easy.

Pours a cloudy brown with a lasting tan head. Sweet malty aromas, spicy belgian yeast and a hint of alcohol. Heavy dose of malt in the flavour, some yeast, chocolate. The palate is a bit thinner than I expected but otherwise a good beer.

Name: Corsendunk Abbey Brown Ale
Date: 05/08/1998

iii+ to ii
hazy brown, good tan head, winey aroma, light malt flavor, hint of chocolate, slight wine like esters, slight sweet finish

hazy rusty brown, big creamy tan head, rich fruity spicy malt aroma, rich malt flavor with lots of ripe fruit flavor, essence of chocolate covered raisons,

Dark ruby, big beige head that quickly subsides, slightly tart rich malt aroma and flavor, chocolate fiqs, tartness subsides into a fine mellow brew, if only summits could get this quality from their lines, a decent sized glass too

lots of tartness in the aroma and flavor, not right

dark brown with ruby highlights, frothy off white head, light bitter dark malt aroma, uninspired dry dark malt flavor with a touch of chocolate, finally picks up a hint of fruit but it is offset by some bitterness in the finish, looses all of its character on draft

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Pours a dark brown with a off white head. Hints of dark chocolate, malts, sour fruits, and spices. Finishes with a yeasty spice on the tongue.

Pours a beautiful, clear garnet with a huge tan head that laces down the glass; certainly one of the prettiest beers Ive drunk.  Scent is malt, grape, soufdough, and something unusual I cant recognize..is it yogurt-like, maybe?  Flavor is dominated by dark malts, with hints of chocolate and caramel, tart grapes, pear, nuttiness, and light spice.  Finish has a clean sweetness to it.  Nice, although the non-malt flavors could stand to be a little more intense.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Bottle. Opaque dark brown with big white head that dissipates fast. Aroma of spices, metal, and water. Very sweet. Nutmeg plus lingering date sugar that can become cloying. Quite thin. Does not shine. Good, but not spectacular beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a very deep ruby red with a thick foamy off-white head.  Aroma is light raisins, vinous, yeast, some spice.  Flavor is very smooth malt, raisin, chocolate, light spice, yeast, some chocolate.  Very easy to drink.
nice thick offwhat head. smells fruity/malty/slightly sweet. Perfect combo of malts and hops with a slightly slightly dry finish. Overall i really enjoyed !

This may be my favorite Abbey Dubbel.  Poured from a bottle at Shores Inn, SCS, MI. Pours hazy brown with short creamy  off-white head.  Great flavor, presiding from what I can tell mostly chocolate and malts.  Sits well on the palate, with the alcohol cloaked well by the other flavors.
Pours a dark hazy brown with a creamy beige head.  Great lacing.  Aroma of fruit, yeast, malts, and chocolate.  Taste is complex with a intricate blend of spices, malts, hops, fruit, and chocolate.

750 split two ways.  Brown in color, hazy, with some yeast floaties.  Aroma is spicy, with some acrid malts, chocolate.  Taste is somewhat tart and sour, with acrid malts, yeast, spices, and light notes of fruit.  Thin in body. Perhaps this bottle was past its prime or exposed to heat, as this was a dissapointment.
Excellent brew.  Dark brown pour with small off white head.  Ruby highlights when held to the light.  Nutty malt aroma and taste of spices (cloves) and dark malt.
Flaske. Flot flot mørkebrun farve. Dejligt skum og en fantastisk afbalanceret smag er med til at gøre denne øl til en nydelse (Afprøver mine reklame evner).

Bottle. More of a deep ruby red in color than brown with a fine offwhite head. A lot of yeast particles floating around. Aroma is of dark fruits such as rasins and plums balanced with some spices and oranges. Most unique in the taste is the high spice quality - a blend of cloves and ginger. Some dark fruit elemets again and malt. It really brings a good mix of things to the table without overdoing any one so it gets points for sophistication.

Draft in the Utopolis, Turnhout. Dark-red beer with a small creamy off white head. Medium carbonation. Spicy aroma.
The quickly disappearing flavors are a bit disappointing. Some sourness coming from the roasted malts. Some spicy notes in the background but all quickly disappearing. Luckely the Simpsons movey was better than this beer I had in their café.
Big bottle in a tin can. Complex aroma. Orange, a bit like Bush Noel actually! A good strong taste with a silky texture.

First of all, Im a huge fan of abbey ales. With that being said, this stuff is incredible. The appearance, well....peep the picture, its brilliant. The head lasts for ages. The aroma reveals that amazing Belgian yeast, orange citrus, plum and a bit of roasty, almost smoky malts. The flavor, differing mildly from the scent, gives way to a host of flavours not hinted at in the aroma. These include figs, clove, a variety of dark fruits, chocolate, candied sugar and also the yeaste. The palate is tingly, velvety smooth and medium-bodied, with lively carbonation and a smooth, long, not-so-dry finish. I will give this the numbers it deserves. Dont be jaded in similarities in Belgian brews. 

also, this is not a brown ale, so get your shit right when rating. Thankyou.
750 mL bottle.  Ruby brown with fluffy white head.  Dark fruit and yeast aroma.  Raisin, date, sweet spice taste with a semi-dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 pours a light golden brown with a two finger head and tons of small bubbles in the glass. a very active beer, head is light and fluffy, smells of mild chocolate, plum,  and sweetness. taste is in line for the style, chocolate, spices, malts, cherry. has a fairly good body and good carbination through the whole beer.
On tap. Mahogny with a rich creamy beige head. Sweet caramel nose with a complex spices and yeast. Sweet, lightly roasted caramel taste. Relatively fluffy and light-bodied. Enjoyable.

Bomber, shared with ArcaneApollo.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with a lacy white head.  Aroma is of spices and slight chocolate and candy sugar.  Taste is spicy with a bit of a chocolate aftertaste.  Very solid brown ale, though not the best Ive had.

The flavors seem almost standard with these Belgium ingredients. Caramel, nuttiness, rich malts and mild floral hops. 
Quite tasty
The aroma has prunes, candy, and yeast. The appearance is dark brown with a nice head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is a little thin. This is a nice beer.
The flavors here are light.. have they been subdued in the 3 years since Ive had this - or have i been drinking too many "imperials" lately? A slightly chewy beer with some nice flavor notes.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Chestnut brown color with a thick and lasting tan head. Aroma is roasty and sweet with some dark fruits, chocolate, and a little bit of sour. Flavor is dark and fruity with some chocolate. caramel, and roasted malts with a slight bitterness at the end of it.

Bottle at KØ07. Very nice appearance, very dark brown, mahogany colour. Very small light brown head. Weak, roasted aroma. The flavour has an estery fruitiness, moderate but noticable. OK malt flavour, but quite common. Weak, thin finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with ruby highlights and a large light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of fresh malt, caramel, dark fruit, and a hint of dark chocolate. Taste is the same as aroma with a well balanced bitterness. Medium mouthfeel that finishes dry. A well balanced and easy drinking Dubbel.

Malty, fruity and flavorful. Very nice dubbel. Appealing cloudy dark brown pour with big off-white head. Lots of malts in the aroma  caramel, raisin and plum. Notes of dark chocolate and a little licorice. Flavor is mostly sweet and lightly acidic. Very slight bitterness. Medium body, watery texture followed by some stickiness. Lively carbonation. Alcohol shows up at the end.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2008 Bomber: A medium body moderatetly spicy critter with a large head.  Deeper brown in color with sparse lacing.  Cardomom in the nose with a watery finish.  Mild bite at finish.  A decent magnum for the aches and pains of life.
Bottle.  pretty head.  raisin flavor, against a dark backdrop.  Thanks be to Erics mighty bar b que.
Bottle. Brown with a large head. Aroma of burnt toffee, yeast, raisins and spices. Cardamom spice, to be exact. Medium to heavy body.

Bottle. High fluffy but lasting white head. Hazy yellow body. Dry and dusty barley malt aroma. Sweet smooth well rounded fruity, apple pear, with a touch of coriander and maybe something else, I cannot quite figure this spice out. Low carbonation, long and plaansant aftertaste although it is pretty sweet. Alcohol percentage seems just right.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2009 Bottled 33cl. It pours a brown beer with a rather big beige head. Spicy aromas of oranges, cloves, caramel and pineapple.  Very pleasantly fruity, spicy and yeasty. Some caramel in the taste, lots of spices, some pineapple. Madeira-like elements detectable, hints of dark chocolate. Excellent notes of pine needles. A well balanced dubbel with a very pleasant mouthfeel. Quite high carbonation. The finish is buttery and rather bitter. A very tasty dubbel - I liked the design of the label too. Rerate: Not as good as I remembered. But Im still sticking to the initial rating allthough bogus ;-) Very nice for style thogh. Far from being excellent.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 cask @ houten clara, antwerp. Great beer and great restaurant (highly recommended). Fruits, malts and nuts dominate the aroma and taste. Finish of dusty chocolate. Nice full body. A regular in my rota.
Spritzy, brown with a slight aroma of cheese or fermented fruit.  Its very light in the mouth.  Sweet and malty flavor.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a average beige head. Aroma and flavour of chocolate, fruit, spice, malt and caramel.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 Pours deep brown with tan highlights and a spritzy cap. Notes are subdued initially do to cold serving temp, but some chocolate and raisan came through as it warmed.  The body is much more chocolate, with some tart cherries and smokiness taboot.  The yeast seems pretty insignificant here, but thats ok because the malt profile is great.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 One of those perfect beers for me. Its my favorite of the Trappist Monk beers. Its a bit on the expensive side, so its hard to stock up on it. But every once in a while its a treat to have it.

Bottle at the Hopdevil in Zagreb After the lovely tripel, I expected a lot from this. It poured a dark red-black colour with a medium to big thick off-white head. The nose is faint. Too faint, which is even more disappointing because its actually quite nice, malty, fruity, somewhat vinuous. Shame you really have to concentrate to catch it. The taste retains some of the characteristics of the nose. Like the fact that its too faint for its own good. Caramel, malt, some metal, regurgitated coffee with cocoa sprinkled in, weak hopiness and weak alcohol. Not bad, but failed to impress me. Needs a lot more body. Im not a particularly big fan of the style but this did nothing to gain it more respect from me. Sure, the subtle flavours are sometimes nice, but if some sublety is all it has...

Appearance: Dark brown body with a very creamy-looking off-white head.

Smell: Enticing malty aroma of chocolate, red grapes, spices, and a slight yeastiness.

Taste: Plenty of malt sweetness with rich, full flavors of chocolate fudge and toffee. Light floral bitterness. Smokiness and the fruity taste of port wine lurking in the background.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Immensely smooth with a very soft carbonation.

Drinkability: Look, this beer had me jumping up and down and juggling bananas. Would a BAD BEER be able to do that?
Ive had this beer numerous times, but never rated it.  Pours dark brown with strong head and medium carbonation.  Great flavor, somewhat roasty and spicy.  One of my favorites!

Pours mahogany amber with a huge foamy tan head. Lightly fruity aroma, with notes of light spicy yeast. Mostly roasted malt flavors, with very little sweetness, only a hint of a fruity undertone, a slight smoked note, and just a hint of bitterness in the finish. Palate is medium, silky, dry, and lightly bitter. Great mouth-feel, and very easy drinking, but the flavor is a bit muted.

750 ml bottle shared with rebelbeerguy. Poured an awesome looking crisp clear brown with a phenominal head. Aroma was very nice with yeast, dark fuit and sugar. Flavor was a little flat and dry compared to the aroma but still nice. Good starter Belgian.

Tap. Small, tan, creamy head (good lacing).  Brown body.  Aromas of light spices which include some perfumyness.  Also bubble gum and roasted malts were present.  Overall I enjoyed this brew, though I usually prefer slightly stonger (in all respects).

Rated 4/21/06:  This is my first dubbel so I dont have anything to compare this too so I will rate it solely on the beer itself. Poured slowly into my glass this beer is an intensly rich brown color that produces a pillowy head. Crazy amounts of lacing stick to the glass and the foamy head never goes away. After this beer warmed up a thick aroma became present. Very earthy tones are present, the aroma is malty and slightly sweet and nutty. The longer I let this one sit the more intense the aroma becomes it is similar to the previous Belgium styles I have had and really wonderful. Robust flavor that is exceptionally crafted. Very malty indeed with some subtle roasted qualities. The flavor doesnt sway much from the nice aroma although it does seem to be a tad more mellow. The tinge of sweetness in the aroma is also present. Overall I was surprised how much I liked this dubbel, It only got better until it was gone.
Bottle from BevMo, La Mesa. Deep ruby color upon pouring. Slightly sweet aroma with some sour fruit. Somewhat dusty smelling. Very dry. Some sweet chocolate along with some dusty dark fruit.

Bottle. Tasty and easy to drink.  Coke colored pour, highly carbonated.  The head was small on this bottle and settled farly quickly which I believe for this brew is uncharacteristic.  Very naturally sweet with what I thought to be a touch of smoke.  Clean finish.  Good, but not a repeat for me.
Thisone was too old and "cellered" in wrong conditions. Soory Corsendonk, because I know youre a very, very good beer, so I have to rerate you on sunday in Valby!!
mmm...warm beer. one of the best dubbels. not too sweet. malty, yeasty and very well balanced. just wish it wasnt so expensive

Bottle Dark amber pour with big microbubble head and good lacing. Aroma of fruit and dark malts. Flavor follows aroma with a bit of nut and caramel. Alcohol is pretty big and not too well hidden. Smooth, good brew.

Aroma of cracked pepper, spices, yeast.  Medium mouthfeel, flavors of prunes, dates, bread with a delightful, dry chocolatey finish.  Not anywhere near as sweet as most dubbels, and I like that about this beer.

Bottle. poors a nice dark amber colour with a huge very bubbly foamy mostly lasting head leaving a very nice lacing. Aroma of dark malt, spices, some alcohol and fruits. The flavour is sweet and spiced, good toasted maltiness and caramel with some dark fruits.
Bottle: Aroma is sourly and fruity, nice notes of cacao and chocolate. Brown color, huge foamy head. Fruity-sourly taste with notes of berries, caramel and raisins. Some smokiness.
Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity. Taste is rasin, carnel, wheaty. Nice beer

Bottle.  Pours a medium brown with a very thin head.  Some rasins, caramel and wheat in the aroma.  Medium body.  Flavor also has the raisins, caramel and wheat, and some smokiness.  I preferred the Pale Ale, but this was still enjoyable.

Pour is a brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is wine like with notes of cherry and wheat.  Flavor is apple and raisons with some chocolate and spice.  It reminds me of a chocolate covered strawberry.  Sweet but and underllying tartness.  Very tasty and worth the price.

Bottle, best before 24/08/08. Surprisingly clear; dark brown with red highlights. Humongous and lasting light-brown foam. Aroma is spiced bubblegum and pepper. Taste is raisins soaked in dry sherry, with slight bubblegum; some brown sugar and alcohol aftertaste.  Palate is surprisingly flat, medium-light and dry. Good beer, but the alcohol takes a little too much of the spotlight for only 7.5%.

This beer was very rich I thought. Which is a good characteristic of the beer. The beer was kind of salty to me, but there was a sweet fruity flavor to balance it out. One of the greatest flavors to me is the combination of sweet and salty. The beer had the smell of dark fruits. I would say raisins would be the closest fruit to compare it to. The beer was dark brown and had a nice caramel smell and flavor to it. ABV is okay, I always wish it were a bit higher. Decent brew.

Dark red pour with a thin white head.  Deep caramel notes with grape and plum nose as well.  Highly carbonated but not overly so as to detract from the beer.  Personally finished tied for third out of the 9 dubbels sampled at a blind tasting.  For the group it finished second.

12 oz. bottle. Dark ruby brown pour producing a very durable large light brown head and excellent lace. Roasted character to the aroma is supplemented by some yeasty and earthy notes as well as some faint dark fruit. Palate is mildly astringent and dry with a medium body and carbonation. Sweet, burnt caramel flavor is held nicely in check by a spicy bitterness. This is not as fruity as some of the dubbles that Ive had. It leans toward a drier, more bitter finish,  which isnt all bad as far as Im concerned.

Sampled at a blind abbey dubbel tasting hosted by tennisjoel on 4-14-07, along with eight other beers. This was the fourth beer that we tasted. It finished in second place in my rankings, and it was second place in the group rankings. Originally poured from a 750 mL bottle. The overwhelming winner of the night was t Smisje Dubbel, with Corsendonk Pater finishing a strong if distant second.

Wheat-like, smoky aroma featuring sweet tobacco and fresh lemon juice scents. Almost reminiscent of a rauch-weizen, although the smoke smell is much weaker here than in an actual rauchbier. Very strong, very good aroma. Pours a remarkably dark amber with a red hue and a very small amount of beige head. Sharp wheat and smoke-like tastes. Tastes like it smells, but I think those elements work better in the aroma than in the flavor. Dry finish. Sour and bitter aftertaste. Medium body. Very lively on the tongue. High in carbonation. When I tried this beer, I figured that it would win the tasting handily. Little did I suspect the awesomeness that is t Smisje Dubbel remained on the horizon...
750ml, very nice presentation with cork.  Beautiful looking with a nice nutty smell.  However, a little dry and bitter.   Not very tasty, but a mildly enjoyable brew nonetheless.
750ml Bottle, dark brown , tan head. mild flavor , tastes somewhat dry almost like a wine. as belgians go an..... OK beer. better than a lager but for the price there way better alternatives
Somewhat weak in flavor. Tastes of apples almost to the point of being apple juice like. Low alcohol mouthfeel with a lasting warming finish. Pretty good but I expect more from a trappist beer.
Draft. good head, belgium yeast, and sent, alot of co2, fruity, and good. Dark in color.
Draft pours dark brown amber with nice amount of head.  Head stays until the end.  Nice smooth flavor, with a very pleasant finish.
Super-dark, almost opaque amber color, with small, lasting head. Flavor is a little on the thin side; something like a black lager with Belgian yeast flavors. Much lighter body than I expected.
Amber with an off-white head.  Lacks hops like it should with a nice mild and sweet malt flavor.  Good dubbel.
Deep orange, brown colored brew. Very nice aroma, a bit fruity and sweet. Flavor is nice, malty and a bit sweet. Well balanced brew, very enjoyable.
This one-ups the tripel, which was somewhat harsh.  This is sweet, yeasty, and mild.  Malt profile is well rounded and balanced.

Bottle - Pours deep brown with tan head.  Great looking beer.  Aromas of malted grain, fruit, raisins, chocolate.  Flavors of spice, fruit, malt with a well balanced hop bitterness.  Caramel, chocolate, and alcohol complete the taste.  Nice mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2007 great appearance upon pouring, slight lace hanging on top 5mm or so of a wide mouth goblet. thick body, flavor reminds me of oak wood, licorice, caramel and dark fruits. great palate, silky finish after the yeast dissipates, with slight alcohol finish. A great beer, but not epic.

Bottle that I sipped on after my anniversary dinner at Margot Cafe in Nashville. Pours a deep mahogany brown with a large beige head. Wonderful aroma of plums, cherry, oak, and dark malts. Mouthfeel is earthy and slightly sticky. Initial flavor is sweet, with notes of caramel, raisens, red wine, and candi sugar. Mid-palate is more yeasty, with some subtle peatiness. Finish has a mild spicy bitterness, with a touch of alcohol. Very nice beer, that hit the spot after dinner.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal pub, Stavanger. Named "Corsendonk Pater - Dubbel". ABV is 7.5%. Bottle conditioned. Deep brown colour, large beige head. Pleasant aroma of dark fruits, caramel, candy sugar, spices and oak, a hint of smoke. Pleasant flavour of oak and malts, some candy sugar and caramel but not too sweet, moderate hops. Nice.

Bottle at Bocktown-Pour was a deep brown with a off white ring for a head with no lacing. The aroma was of fruit, a little yeast and malt. The taste was a bitey carbonated mix of dark fruits, alcohol and spice. A little too carbonated for my tastes and not yeasty enough. Good nonetheless.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: SEP 24, 2007 12 oz bottle. Dark brown with lasting off-white head. Strong, pungent aroma -alcohol, raisin, yeast. Flavor - Sugar, spice and everything nice. Slight fruit notes. Roasted malt hints. Very good.
Bottle. Light brown color, big light brown head. Similar taste to the pale version but more complex and a bit dryer. Excellent aroma and rich taste. Very nice.

Dark mahogany with a huge, nice and lasting head. The first time I tasted this one, I didnt like it, it was to sharp in its acidity. But then I got a 75 cl. bottle as a present, and after some months, I opened it. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit, and a hint of grapefruit. The first one had way too much black currant in the flavour, but in this one its gone, and it only is present as a hint among other notes of fruit.

THOUGHTS: Had this one on new years eve. Just a little too much carbonation. I couldnt stop burping. Looked incredible though. Ive been wanting to try this for a while and got it as an unexpected Christmas gift. I was greatly pleased with this one. It just got better as it warmed, more dark fruit and a little less yeasty in flavor. Nice beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark red-brown with tons of carbonation and an average, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was light nutty and caramel malt and moderate yeast, along with dark fruit and cherry. The initial flavor was light to moderate sweetness and light bitterness, while the finish was lightly bitter and sour with an average duration. The body was medium and dry and oily with tons of carbonation and a lightly astringent finish.
A very nice Dubbel. Classic features are prevalent in the handcrafted beer. The taste is tremendous but a strong aftertaste held be back from giving it a higher rating."

Clear dark amber with a small off-white head. Burned toffee aroma, with some light roasted chestnut and earthy hops. Very fizzy carbonation, malt driven body. Flavours of toffee, yeast, chocolate toasted malt and dried fruit. Slightly warming sweet/spicy finish. Medium bitterness. Very nice.

Pours a very dark and cloudy brown - opaque with hints of burnt orange and amber visible where light shines through the glass. The head pours exceptionally thick and light beige. The foam dissipates relatively quickly, leaving a thin layer of many-sized bubbles leaving lots of lace on the glass. The aroma first hits you with yeast. Hints of soft fruit and citrus fruit and then some sweet malts follow the yeast. The flavor starts a bit sweet and dusty - some yeast, some toffee, and some fruit. The initial flavor also has some dark caramel,  toasted bread, and roasted malt flavors - which stay into the middle of the tongue. The middle of the tongue also presents some interesting fruit and malts. The finish is somewhat dry and bittersweet. The mouthfeel is quite light, bubbly, and creamy. Overall - a very straight-forward dubbel that is very pleasing.

Bottle, 33 cl.  It was long time since ill taste this yesterday. Dark brown color with beige head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity. Taste, hoppy bitter with some yeast and dark chocolate.A beer for beginners,  very drinkable.
Bottle. Purs a nice and dark with slightly brown two finger head. Good combo of fruits with overall dry finish. Good aftertaste that makes you want more. Expensive but a good beer!
Poured dark with an off white head. Aroma of raisins and other dark fruit.  Dark fruits apparent in the flavor along with some spices. Finish is dry. A good dubbel.
Bottle from Ledgers; Nose is bready, dark fruit and mixed spiciness; Heavily carbonated clear brown with a big beige head; flavor has hop bitterness, caramel, raisins. Decent dubbel!

<Proppen>
Fruity aroma with notes of melon. Fruity sweetness in the flavor welbalanced by the alchohol. LIke a bubling desert wine, justy not quite as sweet
Extremely pleased witht his recommendation from a local beer store in paris (which is a rare thing around these parts)

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 I had this on tap at the Sharp Edge Creekhouse in Pittsburgh, thanks to mtoast. This has got to be one of the best places to get a beer tasting experience. This corsendonk pours as a dark brown beer but is certainly not opaque.  It also has an orangey glow as I peer thru the brew.  The aroma is sweet with barely any yeast notes detectable.  None of that  beery yeasty smell that is so common with other beers. The head starts out thick but then fades to a thin coating., it does not turn into froth.  First taste is the personality of a leathery well worn gentleman.  You know, like the friend that you have become used to, a friend who has earned your respect. It has the perception of not too sweet rootbeer with hints of very weathered wet wood. It is not overly roasty but there is slight roastyness there. You would never know there is alcohol in this brew. Yes, roasty and musty, but not in a negative way, if that is even possible. I have never tasted anything like this before. I see lots of bubble rising in the brew but there is little carbonation in the tasting, just a mild roasty creamyness on the back of the tongue. The finish on this beer is nifty, I didnt even get a hint of bitterness on the back of the throat.  Very well behaved, but it does let you know you had some hops and malt, without being in your face. One of the most refined beers I have ever tasted.  Again, looking at the alky content, it is hard to believe there is any alcohol in there at all.  I guess this is what makes the better beers better. 	Grimbergen Double (Dubbel) abd Bells Hath no Fury cannot even hold a candle to this brew.  Now I know what a dubbbel should be like, there is no going back. Beautiful experience.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Poured a dark brown with a pretty big light brown head. Aroma was of yeast, light chocolate, dark fruitiness. Flavor was fruity chocolate and was very smooth. Pretty good dubbel that I could drink again,
Wonderful taste.  The head seemed to last for ages, and even had its own taste.  The finish even had a wonderful flavor.  Some spice, hops, caramel, etc.  Not a chimay, but still wonderful

12oz bottle-pours a thin light tan head and brownish red color.  Aroma is medium/dark malt secondary hops.  Taste is medium/dark malt-some sweet/caramel, secondary hops, spice (coriander?) mild carbonation.
Very full aroma.  Somewhat nutty right in the nose.  The taste didnt match the depth and complexity of the nose or the color.
Bottled. Pours reddish brown in colour with a rather large off white head. Malty and sweet with notes of spices, yeast, dark fruits and berries. A bit thin mouthfeel and a bit too high carbonated.

11.2 oz bottle, poured into my trusty Chimay glass. Clear deep brown with a thin beige head. Interesting nose - yeasty, mildly nutty, spicy with light citrus. Flavor is lightly smoky malt, spicy and yeasty, a hint of mildly boozy raisin. Very nice, one of the best dubbels Ive had. What took me so long? This beer is everywhere, and I always passed it up. Never again!

UPDATED: APR 22, 2007 Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a creamy, long lasting beige head. Aroma is very fruity with orange peels, and a little roasted malt character, and some yeasty and spicy notes. Medium bodied and very smooth. A bit to sweet for my taste.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a large tan head. Delicious spicy aroma with dark fruits. Nice fruity flavour, with a sweet caramel taste. Short, and a bit salty finish.

Corsendonk is one of the best beers I have had in a long time.  Chocolatey and full of other indescribable flavors, theres a lot going on in that glass.  And the head sticks around halfway through dinner, which is pretty cool.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 Surprisingly sour.  It does have fruit, malt, and yeast as well.  Aroma leads me to expect some type of brett infected beer.  Light brown and very cloudy.  The head is thick and lasts a long time.  I get some grape in the flavor as well as dandelion.  Dry, woody finish.   Should this be sour?  It seems Im not the only person to have a sour bottle.

Bottle: Poured a chocolate milk shake color brown. The head was a creamy tan which seemed to keep growing until the bar was covered with its goodness. The aroma was a fruity sweet and malt smell. The taste was sweet fruit and with hints of candi/caramel malt.

Pours dark brown / garnet with a fizzy tan head.  The aroma has dark fruits (black cherry, figs, plums), candi sugar, earthy yeast and is fairly malty.  Medium body with a fair amount of fizzy carbonation.  The taste starts with caramel malt, fruits from the aroma and some sourness with a yeasty twang.  The finish has more earthiness, spice and carbonation spritz.  Further down the bottle it gets richer and fuller.  A good solid dubbel.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2007 I love the bottle conditioned ales, this one is no exception. Pours with a nice champagne like foam. Has a nice carbonation, altho doesnt quite explode in your mouth. Carbonation wears off quite a lot in an hour or so. This does feel a little thin compared to some trippels and quadruppels and is quite an easy drink. On the dry side, dried fruits. I would have this one again.
chocolate, caramel, raisin, smoke, brown, tan foam, lightly bitter, medium sweetness, full body, average carbonation, long finish,

Pours a dark brown with a bubbly head, aroma of caramel and dried fruit, perhaps some raisin type flavor in the taste, bottle also mentions smoky taste which I can agree with to a small degree.  Its a pretty nice beer and Id have it again if some of my other favorite Belgians werent available.
dark brown, nose of juniper, dreied fruit and maybe cherry, lovely malt flavour, again dried fruit on the flavour, some candy sweet flavour. great beer

Pours a hazy, murky brown with a one finger head that rapidly fades to a spotty cap and ring, and leaves behind an adequate lacing.

Smell; lots of rich caramel malts and dark fruits (plums, raisins and some apples). Theres almost a ginger snap spiciness as well as a touch of alcohol.

Taste; mmmm....plums, raisins, pears and apples all make a really nice appearance, along with a sweet and rich caramel maltiness. The ginger that I noted in the aroma came out in the flavor more than I was expecting, and theres a bit of lemon in the finish. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, but the carbonation is a bit on the sharp side which hurts themouthfeel a bit.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: brown pour with enormous head that lasts the life of the glass. lively mouthfeel but finish a little underwelming. parts of the whole are great and others lacking

[Bottle, January 2007] Dark brown frothy brew. Woody/Oaty aroma. The taste has traces of raisins - cant detect much of a chocolatey taste as advertised. Slightly bitter but not overbearing. Very nice and surprisingly light mouthfeel - a wet tasting beer. Good, crisp aftertaste. Great beer to have with a meal.

[bottle from Gallerie Pivni, March 2006]
Excelent aroma of woody sourness and prominent noble hops in balance with a sweet raisiny dark malt.  Pours a cloudy brown with a large top of large bubbles that recedes to a thick, lasting cover that is replenished by this beers effervescence.  Orval-like flavour with less bitterness and less dry.  Woody, sour, dried apricots, tobacco, candi sugar.  Subtle bitterness thta may not be enough for the residual sweetness and body.  Highly carbonated and not as warming as expected.  Medium to full body.
Poured a dark brown with a frothy tan head that was long lasting. Aroma was smoky with vinuos notes. Flavor continued smoky, yeasty, and bitter chocolate.
Dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is effervescently fruity spicy. Taste is somewhat drier than I expected from the aroma, but its not bad.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Brown. Sweet but not too sweet. Slightly fruity as well. Goes down easy and lingers well.

0.33l bottle at home from original glass. Deep ruby-brown color with tall beige head, almost no lace. Yeasty and fruity aromam, hint of smoke. Hoppy bitter taste with some yeast and dark chocolate, also some smoke. Light and easy to drink.

Bottle.  Pours brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, nice and sweet.  Taste is a little more chocolate and slightly smokey, fruit is still there.  A little bit dry in the finish.  Medium body.

12 oz. bottle.  Poured into a Leffe abbey stem glass.  Aromas of plums and chocolates.  This tastes a little more sour than sweet.  Has a raisin like fruity flavor.  Mouthfeel is lighter than expected.  Airy carbonation and powdered hot cocoa mix with a smokey risidue.  Comes across to me as a "poor mans" Dubbel compared to their outstanding Tripel.  Certainley drinkable but hardly meet my expectations.

25 oz bottle, Stateline Liquors.  Got this because I called in a phone order to be picked up by someone else and gave the wrong number, oh well.  Pours a mostly clear brown colored body under a very fizzy beige head that had very long retention due to the vigerous carbonation.  Aroma is fairly simple, lightly fruity with a slight sourness and a good amount of yeast.  A hint of chocolate malt also.  Flavor is quite fruity as well with some raisons and plums.  Some yeast and light alcohol on the finish with that light lactic sourness that is the downfall of this beer.  Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with alot of fizzy prickly carbonation.  Finish is a little sticky.  Overall, a beer Im not particularly fond of these days.  I dont care for that light acidic/lactic finish.

Huge offwhite coarse head. Dark red body thats kind of opaque, possibly because its hazy. Harmonic vinuous licorice aroma with spicy, yeasty notes. Deep, harmonic, bitter licorice taste with chocolate notes and a touch of bread. Dry, almost floral aftertaste. Relatively straightforward and a bit watery. Good, and drinkable, but nothing major. (0.75l bottle.)

Bottle; Had a mediun sweet and chocolate malt aroma. Black body with tan head and some lacing. Flavor had a good chocolate dry malt with some added sweetness and moderate bitterness. Left dry coco mix and cigar aftertaste on palate. Good Brew.

From C&C 750.  Pours a dark brown with orange tints.  Nose of yeats and dark fruits and brown sugar with an herbal earthiness.  Very smooth palate that brings forth most of the nose, with a smooth bitterness at the end.  Very good.

Bottled(330ml). -Deep brown coloured, medium sized tan head, fizzy. Nice spicy nose. Aroma is malty and spicy with caramel, chocolate and honey notes. Spicy, subdued yeasty and slight sweet finish. To be honest I was expecting much better beer.

One of the most drinkable Belgian ales Ive tried.  By that I mean this is not a beer to be sip and ruminate over, its not that complex.  Just a solid, dark brew.  Something Id want to drink every day.

750ml bottle, best by 01/09/07 - Pours dark brown with a huge, billowy head.  It has a fairly light aroma with yeast and some maltiness.  The flavor is a bready malt with some yeast noticeable and a metallic twinge.  I can still taste the latter a little bit in the finish.  Im not sure if this is just my preferences or theres something wrong with this bottle, but its not as good as I expected given a rating here that puts it in the top ten of Abbey Dubbels.  It has a surprisingly light flavor and a mouthfeel that verges on watery.  Its also pretty one dimensional, so the descriptions here that make it sound so complex make me wonder about my bottle.
