UPDATED: NOV 2, 2004 Pale Brown appearance with a nice white head.  Theres a spicy raisin texture to it... a tad metallic.  Sour cherries come through in the aftertaste along with a bittersweet roasted finish.  Light and alright.

Brown.

Interesting and lovely aroma, with notes of spruce, juniper, raisins, tree bark and cherry syrup.

Malt accented with notes of port, raisins, chocolate, ripe cherries and twigs. The finish is very dry with caramel and candy sweetness. This seems a little light bodied for the style.
Muy buena cerveza de abadia belga. Tostada y de agradable sabor. Con bastante alcohol (7,5%)

dark brown color.   taste of plum.  very smooth and tasty. as the brew warmed it tasted a lot like red wine, obviously with less alcohol though.  in addition to that you notice the raisins and chocolate and smokiness noted in the commercial description.
Dark Brown Coloring.  Aroma and Taste of Apple...Like Homemade Dry Apple Cider... Some Malt and Spice.. Overall Very Different but Enjoyable!!

Pours a dark brown color with a big head.  Interesting aroma... almost apple-ish?  Tasting... hot damn, it is apple!  In a dubbel!  Coupled up with slight malt and spice character, this is a winning beer!
amazing head that stood an inch outside the glass. "Notes of raisin" were a little too much for my taste but i loved the chocolate aftertaste. I would like to try aging this one.

I first heard about this beer when I was reading "Get Fuzzy" when Rob Wilco was balancing one on his stomach while drunk.  I wondered if it is real.  Lo and behold, it is!  So I found some, and I was amazed!!!  It tastes so much like the sparkling grape juice I drank as a kid, only better!  The creamy head, the pretty color, and the sweet taste...this beer is awesome!  I want to try the pale ale!

750ml bottle: Just as I removed the metallic protection piece on top of the cork and went to get a glass, the cork popped out and beer started to poured from the bottle  this is already an exciting beer. Quickly poured a glass of dark and hazy brown beer with huge foamy head with excellent retention. Aroma is mostly comprised of spices with some subtle notes of malt and yeast. Taste is more spicy then what Im used for an Abbey Dubbel but I still very much enjoyed that one, I would have appreciated a bit more roastiness though. Carbonation is perfect and body is above average.
Ruby colour with a solid head. Aroma has lots of fruit. Flavor is sweet with a bitter finish.
Fruity/grapy aroma, dark red/amber in colour with nice thick head. Citrus apple taste.

deep brown ale, lots of beige head that fizzes away quickly.  awesome aroma of candy and brown sugar, some yeast and spice, some cider notes. flavor hints at raisin and chocolate, some alcohol.  really enjoyable beer!

Bottle. pours a cloudy dark brown with a fat off white heads that surrenders like the French. alcohol and apple are dominant in the nose. very tart taste of fruit yeast dough and assorted spices. I am going to pick up a few of these to cellar to get a better handle on but i have to go with what i have at this point. this is very warming. finish is a sweet fruit and pepper with a solid malt backbone. I look forward to experiencing the aged versions of this.
Pours hazy brown with a thick white head...smells fruity and yeasty...tastes as you would expect...earthy, dark fruits...chocolately and port...good, but not outstanding...
A very well-made beer.  Amazing pour with thick, long lasting head.  Lacing consistent and continuous with aromas of yeast and fruit.  Very smooth with a slightly smoky/chocolate finish.
Ren-brown color, light fruity aroma and taste, Medium body, light dry finish.
Red/brown colour with a great head, lively on the tongue, cloudy looking. Yeast and sour fruit aroma. Fruity sweet raisin tasting with chocolate. Pretty nice.
Dry finish with subdued fruit. Some maltiness, no real kick. You can call it smooth.

This beer has a huge head, so pour slowly (takes about 5 min.) The nose is typically brown ale and the flavor is chocolate (not a sour brown). The flavor is rather bland at refrigerator temperature, but becomes more full as the beer warms. Pair with Corsendonk Agnus (abbey pale ale) for a chocolate/ vanilla experience. Goes well with  a cigar, if you are so inclined.
Reddish/brown color with a big fluffy tan head. Aroma of raisins, prunes and dark chocolate. Sweet flavor of raisins on first taste, turning slightly tart, then finishing dry.

Pours a nice rusty and muddy colored body with an enormous rocky tan head. The aroma is rather biscuity and tart. Light notes of basaltic vinegar and chocolate ice cream are rather pungent. I definitely pull some big suggestions of warm liquid chocolate poured over an apple big toasty notes, and rather nutty with hints of almond and Brazilian nuts. The finish suggests a tart doughy-ness, pretty yeasty and slightly citricits like a sour orange zest or something. hints of ground black pepper. 
 Im going to have to re-rate this one it taste a little off to me maybe it became light-struck in the store?
Ok, well after reading and judging by the majority response around here it sounds like the beer is supposed to be this tart and vinous. No re-rate necessary!  It's just too sour for me~

Bottle into tulip glass; purchased at Discount Licquor (Milwaukee).  Enjoyable beer, but not elite.  The smell was a nice yeasty, malty, somewhat acidic waft.  Pouring a murky/hazy orange brown with a huge beige and rocky head with nice lacing, this looked appetizing.  It didnt disappoint: sour apple, caramel, spice (mint and oregano).  Soft to active carbonation was almost but not quite too much, and it was medium to full bodied.

Slightly hazy brown with a large off-white head that lasts fairly well.  Soured fruit and yeast aroma.  Sweet, fruity, spicy and sour flavors - rich and delicious.  Medium body and moderate carbonation.
Pours brown with a good white head. Has that Belgian spciiness to it with hints of raisons. Slightly floral. Not overwhelming like some Belgians. I enjoyed it.

Bottled from 207th street warehouse,
poured a deep brown good sized head,
fruity aroma,body was a littile thin,Flavors kina yeasty and rasiny ehh ..it ok
As the commercial description states this has a fruity/yeasty aroma. Initial flavor is raisins and herbs. Thinner body than I expected but quite nice.
Incredible. Smell fruity yet slightly smokey. Tastes of rasins and chocolate. One of the best beers I have ever had

Aroma was fruity... kind of sweet and sour at the same time.  Also a slight hint of chocolate.  Appearance was wonderful... looked like dark muddy water.  Flavor was of dirt, chocolate, fruit, and yeast.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin.  Good beer.

This brew is all nose and mouthfeel...kind of like my girlfriend. 
Cheers
G-rat

Pours a mahogany color with foamy light tan head.  Aroma of citrusy fruit and wine.  Very dry...almost the dryness of Orval.  Sharp citrus flavor that reminds me a whole lot of wine.  Overall, definitely a delicious beer.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2004 Re-rateSecond tastig on draft was much improved (Strange for a Belgian). There was a hint of blood in the taste, but in a good way. Almost as if it was fortified with minerals. (No i'm not a vampire).

This is a pretty simple one - if you can get past the old (musty, sweaty) elements of the aroma - you have a wonderful beer. It pours beautifully, with a rich, dark head. The flavor is significantly "darker" than most dubbels, almost like a smoky Westmalle. The finish is creamy and a touch spicy.
Reddish brown in color with good head.  Aroma was intriguing.  Fruit and malt in a curious way.  Mouthfeel was smooth and pleasant.  Flavor was full, sweet and tart, raisins.  Not bad.

Pours a dark mahogany brown with a puffy light tan head.  Sweet caramel and Belgian yeasty aroma has a touch of earthy maltiness and light fruit.  Starts with a sweet caramel toffee body and a fresh yeasty flavor hinting at tartness toward the finish.  Full, smooth and tasty, a vice nice Abbey Dubbel thats hides its alcohol well.

Okay, I have been waiting to try this for a few days and now I have my chance. Here goes! Nice bottle. Poured into a Trappist glass with an opaque brown body and a tiny head. Head goes quickly and doesnt leave much lace. This beer has an original fragrance consisting of smoky fruit blends, yeast, and malt. I want to give this beer a ten for aroma but something is holding me back. I dont know for sure what it is. Mouthfeel is highly effervescent. Flavor is smoky, fruity, and slightly bitter in the finish. Tastes like a Belgian Strong Ale with a hint of smoke. FYI, I dont really like smoke in my beer; although I do enjoy smoke alongside my beer. Finish is peppery in the beginning and clean and sweet at the very end. Overall, I think this is a decent Abbey Dubbel and would enjoy drinking it again but Chimay Rogue would still be my primary choice.
Brown (slightly reddish) ,clear body.  Brownish frothy head, mostly diminishing.  Malty and spicy aroma.  Lightly bitter, lightly sweet initial flavour.  Moderately bitter, lightly sweet finish.

Bottled.
Dark amber with an off-white head.
A sourish and vinous aroma from peaches.
Champagnelike palate with a dark and fruity flavour. Rather fresh.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2004 Bottle from The Wine Company, Slough. Far too carbonated, complete killed the flavour. I removed much of the carbonation by some heavy stirring, but although that improved the flavour its hardly ideal to be stirring beer. Average in every way, shape and form. Hideously overrated.
Haxy amber, white head. Aroma is malty and fruity from peach and maybe cherry. Quite carbonated and rather vinous. Fruity and with a sourish finish.
I wrote a beautiful description of this ale and the crappy ratebeer server kicked me off when I tried to submit it. So you can all suffer until I decide to re-write it. There.

Dark and cloudy, reddish brown. Looks similar to dark apple cider. Head is large, soapy, long-lasting and a slightly brown-hued white. Smell is tangy and sweet grape, cinnamon, and earthy vegetable, like a sweet potato.  Medium bodied. Taste is dark grapes, coffee, chocolate, licorice and very drying hops. After is dry roasted hops, chocolate and a distinct sourness that rounds out the palate. Finely crafted ale, strongly flavored and delicious.

Hazy brown coloured body with a super dense off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, some root veg qualities (potatoes), cherries, nutmeg and definate malt. Medium to Full-bodied; Tart cherry flavour right up front followed by a large malt presence with the spicey qualities arising. Aftertaste is a good astringent maltiness with some sweet flavours and a bit of a drying feeling. Overall, a damn good dubbel, definately one to try! I got this 33 cL bottle courtesy of DougShoemaker at our last party in Toronto and sampled it on 26-May-2004. Thanks again Doug for everything!!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2005 Man I do like those abbey dubbels.  Definitely can sense the unique yeast strain of the style.  A lovely copper to reddish brown color, hint of either herb or spice and a good lace.  Hmm hmm good, though alas no Chimay.

Initially generous light brown head over a hazy brown body with ruby hints. The nose abunds with yeasty flavors, spices (pepper, nutmeg), dark chocolate and very fruity (grapes, plums, red apple). Palate is sweet (licorice, chocolate) and fruity with a light smoke note in the finish. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The sweetness is either a little unbalanced or too balanced by yeast flavors for it to be world-class and it actually gives a slightly tart character, but its a nice after-dinner drink and good interpretation of the style.

Redbrown with thin beige head.
Aroma of tomato, cheese, ham, malt, alcohol and cereals.
Fruity flavor with peppery and sweet tones.
Amber colour, off-white head. Complex malty flavour with a bit sourness. Roasted  bread. Dryed fruit/ dusty port (in a positive sense). Soft palate. Overall above average ale.

This abby brown ale is quite special. Pours ruby/brown with frothy white head. Nice fruity, spicy aroma. Clean smelling. Flavor is mild chocolate, smokey, fruity and yeasty. Seems uncomplicated and yet very satisfying. This is good.
Enormous carbonation, with a bubbling head that never went away.  Great color and aroma, with dark chocolate, caramel & fruit flavors create a memorable belgium ale.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2004 On draft at the Abbaye.  I remember this being absolutely delicious, but not this time.  Sorry Corsendokers, but this was a stanky sour tasting funkbrew.  Poorly handled?  Poorly aged?  Just my poor tastebuds?  In any case, Ill come back in time for a rerate.
Retasted (but not rerated) on 6-5-04:  this time I tried it from a bottle, and I think this is the firt beer that I've had that was "corked."  Sour, corky, overall funkbrew.
Red brown cloudy beer with a small tan head. Nuts and rasins dominates aroma. Sweet flavour: caramel, fruits and a malty bitterness at the end. Slightly acdic finish. I could drink alot of these :-)

Appearance: Nice looking beer that gushed when opened. Huge head, nice light brown dark ruby color, clarity very good, clear. Bubbles rising quickly and is very effervescent. Nice lacing on glass with persistent head throughout the session.

Aroma: Very complex aroma. Slight smokiness, no hop. Some caramelly malt with pineappley esters. Slight almond/sherry notes as well with a nutty component to it. I also got a winey aroma with chocolatey notes out of this. Nice!

Flavor: The flavor of this beer doesn't match the complex aroma, but its still nice. Raisiny malt with spicy yeastiness and a vague smokey flavor. No hop flavor which is ok for style.

Mouthfeel: High carbonation gives the impression of a thinner mouthfeel, and the carbonic acid and alcohol bite knock this one down a little in the mouthfeel rating. Still, not a bad mouthfeel.

Overall: Good beer, with concentration of great characteristics in some fields (aroma and appearance) and not as great (but not bad!!) in others (flavor and mouthfeel). Would definitely try this again as it is a rather complex beer and good for style.

Pours muddy brown with a large white head.  Aroma is raisin, chocolate and yeast.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate and dried fruit.  Not much yeast in the flavor.  Good sweetness.  Finish is a little dry hops.  Alcohol evident.  Good carbonation.  A very nice dubbel.

A dark brown but not opaque color with a massive tan foamy head. Scent of a rich dessert with chocolate and dark fruit with a hint of smokiness too. Initial punch of alcohol fades to a sweet nutty flavor with some vegetal qualities in the middle and a dark unsweetened chocolate follow, very mild bitter aftertaste along with the warming effects of the alcohol. A great find for me and one I will buy several of on my next roadtrip!

Label reads "Pater Noster" in Europe.  This is the real deal; deep brown with firm yeast aroma.  Dry at the first taste, but this beer will explode in complexity in the mouth.  Those who like Belgian beers, and particularly the abbey ales should not miss this one.

Thanks Doug!
Pours a dark brown, cloudy body with a thick off-white head, with lots of nice bubbles. Looks good already! Aromas are not too strong. Slightly fruity, and I can also smell a little bit of alcohol here, but believe me it makes it really nice. Tastes like pear juice with alcohol. Nice carbonation makes a great mouthfeel, and smooth from start to finish. This is another good beer in what seems to be a neverending rating of trappist beers. Do these monks make a bad beer? Nice one!
Dark with hints are red and a big fluffy head.  Aromas are winter berries and banana with chocolate. Flavours, winter fruit, chocolate and some citrus sourness.  Great foaming mouthfeel.
This is one hell of a good beer.Everything about this beer is quality.Looks great,smells great,taste great.

bottle 3/27/04.  Pours a light, reddish brown; clear; huge beige head, mostly lasting.  Aromas of orange, bubblegum, fresh fennel, banana, and clove.  Little alcohol presence on nose.  Flavors of mild malts.  Belgian yeast flavors are somewhat underwhelming, though tasty.  A bit tinny.  Light citrus, wine, prune.  The palate is wet, coating, slightly astringent on the finish.  Deceptively quaffable.

Poured mine into an Orval glass.  Had a 1/4", persistent tan head.  Smelled wonderful, with hints of chocolate, raisins, maybe a touch of vanilla, dates, and banana.  I think I could spend half an hour looking for aromas in this, its so complex.  First sip revealed a medium mouthfeel, with strong notes of plum and dark chocolate, and perhaps some bubble gum/banana esters.  Fruity up front, sweet in the middle, mild hint of hops in the rather short lived finish, slightly cloying.
Brown color with light brown foamy head. Bitter shlight bit of chocolate taste. Not spectacular, also not bad.
Malty, malty, malty.  Aromas of raisen, plum, rich dark malt, Belgian Candy sugar.   Hass a rich malty, molasses flavor.  Yummy!

Malty aroma, with a hint of citric sharpness. The flavour is malty and alcoholic, but has a very sweet treacle and molasses character. In fact, too sweet for me. I have no doubt this is a good beer, but it is just too cloying for my tastebuds.
With a full airy head and beautiful brown color, this is definitely one of the best beers i've ever had. Period.
large foamy head a bit suprising. rich sweet aroma lead me into a pleasent sweet chocolate tasting beer. very smooth on palate. solid overall will drink again.

Deep dark ruby body. The tan head is rather large and foamy. The aroma is caramel, dark fruit, and yeast. The flavor is sweet caramel, raisins, plums and little bit of alcohol. Body is medium with very lively fizzy carbonation. Not bad, but ther are better to be had.

Very nice hazy brown color with a bit of orange and a huge, fluffy, long-lasting tan head. Clove, malt and banana in the aroma. Sweet banana, clove, and malt flavors with a little spice and hops. Very tingly feel with a fairly dry finish. Very nice.
Garnet appearance with a bigger than average head.  Muted, fruity aroma.  Spicy, fruity taste with overtones of plums and figs.  Crisp, tart finish.
Nice dark brown pour with a thick white head. Nice yeast, fruit, grape aroma. Decent taste. Nice, smooth, and flavorful. Raisin/grape flavor, with some malt. Tasted very well. Impressed indeed!

Pours a dark brown with a huge off white head, great lacing. Good looking beer. Aroma is pretty much like the commercial description. You have the yeast, the fruits (raisin or grape wine, maybe the port aroma coming through,) though the smokiness it mentions doesn't show too much.  Now I can really detect the port. Flavors are abundant and fairly complex. The port hits home first, then the raisin/grapes roll on in, a bread (sourdough comes to mind) and a slight touch of alcohol. The palate is highly carbonated and tangy. Full  body with a nice finish of alcohol and a tang. Fine dubbel.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2004 A dark brown pour with a strong tan head.  A lot going on in the nose.  Very fruity aroma.  I can definately taste the raisins and dark chocolatey after-taste.  I really want to get another and hold on to it for a while to see what changes occur.
Dark brown hue with a very nice head.  Very drinkable and tasty.  Light notes of fruit and roasted malts. Balanced and tasty.  Very solid.

Wow! I have tried this beer in a bottle, then tap, and let me tell you it is night and day. Forget the bottle, it isn't even worth mentioning. From the tap, however, this pours out a deep dark brown,with a ruby red tinge, and a medium tan head which fills and then slowly dissipates, leaving a long lasting lace which grips the glass like there is no tomorrow. If it is too cold like the one I had, warm it in your palms a little, and let the aromas flow. Caramel, Banana, raisins. . . how do I describe this delightful aroma. My first taste hinted of cocoa, no . ., caramel, then a whiff of dry alchohol. The texture was creamy like velvet. So soft an complex; let no wine lover tell you beer can't be as complex as wine. The warmer this beer became, the more I loved its taste. It finishes witih a bit of alcohol, but it is extremelty delicious. I sampled it to many female friends of mine who generally do not like beer, and I have some converts. One of the world's truly great beers.

Garnet highlights are found in this brown brew that has a decent mocha colored head. The aroma is typically Belgian with yeast, malt, fruit and caramel coming to play. The flavor follows the aroma with a smooth and warming palate that finishes dry. Not bad.

This is one of my favourite belgians. fruit/winelike aroma, deep brown color. out of the bottle it's a bit heavy on the carbonation, but on tap this was fine. 'fruit' prevalent in the initial taste, however this fades to a more wine/raison flavor as it glides down the throat. drier than most belgians (a plus for me) and a bit more complex than many i've had. tap is fairly better than bottle, but the bottle is quite worth it as well.

Pours with a copious, perennial head; fruity, roasted aroma, some dates or raisins prevelant; oaky, woody, flavor with slight fruity esters showing up; fairly thin body; tastey, smooth, quite quaffible, not much aftertaste; quite drinkable; a good, "mellow" Belgian.
Bottled. Mid-brown with rich head. Mild and honeyish with soft, livley mouthfeel. Fairly dry with a bit of caramel. Gentle, complex and well balanced.

Deep brown in color with a ruby-reddish hue, nice brownish head, very smooth & drinkable, great balance, sweet & malty but yet a slight tingy hoppiness, caramel undertones, a warming feeling as it slides down, more flavors that I just can't put my finger on, overall a great brown ale
I really enjoyed this one too. Brown in color with a huge head. Caramel fruity flavor. this beer warms you up too. Good beer.
Dark brown with a high brown head. Nice spicy and hoppy aroma. Lots of carbonation. Strong yeast. Quite dry finish and palate.

Ya know, this is much much better on tap thanin a 750 ml bottle. Pours brown with a huge tan head. Earth aroma that has the distinctive yeasty Belgian note to it. Carmel malty fruity flavor, with a hint of sourness. This is where the tap version that I had differs. I would say that the tap version was darker and had more of a Dunkel flavor to it than the bottle, and would even raise my draught rating to around 4.4ish. So all, take a note and give the tap version a try.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Not bad - a medium brown with a thick head.  Relatively malty sweet with hints of spice and chocolate.  Fairly smooth and balanced with a bit of a sour finish.
Not very impressed.  Sweet, fruity, and spicy all in one beer.  Felt like I may be drinking water and cough syrup.

Bottle.  Deep cloudy brown with off-white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and fruity, but you can smell the yeasty alcohol.  Taste is smooth and warming with hints of raison, fig, and chocolate.  Damn this is good.

Bottle gushed a bit upon opening.  Deep malt aroma.  Dark brown color with a long lasted beige head.   Complexe flavor profile.  Chocolate sweetness with a subtle spice bite.  Alcohol taste very evident.
(750 ml. Bottle)  Pours a amber-brown color with a thick frothy beige head.  Has flvors of dark chocolate, caramel, fruit, and port.

Pours a nice dark reddish-brown. Sweet tangy aroma, very fruity. A sour flavor followed by a port aftertaste. This beer has aged quite well with the collage of flavors on the palate. I think a nice choice for a after Xmas beer.

Bottle pours a red brown color with a monster head and good lace.  Aroma consists of yeast.  The flavor is quite yeasty and malty.  The palate is fairly moderate.  Overall, another good Abbey Dubbel, but not as good as some others.
Pours brown with a large tan and frothy head.  Strong fruity and yeasty aroma.  Slightly acidic but otherwise fruity with notes of raisins and wine.  Light on the palate and does not linger.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2003 Brown colored with an amber hue and almost clear. Initial head is frothy and tan but settles down to a thin layer that is dense and creamy. Aroma of sweet malt and chocolate with a hint of dried fruit and alcohol. Also a bit yeasty which is very nice. Mouthfeel is effervescent and a smooth medium body. Flavor is mostly a chocolate one with notes of raisins and figs. Overall one of the better Dubbels I've had.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: On draught. Nice brown body and a creamy beige head. Chocolate and malt nose. Chocolate, nut and fruit flavor. Smooth and well balanced!

This is one of the better in it's kind. Maybe the fact that this bottle had stood in my closet for a year had something to do with it. 
The head is nice, but not extraordinary, it remains quite long, but the bubbles are big.
It had a fenomenal aroma, wich I liked. 
The taste has initial choclate in it, later more sweet (honey) and with a bitter, dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2006 Re-rate 8/06
Deep ruby/copper body.  Light tan head.  Nose is plenty of plum, fruit, chocolate, mint, dark caramel, earthy malt, fruit.  Flavor is slightly cherry, some caramel, mint, yeast.  Not as complex as I recall.  Dry oakey caramel/yeast finish.  A bit thin


Original rate: 9/5/9/4/19
Nice head - I can see the individual bubbles.  Rich brown appearance.  The first thing I thought of when I smelled this was peanut butter.  Malt hits the tounge first, then brown sugar.  Id like a bit more chewiness in this but its still great stuff.
Not as good as the Corsendonk Agnus, but a good brown.  Orangish-brown body.

Beautiful looking beer.  Rich and inviting with a huge head. Tons of carbanation bubbles dancing around.  Aroma is primarily fruity, plum, rasin, dates. A mild sweetness with just a hint of bitterness or sourness lost in the back.  Flavor is very fruity, mostly sweet mild nutty tastes.  I could have done with a little less of the champaigne like carbination. For me it seems to complicate the flavors.  Not my favorite Belgian, but definitely a good one.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2003 Smells ok.  First taste produces some zing, and then the zang comes through.  Corsendong lacks some of the malty characteristics that I would expect.  Coursemydong is Belgian, but it just isn't very full flavored.  But rest assured, if you give Cocksndong a taste, the raisin will come through!

An old favorite.  Hazy brown with a glorious lasting tan head.  Aroma revolves around raisins and chocolate.  Flavor reflects similar notes, with some port echoing through as well, along with jammy black currants.  Beautiful malts, a fine beer.

Poured into ballooned goblet from bottle rich, creamy brown in colour.  Thick lasting head nice lacing.  Nose was rich with fruit; raisins and plums I think.  Nicely balanced begins slightly bitter but hints of raisins and plums come through making for a very pleasant finish.  Seemingly very available. A nice beer to have around.

My first Belguim Ale rating, I can't compare to others. This much I know, this pours (from the bottle) to a monster tan head, slow to disipate. Dark amber color. Very tasty, I think I could live on this for awhile. Yeasty aroma,  pleasant. The taste was a bit sweet/nutty, very smooth. A little taste of alcohol, excellent finish.

11/5/03.  On draft at Stuffed Sandwich in San Gabriel, CA 11/5/03.  2001 Vintage.  Pours dark brown with fluffy tan head that dissipates.  Good lacing.  Nose is of wet malt with light sweetness.  Taste is a little bit musty, mellow dark malts, very lightly metallic, and subtly sweet.  Very smooth, even creamy texture, with a light carbonation zing.  Thin-to-medium body.  Finish is very smooth, mellow and complex of malts.  Very minutely souring.  This beer is so smooth and delicate that it cools the tongue.  Pretty good stuff.

Gushing to creamy, absurdly huge head; brown beer with orange shine, clear. Nose of molasses, brown sugar, nutty. Nutty taste, too, very sweet, sugary, faint wood notes; harsh, unpleasant bitter finish. Very high carbonation, making the beer fizzy at the edge of sourish. Very poor beer, IMO. Forced, crude aromas and flavours.
Brown colored, with a really nice white head. The taste is sweet with a bitter finish. Contains notes of raisins and fruits. Very nice indeed.
750 ml bottle. I wouldnt say no to this brew if offered, I must re-rate with comments soon                      .
aroma is very special. It has a certain earthy, outdoor feel to it. The beer is high on carbonation, taste is dry, spicy, earthy and a little sour...

Wonderful easy to find abbey ale.  I haven't had this in a while, but i really rather enjoyed this.  Very fruity and raisiny with some notes of chocolate.  All I really remember is being delightfully surprised.  Must drink out of a Corsendonk glass (and not the one of the left there, a more goblety one)
very distinctive aroma of molasses; dark brown with a huge tan head; the taste was not at all like the smell - in fact, it's slightly sour

The aroma of this beer is interesting, a touch of fruit, a little bit of something sweet.  The color is something between caramel and milk chocolate.  The flavor is nutty, chocolatey, and fruity.  In my mind this is a great example of a dubbel.
Almost shot our dog with the cork from this beer.  At least he got to enjoy the bit that spilled out adter I opened tho bottle.  Very interesting tasting beer.  Looks cool too.

Murky tan/brown liquid with a light tan head. Aromas of dates, raisins, oranges, brown sugar and toffee. Spritzy feel. Wine like acidity cut through most of the flavors. Apples and raisin with only hints of malt. There is a late toasty malt finish, but to thin in the middle.  A cross between a flemish red and a dubbel.
Dark brown color with a huge fluffy brown head. Aroma of mostly yeast with a little dark fruit. Flavor is sweet, sour, acidic, yeast and a little nutty.

Dark vibrant ruby color, with a continous head building on top.  Smells of yeast and of some berry notes too.  The beer just feels a little too carbonated.  Has a seltzerish mouthfeel to it at first, I guess it needs to settle more than usual. Still has a nice taste to it.
Slight metallic aroma. Creamy head that never dies. Creamy smooth palate that finishes watery. Yeast and fruit flavor with a licorice aftertaste.

This head is huge. Very thick and tan. The beer itself is a beautiful amber. Smells like yeast, raisins, and toffee. Tart taste. Metallic and tangy. Very tangy. I don't know if this is supposed to taste like this. Very different than anything I have had.

Fantastic tawny hue with a massive light brown head that just gets bigger and stay like a piece of styro-foam.  Orangey aroma with yeasty tones.  Sweetish orange flavour and a little malt.  A tad watery though.
Large light-brown head. Dark red-brown colour. Apple and dough aroma. Highly carbonated, sweet, litlle acidic. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2003 Whole lot of head on this one, very carbonated.  Nice deep reddish-brown color.  Yeasty malty aroma with dark fruits (raisins, plums) and maybe a little bit of spice.  Flavor is sweet with some of the dark fruit that I found in the aroma.  Mouthfeel is subpar, I found the texture a little too watery.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2003 Very nice abbey brown.  Little roasty on the balace, not too sweet at all.  Dried fruit aroma.  I love the color on this one.  Nice mouth feel, not too heavy.  Perfect rendition of the style.

Poured a thick, creamy beige head over a deep red body. Aroma is nice, rich and almost vinous. Light buzz of alcohol warmth and a pleasant texture on the palate. Flavor is nice - smooth, warm and sweet with a lightly bitter finish. Very, very good.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2004 Strange, but its doesnt seem to keep a head very well.  When it was there, there was a beige head over a copper body.  Very bready malt aroma and a subtle raisin/Catawba grape.  The fruity esters are also fairly subdued as are the spicy aromas from yeast(pepper & clove), some slight woodiness.  Intensely malty (toasty) w/ flavors or raisins, yeast, and a little alcohol.  Well balanced, but toward malt and finishes slightly on the sweet side; red grape alcohol fruitiness.  no hops in flavor or aroma anywhere.  Highly carbonated like a dubbel should be, warming alcohol, and medium body seems lighter than actual due to carbonation.  A good dubbel but I was a little dissapointed in this one.  Maybe my expectations we a little to high.  Its not quite as complex as Id hoped.

I don't know why I chose this beer for my first rating since I have a Chimay Rouge and a Blue in my fridge but here it goes...  Pours with a huge head that is fed for a good while by the (excessive?) carbonation.  Deep red body that is quite opaque.   The carbonation almost overpowers the initial taste of rich malt and green apple but as it moderates the taste really comes through.  Good pour if a bit too sweet for my taste.

355 mL bottle, goblet, 45 degrees.  Very large, rocky, frothy, off-white head is on a murky brown-red body.  Toasted bread, cookie malt; missing hops; earthy, cobweb yeast; raisin, port, smoke toffee, aromas.  I picked up everything the bottle said I would except for the dark chocolate.  Heavily sweet flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter finish.  Prominant alcohol flavor.  Port and raisins step it up in the flavor, but the chocolate is still missing to me.  Creamy smooth texture is somewhat broken up by the fizzy carbonation.  The body is medium-heavy.  The bottom line is: rich, creamy yumminess.

Nice ale.  inviting aroma of yeast and malt.  Flavor has a fruitiness too it to complement the malt.  Moderately sweet.  Personally I prefer the plale ale by Corsendonk but this is a good brew as well.

I haven't been into Belgians lately.  I was expecting this to be kind of sweet.  My first impression is that it's sour kind of like an apple.  This is really starting to grow on me.  I have to remember that this is not a U.S. microbrew.  Now I'm starting to taste some of the sweetness and chocolatey aftertaste.  It's copmplex and it's flavors are subtle.  Not like a Rogue chocolate stout (tasting and smelling like chocolate milk.  this is complex like a fine wine.  Aroma is like the taste - very subtle chocolate with sour apple.  Beautiful retaining head.  This is a Belgian I would like to buy again.  Palte was just a bit watery though.

Mild spicy yeasty hop aroma.Dark reddish brown apearance with average head and fine carbonation.Coca cola like carbonation followed by yeasty bread flavors with some sourness towards the end.Carbonation was tingly on the tounge.
Tap. Dark brown with large white head, nice lacing. Aroma has malt, bread, musty, yeast. Taste is fairly sweet, molasses maybe, some dark malt. Not great but not bad.
Pours a deep luscious brown. Nice tan head on this. Nice sweetened malt nose with a pleasantly sweetened and spicy taste. Finishes very well and is smooth too. Very good beer!

The Rathskeller Wine & Beer Fest:When poured, this beer had a small sized tan head with fine sized bubbles that fully diminished.The body was clear with no carbonation observed.The hue was brown and the aroma was fruity, spicy, malty and lightly hopped.The flavor was lightly sweet and lightly bitter.The mouthfeel of this beer was smooth, slightly tingly, thin and light bodied.This beer left virtually no lacing.
Brown colour, huge head. Fruity aroma with notes of black currant. Malty and sweet flavour with warming alcohol.
Brandy like aroma... HUGE sweet and malty.  Dark brown and cloudy like a mud puddle.  Fairly Yummy.
One of my personal favorites. Very full in flavor and palate. Beautiful color and head. The 3L bottle will have better character than the smaller bottles.

This was excellent!  Great wine-like nose, alot of raisin, oak(?), carmel...etc aroma.
Thick mouthfeel, almost grainy.  Sour and bitter with sweet undertones as it warms.  Wonderful.  (alot more affordable in my area than Chimay, better too.)

This brew poured a large head of light brown mostly lastin bubbles that left a poor lacing.  Its body was a very nice semi-transparent dark brown color.  The arom was a very nice mixture of malt and smoke.  The flavor was very nice and contained notes of raisins, malt, spice and caramel.

A hoppy sweet raisin aroma with notes of fruit, port and a little barnyard. Orange Blossom red color with an explosive head that kept growing and growing like one of those sponge animals that come in the small pills. Flavor is tart and zesty, nice toasted caramel flavor at the warmer temperatures. Also notes of cheese and a very nice hop presence. Carbonated and sour on the palate. Overall this is a good amber with a large body and obvious notes of Belgian origin, a true work of art.

An incredibly well done take on this style.    I had 750ml of this one to enjoy.  The pour in incredible, the head just never stops, even with the best pour, you only had about an ince of ale, and the rest was a huge, creamy frothy head.  The aroma fills the whole room, with the scent of raisins and figs and quite a floral bouquet.  This head quite literally has a mind of its own, it just kept growing.  The taste is extremely full-boided, sometimes quite complex and others quite vague.  Throughout, you get a flavor of sweet brown sugar, cinnamon, figs and raisins.  I enjoyed this one alot, but it is definitely one of those that can only be enjoyed once every few months.
Think of a very well done brown ale and now make it belgium.  This is very good but very yeasty. Something different.

One of the best beers I've had, ever.  Pop the cap, and aromas of raisins and lavender rise from the bottle.  Oh the fruity aroma!!  Pours a darkish yellow, somewhat murky.  Starts sweet, finishes sweeter.  Very, very smooth, silky mouthfeel.  This is a very complicated beer.  I can't place all the flavors and aromas I sense, but they are most pleasing.
Dark red-brown, tan head. Wheat, treacle and raisins in aroma, along with yeast. Fruity, caramel flavors. Good body, nice drink.
This was best from a tulip glass. A classic Belgian with good beige-ish head, nice aroma and wonderful, somewhat raisiny taste.
Nice off-white head.  Raisins and yeast in the aroma.  Nice flavor.. raisins, figs, nuts.  Not too sweet and the alcohol isn't overpowering.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2003 Appearance is reddish brown with a good amount of off white head. Has some shimmering cloudiness.
Smells like sweet alcohol and figs, maybe some brown sugar in there and the yeast mixes in to the aroma, drying it out somewhat.
Taste is surprisingly dry yet has some rich undertones. Like dry maple syrup, and molasses, even some woodiness in here.  Perhaps a bit too dry.  There is some big alcohol-fig/raisin taste towards the begining/middle, and the body is medium.  Dosent thin out as much as leffe brun, so that was nice, though I find myself wanting just a touch more sweet malt.  This beer is very delicately balanced and must be served at the right temperature (60-62 degreeish), to fully appreciate the complexity.  This is very different from chimay red, and it is pleasant to try something different.
Thin offwhite head on a reddish/brown body. A thin head remained throughout. Has an aroma of raisins and a little nutty. Pretty nice stuff.
Raisins, with a good strong smell. Well balanced and appropriate body. Not too sweet. Lacing hangs on glass all day.
Poured with an OK head that quickly diminshed and left no lacing.  It had a fruity aroma.  It had a flavor of sour grapes, very good!
Smells like raisins, very aromatic, perfume like.  Flavor is sweet and slightly sour.  No bitterness.  Heavy, wet mouthfeel.  Smooth, with alcohol barely noticable.  Pretty good stuff.

Beers pours (in corsendonk glass) a large, frothy head.  Color of beer is dark brown, but can easily be seen through when held up to light.  Aroma is of plum, raisin, molasses, and chocolate.  Head is off-white to medium caramel colored, and soft in texture formed by very small bubbles.  Head rises slowly like the back end of the Titanic, spilling over onto the wood desk - damn it!!  Will it ever stop?!?!  Alright, head is scooped out with a metal spoon and discarded (is that bad?).  Feels good in the mouth, very smooth, but not dry.  Easily drinkable, somewhat sweet - the alcohol is very well hidden, not even noticable.  Excellent beer - will definitely drink again (and again).  Digital room temperature reading is 71 degrees.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit, then.
Very good overall, complex flavor with some hints of a traditional brown ale flavor. Very smooth.
Dark beer with a nice head.  You can taste the added zip although the alcohol is hidden nicely.  Smooth aftertaste left me wanting another.
Dark ruby red color with a thick head. Aroma of raisins & fruit. Intitially had a raisin flavor leading into bitter then a sweet aftertaste. One of the most complex beers I have tasted

Red-brown body topped by a thick lasting off white head with good lace.  Sour yet slightly sweet aroma with vinious notes and hints of berry.  A touch sweet and malty flavor with a touch of spice and fruit.  Full bodied and dry with a wierd almost numbing sensation on the tongue.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Hazy red/Brown color with huge head and some lacing, medium-bodied. Apricot, nutmeg, floral aroma. Fruity and bittersweet chocolate twang with some underline sweetness, fizzy. Good balance with a port like finish. A well made Belgium Brown, a favorite of mine.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2006 Great looking, dark with a nice thick head.  A little hint of citrus  or zing is a better description when sipping it.  Cant taste the alcohol at all. Ah, how young and innocent I was.  Lets see if things have changed. 12 oz bottle, best before 14/10/06, been sitting on this one for a bit waiting to rerate.  Let this bottle warm for 30 minutes.  Poured into a Corendonk slimmed tulip glass (not the one in the pic).  Pours with a very large head, thats sitting for a while.  Color is murky brown with a ruby-copper translucence.  Cannot see through the beer and have to catch the light just right to see into it.  Once that happens one can make out a lot of bubbles just going crazy inside.  Aroma is strong, malty with a Belgian sweetness.  Digging deeper I feel an effervescent, lively character.  Just shoots through the nostrils.  Mouthfeel is a perfect combo of carbination and medium body.  Leaves a sweet belgian aftertaste.  No hint of alcohol throughout.  The taste is what I have come to seek from Dubbels.  Nothing over the top.  A strong malt presence but well balanced with a the sweetness.  I get a slight hint of chocolate.  It is a beautiful beer and still damn good.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Beautiful thick dark pour. Light brown head with no lacing.  Aroma of raisins and faint hint of alcohol in the nose - but overall extremely malty and pleasant. Very cloudy appearance with lots of sediment.  Flavor - detect raisins, dates and the alcohol is hidden well. One of the classics and probably the best Abbey Dubbel I have had. Overall - excellent.

Opaque chocolate brown w/ large, cottony light brown head. Fresh yeasty nose w/ notes of fruit (raisins), light smoke, & toffee. Very carbonated feel. Flavour is sweet (caramel, toffee) & fruity (raisins, plums) at first, lightly acidic, vinous & woody in the middle, and bitter chocolate in the finish which linger with the flavour of a cherry blossom.
This is a kickass Belgian Brown Ale.  Don't drink the bottle, though, only on draught is it good.
Bottled. Crimson with a large fluffy white head. Sweet raison and malt aromas. Only slightly sweet relative to some Belgian's but nicely balance. Lacked depth and length.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2012 
May, 2003 Looks muddy. Smells good - smoked cheese. Taste is like a watery spiced malt loaf. I didnt find this interesting or attractive. I played with it for a while - took it out to the theatre and bought it some new clothes - but we just didnt get on. Some beers are like that. [2.1]
June, 2012 330ml brown bottle Chrissie brought back from Brussels. Browny red appearance. Malty sweet. Quite clean, though yeasty notes linger in the finish. Light mouthfeel, especially for a 7.5%. Awareness of alcohol in the swallow, along with a touch of woody spice. A quite pleasing beer - easy drinking, tasty and satisfying. [3.5]
Pretty good but nothing special.  Better than the light ale.
Pours an amber brown with frothy head. Fruity maltiness in the nose and flavors. A touch sweet but still a nice brew.

Pours with a huge light-brown head atop a hazy chestnut body  no lacing as the beer is consumed.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange and spicy (cardamom and more).  Taste is much the same, though some raisin also sneaks in.  Finishes sweet and floral.  A wet beer, but not watery.

Had from bottle on April 18, 2003 at the Suffed SandwichAn interesting beer, it pours with a light brown head and a solid brown color with a slightly hazy appearance.  The flavor is quite acetic with a sweetness that masks the alcohol well.  Smells of toasted malts and fruit.  A slightly bitter finish, but it goes quite well with the sweetness of the beer.
Wonderful large frothy head topping this redbrown Belgian. Hints of raisins and "English Sweets" in the flavor. Hoppy bitter finish.
This beer smells much like a Weiss Beer, but doesn't taste much like one.  I enjoyed this beer much more than I expected to.  This is much better than their pale ale.
I wasn't saticfied. I expeceted a real fine beer. But the aroma is only a bit of malt, and the taste is a bit sour. Perhaps it was bad?

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2005 Huge frothy latte head. Dark, slightly cloudy reddish brown. Sour hints compliment a generally sweet aroma. Some vinous and Apple notes as well. Medium bodied with smooth carbonation. Nicely done sweetness. A lot of interaction between different sugary flavors. Very light dried fruit notes and a chocolaty, earthy tang. This is all rounded out by a moderate hop bitterness in the finish. This is a steal for the price. A fine example of a fine style.
I did not care for this beer at all.  I think that there is way too much chocolate going on in this medium complex brew.
This beer has a great nose.  Sweet and malty.  A fruity, roasted malt flavor.  The champagne of Dubbels.  Great looking beer. Awesome.

Yummy!  Smells fruity like peaches, plums, raisins, and even raspberries.  Drinks like liquid peach cobbler, with a nice doughy malt backbone underscoring fruit and luscious cream with a pinch of spice.  Alcohol gives the illusion of WARM peach cobbler sitting in your belly.  Give me some more!

Red/brown color with a very large frothy head.  Upon opening the bottle the nose is greeted by a fruity sweet wine-like aroma.  A sweet fruity(raisin) flavor; slightly sour and yeasty.  Lots of carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2003 Pours a nice reddish brown color with a large bubbly head. The aroma was decent...yeasty, slightly sour, fruity. The flavor was full...raisins, slightly sour, yeasty. The only thing about this beer that I didn't particularly like was the feel. The carbonation was just overwhelming. There was simply too much of it. Each drink filled me with copious amounts of unwanted gas. It actually kept me from enjoying what would probably be a magnificent brew.

I looked for this on "www.ratewine.com"...but it wasn't there!  What is this apple cider/port doing on ratebeer.com?  J/k.  Anyways, this beer is a bit apple-cider like for me, even down to the sediment in the bottom of the glass.  Cidery, porty, and dry flavor.  I liked the beverage, but this Corsendonk is guilty of stretching the definition of "beer."

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2007 Huge head of bubbles on the bottom and nice frothy head on the top.  Great carbonation throughout.  Color of dark brown with decent clarity.  Aroma of raisins, yeast, a bit of old decaying wood and fruit.  Full bodied beer with flavors of malt, yeast, various fruits and alcohol.  Finish is slightly metallic, dry and warming from the alcohol.  Also some lingering spices (pepper) that make the tongue tingle.  Not the best of the variety but a good beer in its class.  Kind of average for a dubbel.
Fruity sweet aroma.  Good malt backbone throught.  Finishes to the sweet side, then gradually dries out.  A good example of the style.
Rather ordinary.  Yeasty and sour, with dominant raisin notes.  Too weak and too sour for my tastes.  I strongly prefer Westmalle Dubbel.

Dark brown color similar to a brown ale. Excellent belgain. Very malty flavor but enough hops are present. This is a beer I have been overlooking for a while but Im glad I finally gave it a try. Not as complex as many, but certainly as good

It has a dark, hazy brown color and a medium sized, lingering off-white head. The aroma is hoppy and slightly fruity with malts and yeasts. Full body with lots of carboantion, the flavor is sweet with malts and has touches of yeast, raisons, and grapes. Another winner from Belgium. Imagine that, a good beer from Belgium, who woulda thunk it?

An amazing brown ale. Malty, yeasty, rich fruit hints on the nose and the tongue. I would rate it higher but each bottle seems different from the one before, some are hoppier than others. A must have!
UPDATED: APR 2, 2003 fruity aromas, with a subtile look of what's to come.  This stuff is good! I don't usually go for fruity beer, but this one ROCKS!
Deep brown/red. Large head. Very malty nose with raisins and plums. Palate is filled with port flavors, raisins and dates.  A very good Dubbel.
Fruity Malty nice yest flavor and citrusy higly corbination a few flavours swirling around through out drink

This had a lot of citrus and astringent flavors mixed in with the somewhat fruity malt - reminded me of a carbonated wine in a way.  Finish was dry but had some sourness to it.  Deep ruby brown with off white head and nice lacing.

I really liked this beer.  My first observation was the sweet, fuity, almost wine like nose. Then when I poured it the dark thick sponge like head, and lastly the sweet, smooth, fruity, with a hint of choclate flavor.  Definintly the best beer I've so far this year.

This brown ale has amber glints and a thick, foamy white head. The nose is citrusy (lemons) with blood/copper and underripe strawberry notes. The palate is very bubbly, almost too much so with a slightly astringent lemony characteristic and very little malt. The finish is lgithly astringent, coppery and mildly spicy.
Draught, Don Quiotte, Bruges. I loved this beer, a nice deep brown with a chunky white head. Fruity in character with malt and hops both evident. Nicely balanced and very drinkable.
A superb ale from a great brewer.  Lots of carbonation, and full bodied.  Great aroma.  Enjoyed very much.
Very fruity (especially apples) and very carbonated.  Full, cloudy body and full, frothy head.  Fairly sweet finish with a touch of malts and roastiness.

KA-POP!  I think the cork put a dent in my ceiling.  This has and cloudy, rusty appearance, with a nice head of medium-sized white bubbles.  Fruity, yeasty, sweet aroma.  The flavor is tart up front, but mellows into a slight malty sweetness, with notes of raisins, plums, and perhaps cherries.  There is a slight, port-like character to it as well.  This is like a cross between Westy 8 and Trois Pistoles, but with a little less maltiness and a lot more TANG!

Super carbonated, slighlty cloudy brown.  Bubbly.  Slightly sour smell accompanied by a similar taste.  Some hints of chocolate and roast but only in the background.  Finish is slightly spicy with a hint of clove.  Not my fav. style.

Be careful when you open it. The cork could put someone's eye out, and we don't want that, do we? Extremely carbonated, almost a detrement. Huge sturdy head. Coke brown color. Floral smell and initial taste, note af chocolate and plums. Very mild hop bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2003 The cork pops with the authority of champagne. Pours deep ruby/mahogany with a huge frothy tan head and tiny bubbles dancing to the surface. A little spice in the nose. Flavor: Starts champange like and spicy
                and the finish dry and a little tart. You can feel the alcohol warm your face.
Very fruity, great aroma. I enjoyed this beer. Although i could only drink a few at a time. Very stylized taste
The Abby Brown Ale we tasted was from draft.  It was lingering, mellow, caramelly, lingering, delicate, flavorful and lingering.  Did I mention lingering?  Great beer.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2003 A fruity, slightly sweet aroma start off this glorious brew.  Flavor features the same fruitiness, and is really quite nice.  Corsendonk just makes some great brews.

Very enjoyable beer. Nice copper color and big fluffy head. It's sweet, almost too sweet, but still good. It also has a sweet aroma. Spicey flavor like other belgian strongs. This is a very enjoyable beer.
Good beer nice head solid winter beer with a nice finish.  No bite or bitter aftertaste

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2003 a very rich and thick beer. a bit too fizzy, for the cork nearly put my eye out. i also poured a little too fast. maybe it was the car ride. anyway, it has a nice bitter bite blended with a creamy chocolate that manages to not be very sweet, but adds in for a great flavor. give it a shot and watch that cork.
Not crazy about this ale.  Sweet, doughy and sour flavor made be too sweet for my taste.

murky copper , fluffy head. thin mouthfeel. tart but earthy aroma.  tastes the same as the aroma, slightly tart but mostly rich--plummy,raisiny, whichever. i am very sad to rate this tasty beer on the day the columbia crashed.

The ebullient, frothy texture of this beer is misleading, it seems to me - it gives a sense of lightness to the brew that on this go round I found engaging and interesting, but which might lead to a hasty dismissal in other circumstances.  Instead, I rise with the ether, enjoying the seemingly effortless play of dark flavors (cocoa, raisins, yeast, and plum wine) in the lighter body.  It makes me want to rethink some of my dismissals of Unibroue products, anyway.
The colour is dark amber, with a good persistent foam. The taste is much more delicate than I thought, with light traces of fruits. A good Belgian ale, but not really the best one.

(750 ml Bottle) Beautiful deep ruby colour with a thick, frothy, mostly lasting beige head. Aroma of alcohol and spice. An acidic taste with lingering hints spice and a smokey cask. Very interesting and flavourful but I'd rather have something from Unibroue for this price.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2011 2010-08-12, bottle at Ris Ras, Århus, 8-4-6-3-14=35Dark brown color; generous head, compact. The mix of dark malt and spices constitutes a nice arome, there is also a hint of Belgian yeast. The body is less strong than expected, a dry roastiness steers it in that direction too; mild flavor of roasted malt, medium to low bitterness, too simple. Balanced, but the Agnus Dei is better.2003-01-11, draught, 9-5-8-5-17=44Clean dark amber color; generous, thick brownish head. Strong spicy aroma (cloves, cardamom, curaçao...). Good body strength, more on the sweet side (more balanced in the end); still some alcohol; again the same spices (a lot). Good and long final.Spicy strong Belgian ale, very good quality.

Cloudy copper color, huge off-white head which slowly diminished to leave strong lace.  Aroma is yeaty, doughy, bready.  Flavor is quite sweet and fruity - raisin, cotton candy, and a slight bubblegum and banana in there.  Very tingly mouthfeel.  There are many Belgian ales that far surpass this one.
Classy packaging.  Quite fruity.  No outstanding flavour as I was expecting.  Lightness makes it very drinkable.
Very, very spicey. Re-rate: Very sparkling and prickly on the tonque.
A bit light for such a strong ale. Very nice head, like the Agnus a bit fizzy.
sweet, sugary.  Aroma comes through as nice fruit, which also comes through vaguley on the palate.  I just want more flavor from this one.  It has potential.
Sweet and strongly sparkling dark ale from Belgium. Tastes very lite for a strong ale. Fruity flavours of many fruits. Definetely not my taste. Give me grapefruit soda instead!

Nothing special here.  Nice reddish brown cloudy color.  Fluffy head that didnt seem to last.  No lace at all.  Body was thin.  Flavor was good, sweet and sour throughout.  Fruit at the end.  Love the bottle though!!
Almost red or burgandy in color as I hold it up to the light.  Very soft, creamy and balanced head.  Very sparkly and fizzy in my mouth.  Also very fruity finish.
Lactic aroma. Brown color, light brown head, fair lace. Sweet and sour, orange, bit thin. Short finish. You can drink it and wont regret it. But I wouldnt buy it again.

Very nice beer. Its interesting to find an Abbey "brown ale;" I tend to associate brown ales with thick chocolatey/espresso malt and a fair amount of hops, but this is...well...
very Belgian. Beautiful mahogony beneath a large head - smells of dates and plum. Full malt infused with currant and port. Kind of dusty and nice and mellow.

A superior beer that I would like to get to know better. Tasted at Chris & Jacks Belgian Bar in Namur, Wisconsin, which is the place to stop for Belgians when youre driving from Green Bay to Door County.
It is a little fruity and wine-like for me, but it isn;t bad.  I dont think i would recognize it as a brown ale by taste.

A good dubble.  Very rich in flavor.  Nice aroma.  I sampled the draught version.  
Re-rate.  Have sampled bottled version also.  Very smooth and tasty.  Both are excellent.
Smooth drinking beer hints of malt and fruit

Brown with large tan head.
Malt nose. Good full bodied 
malty faintly fruit taste

this beer tried to kill me and almost gave me a heart attack too, but ill save that for another day..ruby redness gleaming from beneath a gigantic peachy head...aroma was yeasty with lemon zest & honey and tea..flavor was yeasty..fruity notes of lemons, strawberries, and grapes..some green raisin..maybe a tad plum & nectarine..the yeastiness almost completely subsides..complexity in changing flavors..banana bread..sugary coating..the aroma changes to chocolate mouse as does the flavor..then yeastiness comes back again..the head always sitting thick and clumpy..
Brownish colour with a light brown head. Fruity aroma with notes of plums and some caramel as well. Flavour is sweet and somewhat yeasty. Stand upp well to a chocolate dessert.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2004 12 oz capped bottle best before 09/09/05. Pours hazy brown-amber color with a huge light brown head that sticks to the glass. Fruity sweet and spicy aromas, sugary plum and grape flavors, medium bodied with a crisp mouthfeel, finishes dry clean, not what I expected but still a good choice
Big off white head.  Sweet, molasses, raison nose.  Dark ruddy brown hue.  Port like sweetness, dark fruit, yeast in the finish.  A very interesting ale.  Well done.
Dark color, bit cloudy. Spicy malty aroma. Soft sweet malty taste.

Rerate 10/19/2002:  A very malty ale.  Excellent rich head, nice color, like the raisins in the nose.  Huge amounts of candy sugar in this one, a sparkling, lilting sweetness that dances on the tongue and makes my teeth tingle.  Malts are quite chewy, plenty of fruit, cookies, and general malty goodness.  Me like plenty.  Must be some problems with transport, as Ive had two completely disgusting bottles, but the majority are just lovely.

Yeasty smoky? aroma. Nice brownish red color.
Fruity, plums, raisins. Oily mouthfeel. Chocolaty finish.
This is a very nice Dubbel,  It has that slightly moldy taste that it seems that a lot of the Dubbels have.  I like this better that Chimay Red and Allagash Dubbel
very nice flavor, a little over carbed but light and refreshing(for a brown ale)not as strong as i would have thought, but decent never the less.
Rerate: upon reflection, I had to lower my rating for this because, basically, it sucks and I dont care where it comes from.

This was bland.  Almost offensively inoffensive.  The head was large, but dissapated quickly.  There was no complexity to speak of, although it did manage to hide the alcohol content well.  A decent beer to get drunk by, but I expected something more.
On tap. Very pleasant flavour with some heavy fruits (plums! etc.). Apparantly quite a few female Danish beer enthusiasts really like this ale.

Sweet fruity winey nose that flowed over onto the tastebuds.  Fig cookie and baking chocolate can be found along the way with a slightly bitter end. The alcohol is well masked until the end, where it comes through a little stronger.

Nice dark colour and fine light brown head. A very fruity beer. Banana, candied pineapple, plums and some mango in the aroma. Alcoholic and yeasty flavour with notes of port wine and fruit. Rather complex and good.
Decent beer.
Good belgian, great looking beer and aroma, slightly sour with malt and hints of fruit, nice

This beer rocks. 
A very good belgian ale. Give it a shot, but not until youre sure your beer store doesnt have Chimay, Orval, Allagash, Ommegang, Rochefort or any of the Westvleterens.
Malty aroma with apple. Also malt and apple in the flavor, combined with coffee and just a bit of sourness. A bit onedimensional.

The aroma from this beer is spectacular, full of sweet fruits and yeast. Beautiful colour, and a big head that lasts for ages. The flavour wasnt quite as assertive as I expected based in the aroma, but was still pleasant, fruity and malty. Dont come looking for hoppiness, however, cause you wont find much of that here.
Well balanced beer. Dark amber colour. Good lasting head. Sweet and refreshing, in the end more a bitter taste. Definately a good brew but not as good as his brother the Agnes.
Amber coloured with a big head. Slightly sour taste. Hop and malt in a good cobination.

A deep brown color and thick firm head made this a very attractive beer.  The aroma was unspectacular and hinted lightly of malty sugar.  The taste cleared right throw my mouth beautifully.  This beer is what would happen if an IPA and Stout had a child.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 Rich, warm, yeasty brew. Very drinkable and friendly to drinker. Simplistic but in best production. Nice !
a good brown ale.  after experiementing with a few begians tonight,  this was my favorite.

Very floral and fruity aroma with hints of citrus.  Yeasty smelling very appealing.  Nice beautiful color, persistant head.  Great appearance.  Malty and almost bread like flavor very nice.  Hints of fruit, alcohol very apparent.  Good Drink.  Finishes well, goes down too easy.  Waaaay to easy.
pours with a huge and very well retained head.  lovely reddish brown colour.  sweetish aroma, chocolate and dried curranty taste.

Rerate August 16  2002 Clear dark-cola brown with medium-large beige and this time slower dissipating head (I think my pouring skills are improving). 
Dried raisiny fruit and chocolate, stronger malt and some hints of yeasty over-ripe fruit and alcohol in the aroma. Medium to light body with sweetish start moving to a more balanced bitter middle palate and flavours that closely mirror the aromas. Despite the general sweetness, even in the aftertaste, the overall finish is clean and crisp and pleasantly refreshing. Still a classic Belgian! 
Second rating July 20 2002: 4 First rating  June 3 2002: 4

I can taste the Belgain Sugar here,dark brown color with little head on the first pour, as it warmed the head grew, & on the 2nd pouring it filled the glass to the top. I can taste  carmel, raisins,and malty sweetness of a Belgian Strong Ale dominates.This Nice Belgian Ale would make a fine introduction to those who prefer macro-brews.
A beer with a fanstastic aroma and a very beutiful head. It has a very beutiful amber color. And has a great filling taste with hints of fruit.
A malty smooth beer. Can really taste the hint of raisins and dark Chocolate.
Nice dubbel. Malty, a little sweet, caramel, some raisins.

nice light brown color with slight head- med head.  My favorite abbey dubbel so far.  Aroma was complex with some alcohol and some hints of port and sherry and nice malt aroma.  Flavor was very strong with lots of belgian malt and some hops - and some coriander.  Very smooth and easy to drink an entire bottle.  Left me wanting another.
rich aroma with a beautiful dark tan mostly opaque color. malty smooth with just a hint of bitter. robust flavor without overwhelming. excellent aftertaste

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Wonderful appearance, cloudy dark-brown with thick, long-lasting head. Complex aroma, roasted malts, fruity and a bit yeasty. When aged the aroma strongly resembles a Flemish Sour Ale, very fruity, really nice. Complex flavour: chocolate, roasted malts, fruity, some sourness, raisins, it’s all in there. Smooth finish. From tap it’s a bit disappointing, but bottled (especially when aged) this is pretty good.
First Belgian Strong I was introduced too. It was a happy memory. Very palatable, very drinkable, very flavorful and enjoyable.

Once again a pretty solid beer from Corsendonk. Deep brown amber colour, malty yeasty nose, slight sweet start, malty caramel flavour, fairly dry finish, and not overly complex. Cool bottle design aswell.

This girl that I know had never tasted a belgian beer.  And couldnt understand why I find belgians (beers, that is) so outstanding.  After trying to describe the difference between lambics, wits, dubbels and triples, I un-corked a Corsendonk.  No better way to explain than through show and tell.  She read the description on the bottle and blurted but I HATE raisons!  I calmed her fears by assuring her that this beer would not taste like raisons.  It would be dark, rich, with mild hints of chocolate and slightly sweet but not obnoxious.  After finishing the bottle, she agreed that belgian beer is rather remarkable.  Say no more, nudge nudge, wink wink.

This beer poured a dark brownish amber color and formed a light tan head that left little lace(might have had chilled too cold). Some degree of carbonation. The aroma was of grapes/raisin. The flavor was of grapes/raisin, spice and light chocolate. The finish was a bit tart with some elements of the grape and spice. A good ale which hides the alcohol fairly well.

Bottle with cap.  Cloudy brown appearance with a nice head that dissipates quickly.  The aroma is wonderful, sort of a pine, fruity, and yeasty mix.  The flavor is typically brown in that it is subtle and smooth but has some of the Belgian brilliance.  Hints of lemon, sugars, citrus, raisins, and apples.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005 Agressive carbonation nearly smothering the light molasses in brandyNutty apricot sweetness and roasted malt bitterness mingle with the lemon and wood puddingSatisfying for a quaffer, disappointing for a rich dubbel...
UPDATED: APR 17, 2003 Lots of fruit in the aroma (apples, pears, plums?)  Lots of flavour in this one.  Had a large almost fizzy white head.  Also had notes of chocolate in the aftertaste.
A little bitter for me, but the shapness definitely died down a bit as it warmed.  Nice complex flavor, a little heavy on the alcohol taste.

Thanks to aracauna for this one (although it turns out you can find it in Ohio after all...). Thick, slowly dissipating head that lasted pretty much the whole glass. Rather dark amber color. Very complex aroma with hints of caramel and fruit (was that really raisin?). This one definitely improved as it approached room temperature. I am looking forward to trying the Pale Ale.
A strong, sweet Burgundy-colored ale with a rich full flavor. Some notes of fruit and alcohol were present. Quite good.
Muddy brown - like chocolate milk in color, pleasant aroma, mild nuttiness, quite nice, full-flavored, an out of the ordinary brew, significantly more alcohol than most, much maltiness.  Good!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 May 2002 original, then rerated April 2003, now rerated March 2005. Wow, has this sunk in my estimation. Draught, for the first time, reveals the real underlying sugariness and lack of smokiness that would help. Let this warm up for best effect, and maybe it wasnt designed for draught consumption. -- heres the original: I really really like this! The aroma is fantastic...malted, musty like old leather, yeasty. The taste is easy to handle, but if you really think about it, it is complex, sweet but not overly (raisins, bread dough). Man, this and the pale are both excellent! And, I gather, fairly accessible. Is this *the* combo of best and most accessible of the Belgian breweries?
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: a nice maltiness characteristic of a brown ale, but more complex than most ive had.  a little sweet/tangy and finish reminiscent of a white wine.  had to experiment with temperature a little.

excellent dense head, very rocky lots of lace and when  I finished sipping the contents of the (750ml) bottle an hour later the head was still there. Aromas of butterscotch, caramel and wood. Very vinous and figgy with a hint of earthy cork notes and a trace of phenol. sweet and smooth finish with more vinous/citric hints.
Interesting aroma of spice, fruit, and some hints of alchohol. Wonderfully rich in flavor, from chocolatey roasted malt notes to a bounty of fruit flavors, notable cherry and green apple. Great beer.

strong rich aroma. appearance is what id expect from a brown ale. the bottle i got was strongly carbonated, with almost unidentifible taste of fruit and smoky grains. this brew reminds me alot of chimay bleu. need to do a side by side comparison for reference.
Nice darker version,not quite the alcohol presence as some,fruity,slight smoke flavor,smoked barely???

A little more fruity and tangy than I tend to like beers to be, but it worked well in this one. Tastes almost like a mix of chapaigne and beer, which doesnt sound all that appealing, but was quite good nonetheless.

A great dark, malty aroma.  Has a fruity hint too.  Good brown appearance.  Initial flavor is pretty complex.  Cidery... tangy.  Has an almost champagne like kick to it for an aftertaste.  You can taste the strenght.
This was a little better than the pale ale, however it is a lot more burpier.  Either a lot of yeast was added in the beginning or in the end.  It has port undertones with a suttle smokey flavor.

Very strong malty aroma.
Head disappeared quite quickly. Taste of raisins, malt. Nice round mouthfeel.

Large foamy head, light tan. Its a nice deep ruby brown color. Its a very aromatic beer. I could smell the floral fruitiness if it before I even got near the glass. There may be some caramel to the flavor and some sharp citrus aspects. Some sweetness, as well. A little disapointing because of its lack of complexity. Good beer, ok Belgian.
I can see this being a pleaser for you mud-lovers out there but even with a respect for Belgian beers I was not impressed. A pretty lame overall flavor. I had to really work to finish the glass.

Okay, Im rating this from draft, not from bottles.  Its quite good, with good flavor and, like its paler cousin, very pleasant to drink with excellent fruity tones.  From the bottle its far too sweet and not nearly as enjoyable.
Yummy.. complex beyond belief.. goes down like water despite its hefty alcohol content..

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2005 Had this beer for the first time in The Burp castle in the Village in Manhattan. Wonderfully tasting beer with the alcohol content to go with it. Its a relaxing drink, very hoppy and a bit sweet. But one of my favorites, price withstanding.
One of my all time favorites. A must for any beer lover.

This is what I wrote before they changed the recipe. This beer used to be the best. Its a shadow of its former self now. Some monk got his palm greased and went off into a corner?!?

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2005 750ml bottle. Head is initially large sized, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is medium brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, roasted nuts), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of raisin and brown sugar. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is moderately sweet, liglhtly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.  An overly sweet, somewhat sticky rendition that doesnt smell or taste too much like a dubbel. I seem to remember this having more character years ago, but maybe Ive just found better things since. Very simple.
Smells of fruit and nuts. Russet colour. Like drinking a raison and peanut chocolate bar. Lucious.
Better than their pale. Port and raisins, I agree with the Commercial Description.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2003 One of my favourites right now.  But my taste changes like the wind..;-)  Anyway one you need to try more than once.

Bottled 1/3 liter.  Beautiful opaque thick brown color with a creamy tan head.  Nose aged, yeasty, caramelly, bittersweet.  Flavor malty but not really distinctive; doesnt have enough guts I guess.  Rather highly carbonated for a dubbel, I think; nicely warming and smooth as it goes down.
My favorite Belgian so far. Dark brown, best at room temp, the best part is from the bottom of the bottle with all the wonderful sediment!
I love the raisins.
Wonderful black chocolate aroma with a nice raison and other fruit notes.  Definately could use more of a malt presence.

Deep brown/red. Ok head and lace. Huge malty nose with raisons and plums. Very lush and a bubbly(in a creamy sort of way) in the mouth. Palate is filled with port flavors, raisons, lively as hell and some nice alcohol warmth. IMHO it can use some more malt development, that would seal the deal but this is good stuff!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 This beer has an outstanding flavor.  I was very impressed.  Highly recommend.  Even if you cant afford to buy lots of it, buy one bottle and enjoy. This was the beer that turned me into a beer geek.

RERATE:  I have been avoiding the rerate of this beer because I knew it would come down in its standing.  It was the beer that really turned me into a beer geek and I dont want to hurt its rating but here goes....  Plum red color with a huge rocky head.  Very attractive aroma of dark fruit and spice.  Mouthfeel is well carbonated but very smooth.  A tad watery.  Flavor has a good amount of spice and fruit.  This is still great stuff, but I only rated it as highly as I did because it was my first Belgian.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 I"m pretty much copying Gusler"s remarks, as he has the description dead on. Deep brown color, front sweet and malty, the middle is light to medium with moderate carbonation, the finish is slightly sour, quite acidic, alcohol tones evident.  I noticed little hop presence. I also thought this beer was a little light to the palate for my liking.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 re rate-corked:  If you pour this into a more narrow glass, like a Corsendonk glass, it forms a mountainous roucky head with unattractive soapy looking bubbles.  If poured in a chalice, as I did with the second pouring, and let it sit, it forms an extremely creamy top with a ring of darker large bubbles.  This is the only time I have ever witnessed such a thing.  Aroma is caramel, raisins, and very perfumey.  I detected wood, cork, and light vanilla in the flavor.  Mouthfeel is effervescent.  The finish has an acidic feel, with hints of apples lingering for some time.  IMO, this is more of a hybrid Bruin/Dubbel.  Very appetizing.  96 bottling.  I had this two years ago and was not impressed, so I decided to put some in my parents cellar.  It has improved drastically.  Caramel notes alongside apples, raisins, and warming alcohol, combined to make this an elegant brew.  Surprisingly, this really did improve with a little age.  IMO, this beer was at its peak near room temp as it released the qualities of malt depth, of which it had none at 53 degrees.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: The first time I had this beer was from draft in Belgium and I enjoyed it thoroughly.  It is definitely not as good out of the bottle, too sweet with too many fruit notes and not well balanced.
Nice raisin fruit flavor with some cotton candy sweetness. The yeast at the end adds a nice touch. Excellent ale.

Nice deep brown color, generous light brown head, that dissipates rather quickly, but the lace clings mightly to the glass. The nose is fruity, plums, over ripe apples maybe. Front sweet, malty, the middle is light to medium, moderate carbonation, the finish is slightly sour, quite acidic, alcohol tones evident, and a light touch of hops in this dry finishing beer. Good, and well worth the  expense.

Very interesting.  I wasnt crazy about the aroma, but was quite impressed by the flavor, mouthfeel and head.  Its a very nice combination of flavors, and the port and raisin do stand out well.  Got a bit heavy toward the end, but overall, a unique and impressive ale.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 23, 2005 bubbly beer that has the feel of champagne and the taste of a fine belgian ale.  great beer!
A good belgian, though I expect that thls would be better laid away. Nice look, and the bottle has a good feel. Satisfying palate. Cidery, more mellow than the golden Belgians.

Fruity aroma gives way quickly to strong hints of currants and chocolate.  There is something in here I cant identify, some taste, but it is pleasant nonetheless.  Overall not my favorite Belgian, but still excellent.  I especially like the lingering, sweet finish.  A second place finish to Chimay Bleu.
It had a nice aroma and a nice color, but I didnt care too much for the taste.  It was too much like apples, and I guess I am just not that much of an apple fan.
This is a beer for a nice relaxed evening with just you and your beer
Excellent, smooth flavor. One of the best brews I have tried. Each bottle has been a pleasant experience. The Brown Ale is a much better selection than the Pale Ale. A taste exquisite.
Too sweet and buttery. Im going to put one away and see what happens.
Definately better balanced then the Abbey Pale, IMO.
Very rich and complex -- raisin and nutty - bready and somewhat chocolate tasting.  Beautiful head -- definitely a beer I will pursue again - much better than the pale ale. Cheers!
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: I actually liked this much better than corsendonks abbey pale ale.  Much smoother and less hoppy with a great head on it.
Fruity aroma with a thick creamy head. Sweet, toasty, woody, chocolatey, port like taste with a slight hoppiness.

Nice cloudy dark red color, huge head.  Pour carefully, or youre going to have to wait 10 minutes to drink it.  Spicy, yeasty, sweet malty aroma.  Chocolate, yeast, sweetness dominates the palate.  Nice beer, I wonder  how it is after a few years?  Well see.
this has a fruit and spice flavor.  A little bite on the tongue from the alcohol, but its not bad.  I recommend it, but not my favorite abbey ale.  So far, Chimay holds that title.
Decent if unmemorable belgian double.  Decent yeasy character with raisin-candi sugar aroma.
Its a belgian dubbel, which is good. However, its not a good belgian dubbel. Just not a lot of flavor in this one. Not bad but it paled in comparision to the Ommegang which I had afterword.
Very good with dinner.  Flavers in this beer were pleasing; on the sweet side to me.
Promising initial flavor gives quickly into-- nothing in the back of the throat. Tastes better after its had the cap off for half an hour or so.

All I can say is amazing.  Raisin aroma with some yeast in the nose.  Even more pronounced raisin flavors with some minor port wine notes.  Thick, rich brownish head that sticks around.  Deep, muddy brown color and great body.  I will be drinking it again and again.
preferred the other corsendonk. dug the bottle though
What a great looking beer. Beautiful head that sticks to my moustache. Has a rather wonderful apple under-tone. A rather dry finish. Good, but I like their pale ale better.

a great brown.
has sweet and sour tastes
Pretty good, yet just doesnt seem as outstanding as many of the other Belgians i have had.
Absolutely delicious.  But what a price!!
One of the best looking glasses around. Carmel, yeast and alcohol aroma, effervescent and plenty of mouthfeel. Interesting but not gripping. Still a mighty fine brew.

Intitially a bit malty, perhaps even fruity. Nice, creamy head. My enjoyment of this was hampered only slightly by a very subtle alcohol taste, almost as if it were a cocktail instead of a beer. Still very good, and worth a try.

Its tough for a beer of this style to not be enjoyable, but this one let me down a little for the price. I cant taste any hops and all of the flavor disappears almost immediately. It has a strong initial chocolate/fruity malt that quickly disappears. Very smooth, but not too exciting.

This beer has a strong raisin aroma that is just slightly stronger than the taste.  If one were to combine the flavors of raisins and brandy, I imagine this as the result.   Alcohol slightly pervades the smell, probably the only negative thing I can say about this beer.  Creamy head and an attractive dark brown color make this beer look as good as it tastes.
Mice fruity flavors. Some choclate. Nice head. Great bottle. Potent 25 oz bottle.

Very nice double. More than a little reminiscent of my personnal beloved Piraat. Nicely spiced with a raisin quality. It has a bit of a metallic taste that I could do without, but this subsides on the third or fourth nip. I will be serving this one again and again
Not as good as some of the better beers Ive had recently, but very tasty and nice to drink.
The lack of assertive yeast in welcome in this dubbel, as it allows the malt and dark fruit (especially raisin) to show through.  Problem is, those malt flavours are not particularly well-developed.
Sweet, mild, and unmistakably Belgian.
I love this. Smooth, yet spicy.
Really good.  Bubbly like champagne, with a real different flavor.
Awsome Belgian Brown

Goes great with cheese. After
laying down for 9 months 
some flavors mellow, maybe 
too much so.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2004 2000 vintage, sampled 03/2004 - dark ruby-brown colour, fine head, strange aroma of unfermented malt, caramel, sweet and medium-bodied with an unpleasant vegetables aftertaste - not exactly what I remembered. Could have been altered, I will have to retry it

Inconsistent color in the glass. 
Not much head.  Aroma is pungent and
sweet.  Flavor is clearly sour, yeasty,
and malty.  Not bad - but surprisingly more
like a gueuze that an abbey ale.
Sourness remains but other flavors come out
as you finish it, giving it a nice complexity.
An enjoyable creation.
watch out for this one......
